PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KEATING
TALKER.ROLE: Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: I inform the House that Senator Richardson resigned from the Ministry and as Vice-President of the Executive Council last Monday, 18 May. Senator Collins is Acting Minister for Transport and Communications. Questions on the Transport and Communications portfolio should be directed to Mr Beazley, Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I inform the House that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Bilney, is on sick leave this week. In his absence, questions should be directed to Mr Beazley, Minister for Employment, Education and Training.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. I remind him that since this Parliament last sat 19 days ago, as many as 9,000 Australians could have joined the dole queues. Can the Prime Minister tell the House exactly what he has done since the Parliament last met to create jobs for our nearly one million unemployed?

—On the macro-economic front—the front that matters most to employment, GDP, job creation and wealth—the Government, through the successful prosecution of its fight against inflation, was able to see interest rates decline by one per cent. In those ensuing two weeks we have had quite a deal of response to the confirmation of lower inflation in the economy as a result of that inflation and the interest rate numbers.

PARA.TAB: I suppose the best manifestation of this was the Westpac Bank's writing off $2.6 billion of losses, writing off the 1980s' inflation fetish, writing off the economy as the largest trading bank—

TALK.START.PARA: —You were the Treasurer.

—Where did the high inflation come from? From 20 years of you! Writing away the inflation fetish of Australians, of Australian investment, of the fetish with inflation, of the fascination with inflation, not mooning around with a property book waiting for property to lift under another inflationary cycle, Westpac, to its credit, said, `It is over. We are cutting the 1980s out. We are not going to have the bank's profits compromised by continual write-offs. We are not mooning around waiting for inflation to pick up. We believe the Government, that long term inflation is down'.

PARA.TAB: This of course was reiterated by the Deputy Governor of the central bank—he was attacked for it by the Leader of the Opposition a couple of days later—when he said that inflation is now at 2 1/2 to 3 per cent and could be sustained. That has certainly been the view of Westpac; it is certainly the view of the business community. The low inflation outcome which we have seen and the interest rates which have attended it, and the announcement by the Treasurer and the Governor of the central bank for a further one per cent reduction in interest rates, bring interest rates to 6.6 per cent for 90-day bills and of that order for 180-day bills, which are the lowest interest rates since the 1960s.

TALK.START.PARA: —The highest unemployment rate.
—The honourable member for Casey will cease interjecting.

—Now we see inflationary expectations, not just statistical inflation, again trending down and the long term bond rate, where the market fixes its own view on what inflation will be, of around 9 per cent. That is what we have done to get the economy going in the last two weeks. That is what is happening in the real world, the world beyond the flim-flam of Opposition press statements, the real world where people are out there watching now a pick-up in retail sales, motor vehicle sales and housing starts—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—You need to do better than this.
—Order! The honourable member for Lowe!

—I know, you hate any good news. You hate any recovery news. You hate any news about anything good on the economy. You wish the economy the worst. You actually sit back and grin at every problem that is in evidence in the media for general members of the public, thinking it will advance your political cause. The fact is that we are now laying the basis for a long term low inflationary recovery in the 1990s. Nothing has brought this more into evidence than the low inflation rate and the interest rates which are now attending it, the structural decline in the current account deficit and the improvement in the current account beyond the Budget forecast. It is woeful news for the Opposition. No wonder you have asked your question.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Is the Treasurer familiar with the argument that rising prices rob people of their savings and also discourage savings? Can the Treasurer provide the House with any recent statistics on this issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am familiar with the argument and so too, apparently, is the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. On 15 May last year he said in this House:

ANSWER.PARA: It is also indisputable that the economic and social costs of high inflation are very great. . . . It robs people of their savings. It discourages savings. It is theft.
It discourages productive investment. . . It distorts investment patterns.

You would think that, if that were his true view about inflation, he would be applauding the fact that the Government had been able to produce consumer price index growth in March of zero, and a rate for the 12 months up until March of just l.7 per cent, with the underlying rate estimated by Treasury of 3 per cent and falling. You would think that the Opposition would be applauding this. You would think it would be congratulating the Government on ending inflation's robbery of people's savings and congratulating the Government for encouraging savings and encouraging a productive pattern of investment.

PARA.TAB: Instead, the Opposition is doing two things: it is blackguarding anyone in an official position, particularly the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank, for making the simple observation that inflation has come down and can stay down. Anyone who makes that observation is worthy of nothing but a scurrilous attack from the Opposition. The second thing is that members of the Opposition are about sparking a new surge in inflation in Australia, because their policies are about deliberately aggravating inflation and deliberately increasing the average price level by 4.7 per cent; that is, in their own terms, they would rob every Australian of 4.7 per cent of the value of their savings. It would, in that sense, be a tax on wealth, an arbitrary confiscation of 4.7 per cent of the money in every pensioner's bank account, every young person's building society account and every child's piggy bank. You would not even be safe by taking on board the advice of the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, when he said, `Put your money under the bed'. It would not even be safe there, because the Opposition's theft, the Opposition's inflation, would not save your money under your bed.

Of course, this would only be the first instalment because, as Australians know all too well, once the inflation genie is out of the bottle it takes a very long time to wring it out of the economy again. Members of the Opposition claim to have a compensation package which would deal with all of the shortcomings of their inflation inducing policy. But it is full of holes. It is full, first of all, of that big $6 billion hole, which means that they cannot even fund the proposed compensation package. But, even if they could, it applies only to those who are 60 years of age or over in 1994; it applies only to money which earned interest in 1992-93; and, in order to qualify for full compensation, you need to have an annual income of below $20,000 in 1993-94.

If you are 59 years or under in 1994, the Opposition will rob you of 5 per cent of your hard-earned savings and give you nothing back. There is nothing in the wealth compensation package for you if you are under 60 in 1994.
Opposition members—Wrong! Wrong!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order!

—Let us imagine someone who sold his house in late 1993 or got a superannuation pay-out or a life insurance policy paid out at that time. Again, the Opposition says, `Tough. We will confiscate 5 per cent of the value of whatever you receive'. In other words, 5 per cent just goes up in smoke. What if you retire in the middle of 1994, having earned anything more than about three-quarters of average weekly earnings in 1993-94? Again, the Opposition would say, `Tough' to you because you would have fallen through one of the many holes that exist in the wealth compensation package proposed by the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: If you are one of the aged pensioners who actually qualify for the compensation package, you would have to fill out forms and wait until they are processed just to get back the money that the coalition has robbed you of. The Leader of the Opposition was quite correct last year when he said that increasing prices and increasing inflation is theft. That means that Fightback is theft.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

—Order! If the honourable member for Bass does not resume his seat, I will deal with him.
—The honourable member for Bass will resume his seat. I warn the honourable member for Bass that, if he behaves like that again, I will deal with him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If one of his colleagues suggests he is learning, he might learn faster.

—I thank the honourable member for Kooyong for his concern. I am sure it is a pity that he did not share the same concern with his friend the honourable member for Hume. We might get this debate back on the right plane.
—The honourable member for Bass just revealed his total inexperience in the running of the House, just as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition revealed his inexperience in the business of Budget—

—There is no point of order. If honourable members on my left cease interjecting the Treasurer might be able to answer the question.
—Order! The House will come to order.

—Order! The honourable member for Cowper will cease interjecting.

—Mr Speaker, you will see these increasingly desperate tactics on the part of members of the Opposition. As they see any glimmer of hope for the economy or for Australia all they will do is simply attempt, again, to sabotage that improved result.

—Mr, Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145, concerning relevance. The Minister was given an opportunity to get back to the point of the question. He has failed, and is continuing to fail, to address it. Therefore, I ask you to direct him to get back to the question now.
—There is no point of order. I call the Treasurer.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting.
—The chance to answer would be a fine thing. There have been three Opposition-inspired interruptions so far.

PARA.TAB: Mr Atkinson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for Isaacs.

—It is not clear to me whether the Opposition is remotely interested in the answer that I am giving. What the Opposition, and particularly the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, would not understand is the process of putting Budgets together. What this Government is very experienced at, and indeed what this Government has in terms of a peerless record, is an ability to put together Budgets in all kinds of circumstances.

PARA.TAB: It is true that, as a result of a much-improved inflation position and declining interest rates, the predicted revenue for this year was not realised; that is, there was not as much revenue collected from non-PAYE individuals because inflation was coming down and earnings were lower because of cuts in interest rates. That is the primary reason why the revenue is not as great as was anticipated and why the deficit is larger than was anticipated. But, as the Government sits down to put together this Budget, it will be concerned to do a couple of things. First of all, it will be concerned, once again—
Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.
—to exercise the kind of restraint on expenditures for which we are famous.
—What about an answer to the question?
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—That is a fundamental ingredient of the size of the deficit—that is, the extent to which we can continue to bear down on outlays growth. Secondly, the Government will look at the components of the revenue. If the honourable member thinks that in the context of looking at the revenue side of the Budget we would not look at any of the individual components of the revenue, he has no idea at all about how this Budget is going to be put together. But if he is trying to suggest that, in order to curtail the size of the deficit for next year, we would have resort to some new tax of the kind that the Opposition has in mind, of course he is wrong. He is wrong and he will continue to be wrong.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I ask him whether he has seen the recent remarks of the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank concerning Australia's inflation rate. Does the Prime Minister agree that we have witnessed a structural reduction in inflation? What are the implications of this for economic recovery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree that we have witnessed a structural reduction in inflation. The implications of this for economic recovery are profound—that is, it will give confidence about competitiveness; it will permit lower levels of interest rates and, therefore, over time, higher levels of investment and spending, particularly on the investment side; and it will have long term implications for Australia's competitive position in the world.

PARA.TAB: The Deputy Governor of the central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, said as much in a speech last week called `Structural Adjustment to Low Inflation'. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: but it has been our view—
that is, the Reserve Bank's view—

for some time that we have made a structural downward shift in inflation and that, with reasonable policies, we should be able to retain it. There has been a fall in inflationary expectations this time which we have never had before.
He goes on to amplify the points with charts, and he goes on to say:

First, the rate of growth of earnings has come down pari passu with the rate of inflation. In the event, there turned out to be no `floor'. What was left of the centralised system was flexible enough to adjust to the recession and the sharp fall in consumer prices.
He is talking about wage flexibility. He goes on to say:

Second, for the first time that I am aware, the union movement has accepted the principle that Australian wages should be determined in relation to the growth in prices and wages of our trading partners. This is a very big change of attitude, and it mirrors some other changes that are going on in the economy at the same time.

He talks about the underlying rate being probably 2 1/2 to 3 per cent. I concur with those sentiments and I concur with the attempt by the Deputy Governor to inculcate a lower inflationary culture in the economy. Need I say that that speech was met with a hostile political attack—a shabby, irresponsible political attack by the Leader of the Opposition—an attack which today brought these headlines:
Hewson's charge puts his own credibility at risk.
When we go through it he has this to say:

I must admit, when I read Ian Mcfarlane's speech from yesterday I was amazed, to put it mildly, at the claim in effect that we had beaten inflation, and that inflation would stay at somewhere between 2.5 and 3 per cent from now on under the sort of policies that are in prospect under this government. And as I read the paper, I thought it was without question the best argument I've ever seen for why the Reserve Bank should have a good shake-up.

That is, no more independence, just get rid of it; `shake up' meaning `tip it out'. This is a career central banker, a career bureaucrat, who has not been appointed to the lofty position from the Treasury or anywhere else. But he says it is a good reason for a shake up. This is the rhetoric of independence from a person who the former Governor—

TALK.START.PARA: —You had them in your pocket, Keating.
—The honourable member for Gilmore will cease interjecting.

—The former Governor, Mr Bob Johnston, said that you had to be an insider to know this has always been so. He was talking about relations with the Government—he was referring to good relations with this Government—
—In your pocket.
—Order!

—No. But they told me about your thugging the central bank in those days, about your ringing the central bank, trying to direct it on interest rates, while you have the gall to talk about independence. Then you say to this person, a career person, that that is a good reason for a shake up, to tip them out. You go on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: And that is, if it does go over 3 per cent he ought to be willing to resign his position.

In other words, it is a personal matter now about Macfarlane and his job. He goes and does the sensible thing, as you would enjoin him to do with an independent central bank, to go and proselytise for low inflation. He goes and does it and wears this from you. I get concerned that if it actually works out, it will almost certainly blow this country out of the water. You were talking about Government policy—

TALK.START.PARA: —One Nation!

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Both inflation and the balance of payments are very near time. Of course there are other quotes from you where you say that it was blatantly political. You state:

ANSWER.PARA: I think he is prepared to come out and make a blatantly political statement without any evidence to substantiate that view. I think he has a greater responsibility than that.

What is `blatantly political'? Is it referring to the statistical inflation rate at 2 1/2 to 3 per cent, underlying at zero for the quarter, 1.7 per cent for the year? What is blatantly political about referring to zero inflation for the quarter, 1.7 per cent for the year, and an underlying rate of 2 1/2 to 3 per cent and referring, as he did, to the fact that the unions have provided wage flexibility and have agreed to look at the inflation rate of our trading partners? What a shocking thing to say, to make a commentary on the work force of Australia, that the rate of earnings growth, what was left of the centralised system, was flexible enough to adjust to the recession! What a shocking thing for the Deputy Governor to observe, or to go on to say:
The first time I am aware the union movement has accepted the principle that Australian wages should determine the rate of growth in prices and wages of our trading partners.

What a terribly political point to make. For that professional remark he bears the odium of making a blatant political statement. This is the kind of wilful thuggery of the bureaucracy we are seeing from this person perpetually. This is the man who has no respect for institutions and, when he was advising a former Treasurer—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have no respect period!
—The honourable member for Gilmore will cease interjecting.

—He would ring the central bank and tell it what its rate should be, how monetary policy should be conducted, and try to use the authority of the Treasurer's office and the monetary policy committee of the Cabinet to push the Reserve Bank around.
—In your pocket; in your pocket!
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mackellar.
—Mr Alan Wood in today's Australian has a few interesting things to say about this piece.

PARA.TAB: Mr Ronaldson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Ballarat!
—As honourable members would know, Mr Wood does not share our political view of the world. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: There is, quite simply, no basis in the speech or in remarks Macfarlane made afterwards in response to questions for any charge of political partisanship.

PARA.TAB: At no point does he mention the One Nation Strategy or endorse its policy thrust. He is talking about his expectations for the average rate of inflation over the rest of the 1990s.

ANSWER.PARA: Referring to the Leader of the Opposition, he went on to say:

Increasingly he is giving the impression the issue is not one of good economic management but paranoid politics. . . There is no evidence of any kind, circumstantial or otherwise, to support his charge of pro-labor partisanship on Macfarlane's part. . . To claim, as he did, that Macfarlane had no evidence to substantiate his view is just plain wrong. What he really meant was that he disagreed with the evidence—an entirely different matter.
It was not that Mr Wood was the only person to make those observations; so, too, did the Australian Financial Review where it said:
It is difficult to see what Mr Macfarlane said in his speech on Thursday which would count as blatantly political.
I also refer to the Australian Financial Review editorial this morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are reading today's newspapers. You are supposed to be the Prime Minister, not some sort of reading service.
—Order!

—The fact is that we have inflation structurally low in this country, and the Opposition hates it. It hates the success Australians have produced, some of it under the burden of the recession. The Opposition wants to deny them any benefit that comes from it. It wants to attack the central bank, which is out there talking up the issue of inflation control and lowering inflationary expectations. The Opposition is wilfully, needlessly, shamelessly attacking a career bureaucrat, saying he should resign if the inflation rate goes over 3 per cent, and that the Reserve Bank needs a shake-up and ought to be tipped out.

PARA.TAB: This is the same independent Reserve Bank that the Opposition is speaking of; the same one that the Leader of the Opposition used to thug on the telephone when he advised the former Treasurer. This is the same Leader of the Opposition who would rip the inflation rate to pieces and who would double the inflation rate, as the Treasurer says, by adding five to six percentage points to the price system with a GST, while requiring the central bank to then bludgeon it down with interest rates. This Leader of the Opposition has no respect for the Reserve Bank, no respect for the Reserve Bank Act, no respect for the role of the Government and the Reserve Bank working in tandem, no respect for the mores of the board of the Reserve Bank or its officers, its Governor or its deputy governors, and will only pursue a rotten political line whenever it suits him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer him to the fact that in the two weeks since the House last met there has been a $2.5 billion blow-out in the Budget deficit—nearly doubling the Kerin Budget forecast—a 6.5 per cent plunge in steel dispatches for the month of April, a 6.5 per cent drop in new home sales for April, an 18 per cent slump in new car and truck sales for April and the smallest rise in new capital stock for 30 years. Whilst we would welcome any genuine economic recovery, when will he stop misleading the Australian public about the real state of the economy and admit that the One Nation growth and job forecasts will not be met?
—Here we go again. The Opposition is simply trying to talk the economy down, talk Australia down and talk our chances down. In relation to these—
—You have no policy.
—Order! The honourable member for Cowper will cease interjecting.
—The Leader of the National Party really ought to have more sense than to light upon one month's statistics, whether they be for housing or motor vehicle sales, and suggest that these—
—Capital stock?

—Well, make up your mind. The monthly figures that the honourable member referred to were for motor vehicles and for new housing. One month ago, when we had spectacular increases in both housing and motor vehicles, why did we not have him up here saying, `What a wonderful result this is for Australia.'?

PARA.TAB: Dr Hewson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not, because—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections.

—I did not do it on that occasion, just as I am not going to sink into my boots on this occasion, because there are monthly fluctuations, as the Leader of the Opposition is all too well aware, and these fluctuations need to be looked at in terms of their trends. Whenever I have been asked about the state of the recovery, I have said that it is, at least at this stage, patchy, but it is nevertheless under way. If you particularly take the two-month figures for both vehicles and housing, you will see that the trend is up, and when you compare this month with the month 12 months earlier, you will certainly see that things are dramatically improved.

PARA.TAB: It was particularly surprising that the Leader of the National Party referred to questions of deficits. You guys are the deficit experts. Perhaps you were not around at the time, Tim, but some of your colleagues were, in various guises.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Under Standing Orders, Ministers must refer to other members of the House by their proper titles. The Minister is failing to do that.
—The Minister will refer to the honourable member by his title.

—I apologise, Mr Speaker. I refer to the Leader of the National Party. During the period 1976-77 to 1983-84, the average size of the deficit recorded by the coalition Government at that time was 2.4 per cent of GDP. That was your average rate of deficit for that entire period. That, of course, is the forecast deficit for 1991-92. But if you take the average of our deficits for the period 1984-85 to 1991-92, you will find that the average of our deficit was just one-half of one per cent of GDP.

PARA.TAB: Well may you get up here and complain about deficits, because you have a lot of complaining to do about your own record. The problem with your deficits is that they were frequently occasioned by an uncontrolled blow-out in expenditure rather than, on this occasion, an error of estimates in relation to revenue collections because earnings were lower, interest rates were lower and inflation was lower. I think the Leader of the National Party ought to leave to us the business of putting Budgets together. We are much better at it than you have ever been or are ever likely to be.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Recruitment and Retention of Apprentices and Trainees

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, relates to initiatives to encourage the recruitment and retention of apprentices and trainees. I ask the Minister whether he can inform the House of a range of initiatives which have been announced by the Government to encourage the recruitment and retention of apprentices and trainees. Can he advise of the response that he expects to those initiatives?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 146. This question was asked and fully answered in the last sittings and therefore cannot be asked again. I ask that you rule it out of order.
—There is no point of order. The question is in order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a choice, increasingly—
—What about the Standing Orders?
—Order! If the honourable member for Cowper interjects again, I will name him.

—That choice is between an Opposition which has now declared itself as lamenting—as opposed to actually intending to do anything about it—what it describes as the failure to provide substantial numbers of dead-end jobs for young people. The Party on this side of the House believes that what our young people need and want, and what this nation needs, is training. We have had several opportunities, in statements made both last year and this year, to provide an opportunity for it.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member's question goes to the issue of traineeships and apprentices. In the March 1991 statement the Government announced a set of measures that included a living allowance for unemployed apprentices and trainees to assist them to complete their basic trade training at TAFE, funds for private training providers to run intensive training courses for unemployed apprentices, a subsidy for employers of third and fourth year apprentices and increased incentives to encourage employers to recruit apprentices and trainees. In February this year I announced a further $33m package of measures to assist apprentices and trainees at risk due to the recession, and in the One Nation statement the Prime Minister announced a further $49m for prevocational places for 10,000 unemployed young people, $6m in special training assistance for group training schemes and an extension for another year of the measures announced last March.

The measures have worked, as honourable members will no doubt be pleased to know. The take-up of the March 1991 initiatives has exceeded targets. At the end of April this year well over 8,000 unemployed or at risk apprentices have been assisted and 7,040 unemployed apprentices have been assisted into new apprenticeships or in their efforts to continue with their trade training. Nearly 1,150 later year apprentices who were at risk of retrenchment have been retained in their jobs. The response by group training companies to the One Nation initiatives has been encouraging. Twenty-two projects have already been approved, providing employment or training opportunities for over 800 apprentices and trainees. And there is more to come.

Most importantly, the combination of measures has turned around the serious declines in traineeship and apprenticeship commencements that were evident in 1991. As all honourable members who take an interest in these matters know, after every single recession we have had—the last one was no exception—we have had to gallop to recruit skilled workers to this country or else confront major bottlenecks in industry which hamper recovery.

That is exactly where the Opposition's policy on traineeships now stands. With these replicated circumstances, those opposite would produce exactly those conditions again. Yet they parade around the country saying that they are in favour of reducing immigration rates, whilst putting in place policies which mean that that could never be done unless we were prepared to flatten the economy forever. There is an absolute dichotomy between what those opposite say they intend to achieve and their objectives.

Those opposite do not understand that because of where they stand mentally as far as these issues are concerned. They are exactly where the honourable member for Bennelong is: lamenting the disappearance of dead-end jobs, jobs that have been disappearing from the economy for the past 30 years as there has been an ever higher requirement placed on us for more effective employees. As Ross Gittins had occasion to say in his `Monday Comment' column of a week or two ago, entitled `Good riddance to the dead-end job', in respect of the fact that young people are now in training:

This is a positive development. Our kids have got the message that has so far eluded Mr Howard: the path to material prosperity (not to mention job satisfaction and job security) is via the acquisition of economically valuable skills. And, in this case, what's true for the individual is just as true for the national economy. Preserving and improving our standard of living requires not only greater investment in physical technology, but greater investment in skills.

ANSWER.PARA: For those who are chanting `provide them with a job', he refers to the point that the young people, themselves, have taken up:

PARA.TAB: The point is that 61 per cent of our teenagers don't `want a job' (not a full-time one, anyway) because they're in full-time education. In February, just 147,000 of our 1.3 million teenagers—one in nine—was seeking full-time jobs.

ANSWER.PARA: I might say that this is a very interesting feature of that statistic. He continued:

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I again draw your attention to standing order 146 which alludes to the asking and answering of questions that have been fully answered. The Minister is even reading the same quote that he used in his answer last time.

—Order! There is no point of order. The standing order about questions having been fully answered not being repeated refers to questions asked on the same day, not in the same week or the same month or the same year. Seeing as the honourable member for Cowper has drawn my attention to the Standing Orders, I might remind him of standing order 55 regarding interjections.

—I am sufficiently modest to quote from an answer to the proposition by Ross Gittins, not by me. He pointed out that there were actually about 34,000 fewer teenagers seeking full time employment than in February 1983 during the recession of the honourable member for Bennelong. So there are clear-cut choices for both sides of this House as far as traineeships and a skilled work force is concerned. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Pulp and Paper Mills Dispute

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Should the industrial dispute at Burnie in Tasmania involving the APPM mill be settled as soon as possible? Is the Prime Minister aware of criticisms of the actions of the Tasmanian Premier in seeking to settle the dispute?

TALK.START.PARA: —The APPM dispute began nearly two months ago when the company unilaterally cancelled some of its agreements with employees. It insisted on changes to work practices but has refused to accept the employees' request that it negotiate with the relevant unions on their behalf. The Leader of the Opposition was asked about this question and he said:

ANSWER.PARA: I have some sympathy for the company's position. You've got to have some sympathy for their position in this dispute.
Of course he has; that is his policy. His policy is to fracture the relationship between employers and employees so that we do not have a collective bargain between employees and an employer—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lie.
—The honourable member for La Trobe will cease interjecting.
—but a negotiation between one person—a worker; an employee—and his or her employer. A journalist asked:

ANSWER.PARA: That is not a view shared by Mr Ray Groom, your Liberal colleague in Tasmania, is it?
The Leader of the Opposition replied, `Apparently it is not, no'. He added:
I am surprised he hasn't given the company more support in its right to deal with its workers on over award terms and conditions.
Of course, that criticism of Mr Groom was carried in the press. Mr Groom said in Parliament:

Dr Hewson has a very good theoretical knowledge of industrial relations but here of course we are dealing with a real dispute. I said that Dr Hewson has a very good theoretical knowledge of industrial relations but here we are dealing with a real dispute involving real people and it is important to have local knowledge and understanding of the facts, which the members of the Government have in respect of this matter. I think we need to have a good knowledge of the facts and certainly that is what I have and that is what my colleagues here have.

The Tasmanian Premier slapped his coalition colleague down in making those remarks and repudiated the sort of big bang approach to industrial arbitration. At the same time Inside Canberra has reported:

We checked with the office of the shadow industrial relations spokesman John Howard this week and had it confirmed that in enterprise based bargaining the coalition policy will be that workers in an enterprise will be able to call in their union, if they so wish, to negotiate with management. That is what the APPM workers want, what the union wants and what the Liberal Premier of Tasmania, Ray Groom, wants. The company repeated this week that it will not negotiate with the union, only with workers. In taking APPM's side, Dr Hewson seems to be reversing liberal policy.

The fact is that we have seen such headlines around the country as `The battle for Burnie' and `Groom-Hewson rift opens over APPM'. Under the Leader of the Opposition's industrial relations policy, the big bang policy that he described in New Zealand, we would see a battle for Sydney, a battle for Melbourne, a battle for Brisbane and a battle for every other city and provincial city in Australia. There would be no more industrial harmony.

PARA.TAB: Industrial disputation is at its lowest level for decades. Over the last nine years the number of industrial disputes has been less than half of what it was during the previous nine. In this dispute we have had headlines about workers standing at the main gate and police trying to protect them. This has occurred so that the company can say, `We will not negotiate with your union. We will only negotiate with you personally. When we negotiate with you, of course, you will lose your annual leave loading; we will get into you about all those various things.'

Under the model proposed by the Leader of the Opposition Federal awards will fall out and people will opt out of the system and will require an employer's agreement to opt in. Annual leave pay, sick leave and all those other conditions of employment will go as there will be negotiations between individuals and their employers.
The fact is that after that first salvo we then had this headline in the Hobart Mercury: `Hewson backs off APPM'. The Age had this line: `Opposition is strangely silent on the APPM dispute'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you an oral clipping service?
—Order!

—In other words, those opposite were saying, `Let's keep mum about this. Let's not open up the argument that this is really our industrial relations policy at work. Let's keep it quiet because, if we identify ourselves with this, people will understand what a big bang means before it actually bangs. In other words, they will understand when they see this sort of thing that that is what we have in mind for industrial dislocation in Australia, as we try to shove millions of Australian employees off their awards and turn their conditions out.'

PARA.TAB: The industrial relations policy of the Leader of the Opposition is a recipe for turmoil. That is why the honourable member for Bennelong keeps backing and filling behind him, as we have seen in journals such as Inside Canberra. In the last couple of days we have seen a transcript of an interview he gave on the Matthew Abraham program on ABC radio where again he said that he cannot refuse people the right to talk to unions. There have been references to the trade union movement accepting the principle that wages should be determined in relation to growth in prices and wages of our trading partners or that wage flexibility guarantees low inflation.

How long would it be there with those sorts of disputes? There would be people lined up out the front of factories, battles for Burnie, and battles for every other major industry around the country as the madcap policies of the Leader of the Opposition, with his big bang in New Zealand, would mean that he would come over to bang Australia with a big bang, to bang the inflation rate, to bang industrial peace and to bang a recovery. That is what he is really on about. The serious minds in Australian business know what that means. They do not want to have their industrial peace put at risk. They do not want to have 6 1/2 per cent bill rates put at risk. They do not want a 2 per cent inflation rate put at risk by this madcap theoretical policy of the Leader of the Opposition—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Royal Commissions: Access to Tax Information

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. In view of the Prime Minister's statement on 15 May, what is the Government proposing in relation to the granting of access to tax information by royal commissions? Has the WA Royal Commission been consulted in relation to such proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 May, it is the case that the Prime Minister announced that we intended to amend the Taxation Administration Act. The Bill to give effect to that amendment will, I think, be debated in this House on Thursday. This is in order to facilitate certain taxation information being handed to the WA Royal Commission.
—It will not be the same as Queensland.

—I will get to the Leader of the National Party in a moment. The amendments will be to section 3E of the Act which was introduced by the then Treasurer, now Prime Minister, in 1989. It will be recalled that those amendments came into the Parliament, into the law, after the Fitzgerald Royal Commission when it became clear that there was a need for certain law enforcement agencies around the country, both State and Federal, to have access to tax information when it was necessary for pursuing suspicions or suggestions of serious offences being committed, information from the tax files being deemed to he helpful in those inquiries.

PARA.TAB: It was always the idea that the WA Royal Commission should have access to that information and we thought it was possible via the police unit which was there to support the Royal Commission. When it became clear that there were certain reservations held on the part of the Royal Commission about the utility of that device, it was very promptly rectified in terms of the Prime Minister's announcement.

These amendments will specifically extend to the WA Royal Commission and other royal commissions prescribed by regulation access to relevant tax information provided for in section 3E. It will allow the WA Royal Commission to disclose that information in a confidential report to the State Governor; it will allow the Governor to disclose that information to a law enforcement agency; and it will permit the WA Royal Commission to disclose the information to certain persons in private proceedings.

These proposed amendments have been discussed with the royal commissioners and their officers, and they have written to us indicating that they are satisfied with these changes. In other words, these changes satisfy their requirements as far as access to tax information is concerned.

The only thing which stands in the way of providing access to the WA Royal Commission is the confused and, I would say, capricious attitude of those opposite. The other day we heard the Leader of the National Party saying that he endorsed the statement of the Prime Minister and that this was adequate as far as he was concerned.
