INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The doubling of the Budget deficit and the inability of the Government to pay for its One Nation promises, which will lead to higher interest rates and higher taxes.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALKER.NAME: Mr REITH
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have proposed this matter of public importance to highlight the fact that this Government is basically lurching from crisis from crisis. In its ministerial appointments we have just had an extraordinary display of a Labor Party, as a result of the factions, putting in a time server. I must say—and I am sorry that the Speaker has gone—that the only good thing about the elevation of the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) is that it will mean the end of the Speaker. Apart from that, we have this crisis at a time when Australia looks to the Government for a set of solutions for people who are unemployed, but this Government and all its factions spend all their time looking for the job of one rather than looking to provide a capacity for this country to provide jobs to the nearly one million people who are unemployed.

PARA.TAB: Under the umbrella of this amazing saga of Senator Richardson, with all his wheeling and dealing over the years, in recent weeks we have also seen all the evidence one would ever need to show that the Government's control over the economy has literally fallen apart. The classic example of that, I suppose, is the Budget deficit, which has blown out to $9.3 billion. It is nearly beyond belief that in the August Budget last year the Government said the deficit would be $4.7 billion. By the time we got to February it was $6.8 billion. The Government said it had checked the figures and that that would definitely be it. But about 10 weeks later the deficit has gone from $6.8 billion to $9.3 billion—$2,500m more. These guys are either lying about the state of the Budget or they are accused of monumental incompetence when it comes to having any idea of what is actually happening in the Federal Budget.

The bottom line is that, when honourable members opposite made all their promises in February in this charade which they called One Nation—the Government's plan for Australia—the truth is that they did not have the money to pay for it. If you are in any doubt, not only did they not have the money to pay for all these empty promises—all of which are basically to be put on the international Bankcard—but also the revelation that the Budget deficit has gone from $6.8 billion to $9.3 billion ought to convince even the most cynical of those who might otherwise support the Government.

The fact is that they do not have the money to pay for their promises. If they are to fulfil their promises contained in the One Nation statement, which is a pretty big question mark on its own, one of two things will have to happen, if not both; that is, there will have to be higher taxes or higher interest rates as they borrow to pay for it.

One Nation, as it is called by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), is their plan. The coalition came out with Fightback last year, which was the most detailed, comprehensive reform agenda ever produced by an Opposition. We showed how we could turn this country around, how we could create two million jobs and how, as a nation, we could start paying back our massive and spiralling debt. In response to that, as everyone knows, the Government came up with a statement which it calls One Nation.

Today I want to look at the basis upon which One Nation was constructed and show why the whole thing is just a pack of cards which has come tumbling down around their ears. The first thing about One Nation is that it made a whole lot of assumptions. Honourable members tried to work out what the growth in the Australian economy would be in the few years ahead. They estimated that the growth in the Australian economy would be 4.75 per cent starting from 1 July. Quite frankly, that figure in itself was unrealistic and totally optimistic. The reason they thought they could get away with it was in the hope that, by the time the next election came along, the figures would not be out and it would be difficult to disprove otherwise.

The truth is that since then many leading commentators have shot holes in the 4.75 per cent assumption. It is not going to happen. Even the OECD—which basically has the Government holding its hand as it writes the report—says that the growth rate for Australia in the ensuing year will be 3 per cent, not 4.75 per cent. If we look at the investment data that has come out in recent weeks, we can see what an absolute charade and what a facade One Nation was when it came to its projections in respect of investment. We had a 2 per cent fall in investment in the March quarter and, on the Access Economics estimates, capital stock declined in the December quarter.

We do not need to be economists to work out one very simple fact, and that is that we are not going to have a sustained recovery in Australia until people have some confidence in the future of this country and are prepared to start to invest. Investment is not going up, as the Government has projected, from 1 July; the harsh reality is that investment is falling. Even on the Australian Bureau of Statistics latest expectations data—and admittedly it is not comparing apples exactly with apples—the expectation for the ensuing year is a 4 per cent decline in investment, not the 4 per cent increase on which those opposite have based all their figures.

Even the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank—and perhaps his speech was disappointing in some ways—said in respect of growth that a 5 per cent figure was unrealistic. I will come back to that in a moment. But the Government's official figure is 4.75 per cent, and he said that nobody in his right mind would believe 5 per cent. The Government's plan for the future of this country is based on what it reckons is going to happen by way of growth, and there is hardly a person in the country who believes that there is any credibility in those figures.

The second point goes to the Budget. I think those opposite are either lying or incompetent, because back in February it just happened to suit the Government's convenience to say that the deficit would be 6.8 per cent—`We've got the system under control'. The last thing the Government wanted to know back in February was that there would be a blow-out of $2 1/2 billion. Why was that? It was because it would not be able to afford its One Nation claims if the deficit did blow out to that extent. That was despite the fact that a group of economic forecasters outside of Treasury actually picked the right figure of $9 billion.

I say to the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) that I find it beyond belief that his people had no idea of the blow-out in the Federal Budget deficit when that figure came down in February. I believe he did know. I admit that I cannot prove it, but remember the saying: if it walks like a duck and quacks like a duck, then it is a duck. That is the truth of the $9.3 billion. But there is another point that arises when we look at the Budget and revenue, and that is that, with regard to One Nation, its growth figures are shonky. That is clear and obvious for everybody to see. Another revealing thing is that in One Nation the Government said, `We are going to get so much money coming in', calculated on the assumption of a certain level of inflation. Most people have heard about bracket creep. As inflation goes up we pay a bit more tax as we go through the progressive income tax scales. I used to say `tax creep' until someone said I was being personal about the Treasurer.

The Government had an expectation of what inflation would be. The latest inflation figures came in and they were lower than what the Government thought they would be, which meant therefore that the revenue from bracket creep would be reduced. There was a very revealing press conference with the Prime Minister and the Treasurer not so long ago, and a journalist picked up on this point. He started to ask the Prime Minister, `Hang on, you built this sort of house of cards on certain expectations of how much money is going to come in. You have just said you are going to get less money from bracket creep. Where is the rest of the money coming from? Your tax cuts are based on bracket creep. But if inflation is lower, how are you going to fund your tax cuts?'. The world's greatest Treasurer—he is really bright, this bloke—said, `Well, the brackets will be creeping less, won't they?'. This is classic Keatingese. This is the smart alec at work.

The journo is rather pleased about this, because he has the Prime Minister on a hook now and he is really starting to squirm. The journalist said, `That's right'—and he might as well have said, `you mug'—`and you will have less money to pay back'. Then came this answer, which shows that there is not much between ear and ear when it comes to this bloke sitting at the front: `Therefore'—then there was a pause and the penny was just starting to drop—`well, we will see'. My word, we will see! John Kerin got the sack for saying, `Watch this space'. He did not have the vaguest idea. His bright little mate, John Dawkins, the Treasurer—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw—
—No, the honourable member will wait. Opposition members are raising points of order about calling honourable members by their proper titles. You are the Deputy Leader; you do it.
—I withdraw the word `bright'. He could see that the Prime Minister was in trouble, so he says:

SPEECH.PARA: Of course the other point to bear in mind is that with lower inflation you've got the prospect of maybe growing a little faster.

He has really jumped in with both feet. They are expecting to get all this money in, they have just realised they are going to get less in, so when they are asked, `Where is the money coming from?', he says, `Oh, we're going to grow a bit faster'—that is, faster than the 4.75 that nobody believed in the first place. He has this proposition that is shonky from start to finish, he is in a bit of hot water, so he adds a bit on, and we get to the 5 per cent that even Macfarlane said we could not have a bar of. So here they are, they have no money and they are starting to hunt around to see where they can get the money from.

PARA.TAB: The next thing we find is the Treasurer on Lateline one night. The obvious thing is that maybe they will get the money by spending less and cutting expenditure. The Treasurer said, `In the past we got there through expenditure restraint, but very substantial expenditure cuts'. Then he said, `But then again, we do not think that expenditure cuts will play such an important role on this occasion'. The first choice is that they might get the money by cutting back somewhere else. He has basically ruled that out. There goes option No. 1. That was a good one.

I do not want to miss anything out here. Next the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) waltzed down to the Sunday program to be interviewed by that tenacious reporter and journalist extraordinaire, Mr Laurie Oakes. The first question to Mr Willis was: `Are you going to cut back on expenditure?'. In fact, he is going to increase expenditure; he is going to give more money to the States. On the question of cutting, they might cut a little bit—a snip here and a snip there—but that would just pay for something else that they might spend the money on. The Treasurer is going to increase expenditure; certainly, he is not going to cut expenditure.

Then we get to the big question. They have not got the expenditure. We already know they are going to borrow; that is the second option. These guys are very good at borrowing. In their One Nation statement, they are up to their ears in debt. It is amazing; Australia has a debt of $145 billion, and they are going to borrow over $20 billion in the next four years to pay for it. We are literally drowning in debt. Of course, that borrowing means higher interest rates, so we are going to cop higher interest rates if Labor is re-elected, whatever happens.

Then we get to the other option; then we get to the dandy of them all. When asked, `Will you give us a guarantee you won't increase taxes?'—that is the other place they can get the money from—what did the Minister for Finance say? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I don't think it's appropriate to make those sort of guarantees.

There it is. These guys are going to increases taxes. When we asked the Treasurer at Question Time, `Do you agree with what Mr Willis said?', he answered, `I am not going to tell you how to put a Budget together'. Then he said, `Of course, we would consider various components of the revenue'. That is a bit of bureaucrat talk which means tax increases. Just to settle it in everybody's minds, today they are bringing in their legislation to change the sales tax. The sales tax is a hidden consumption tax. They are not going to just fiddle at the edges; they are going to start again. It is going to be a new consumption tax. That is the tax that the Government will massively increase after the next election, if it is elected.

PARA.TAB: The Government has now got a tax on takeaway containers, pet food, biscuits, pizzas, thick shakes, electric jugs, electric heaters, hot-water services, water tanks—and on services. It is a goods and services tax. It will be introduced in the Parliament today. These people in the Government have the hypocrisy to say that they are opposed to a goods and services tax—yet they are introducing one into the Parliament today! They will increase taxes. Would anybody really be surprised to find that the Government has done nothing but increase taxes the whole time that it has been in office? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have frequently had to complain about the hopeless task one is confronted with when trying to debate the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith). He tries to participate simply in the context of a debate taking place on the electronic media, just mouthing slogans or repeating gross distortions and inaccuracies. The task of answering such a debate is difficult enough; but when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, as he did today, simply accuses the Government of having resorted to taxes and of being likely to resort to taxes again when putting its Budget together, he simply displays a breathtaking lack of knowledge about the national accounts—or, alternatively, he is simply in the business of telling the big lie.

PARA.TAB: Of course, that is something which comes very easily to members of the Opposition. In fact, in the course of this Government's period of office we have seen a reduction in the size of the revenues as a proportion of the total economy to the point where government revenue of all kinds, State and Commonwealth, is lower than that of any OECD country apart from Japan. We are right at the bottom in terms of tax raising.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition started by referring to a deficit blow-out. I simply want to record this for his information and for that of the joker sitting next to him. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) may well remember uttering these words. On 17 August 1982 the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong, stood where I stand now and, in terms of the Budget he was putting together, said:
This has necessarily meant some increase in the size of the overall Budget deficit compared with last year.
But the outcome—a deficit of $1.674 billion—is only one per cent of gross domestic product . . .

SPEECH.PARA: What was the outcome of that Budget 12 months later, at the end of June 1983? In fact, a deficit forecast at the time of $1.6 billion had grown to a massive $4.5 billion. It was not one per cent of GDP, as claimed; it had grown to 2.6 per cent of GDP. Of course, the then Treasurer was following a long tradition of Liberal Treasurers. We have to go back to the very early 1950s to find a Liberal Treasurer who did not bring in a Budget deficit.

PARA.TAB: This talk that it is this Government which is about increasing public sector debt is totally wrong—and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition knows it. There has not been a Liberal Treasurer who has brought in a Budget surplus in 40 years. For 40 years Liberal Treasurers have been bringing in Budget deficits. If we go back to the most recent period of Liberal Treasurers we find that the average of their Budget deficits during the period of their reign was, in fact, 2.4 per cent of GDP.

Those opposite now have the cheek to complain that this year, with a Budget deficit of 2.4 per cent of GDP, we are to be condemned. They did not have that for just one year; they had it every year. Every year, on average, those opposite brought in a Budget deficit of the size which will be recorded for this particular financial year: 2.4 per cent of GDP this year, compared with 2.4 per cent of GDP for every year under a Liberal government during the period between the Whitlam and Hawke-Keating governments.

These people really have to be judged on the basis of their own credibility on this question of Budgets, of deficit and of debt. The other point that is worth bearing in mind is that when the Opposition gave itself the chance to put together some prospective Budgets in the context of its Opposition policies, in fact we found them lamentably lacking. We have so far been able to record $6 billion worth of shortfalls in terms of the arithmetic which is intended to support the GST—$6 billion worth of shortfalls.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you say that with a straight face?

—The honourable member knows it is true and he has not been able to dent these Treasury and Finance discoveries of holes in his prospective Budget figuring. This is not my accusation; this is not my assertion. It is the assertion of the Finance and Treasury officials: the ones whom the Opposition finds so easy to disparage, the ones who have the responsibility and the expertise to put together Budgets and the knowledge to criticise the efforts of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition stands here in tatters. It does not have a policy which stands up because the whole of the support mechanism and the compensation package for its proposals is a mess. In fact, the Opposition cannot fund it because there is a $6 billion hole. The last people on earth who should be criticising us in the context of our Budget work are, of course, those opposite and, most particularly, their Deputy Leader who took responsibility for putting together the figuring of the Opposition's proposals.

As though they have discovered some gem, those opposite say that we should have known in January that the Budget deficit this year was going to blow out. They say, `Access Economics told you'. Access Economics actually said in January that it expected there to be a huge shortfall in PAYE collections. That was the basis on which it made its calculations about a Budget deficit. At the time I asked what was happening to PAYE collections and what was the current estimate of PAYE collections. I was told that PAYE collections were not only on track, but also it had no reason to alter the estimate. Indeed, even now, the estimate is within $100m of the Budget-time estimate of PAYE collections.

So it is just fatuous and ignorant for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to suggest that, because Access told us in January, we should have factored it in. What Access told us was actually totally wrong because what it thought was going to be the ingredient of the shortfall was not. In the press statement I made on this question when we published the May review of this year's Budget, I actually identified the areas in which the revenue shortfall had occurred. As I said at the time, it was due primarily to a nearly $600m shortfall in company collections and a $1.5 billion shortfall in the context of individuals, other than those who pay via the PAYE mechanism.

There was no way, I am told, that the Tax Office could have known when it was asked the question in January that those collections were going to be well below the Budget time forecast. The reason for that is that until one has the actual evidence of the collections—typically in March, April and May—there is no basis on which to deviate from the Budget time estimates.

This is all just a shabby and somewhat desperate attempt on the part of the Opposition to make something out of a deterioration in the revenue side of the Budget. The idea that the revenue side deterioration is a contributor to the deficit is rather novel as far as the Opposition is concerned. Usually the deterioration in its Budgets, which happened so frequently, was because of the ill discipline that it exhibited in relation to the expenditure side of the Budget.

The expenditure side of our Budget is not a contributor to this year's deficit because we have been able to keep those expenditures under control. The reasons for this—I have said this many times but of course the Opposition has refused to listen or believe it—are essentially related to the fact that the economy is doing better on the inflation front. As a result of inflation, lower interest rates and lower than expected earnings in some areas, we have seen lower incomes and, therefore, lower taxes. I do not see what the Opposition is really complaining about when in fact we are collecting less tax from those people who might otherwise have paid more tax. Yet at the same time the Opposition says that we are a government which is interested only in increasing the revenue.

One of the interesting sidelights to this particular debate is that at least it has the Opposition talking about the Government's One Nation statement. Let us recall again why it was that the Government decided to introduce its One Nation statement. It was because the Government's assessment in January of this year was that the recovery was not proceeding as fast as had been anticipated at the time of last year's Budget. Indeed, the Opposition is in here every day, up with the media on every occasion it can, talking down the economy, telling all Australians how poorly we are doing. It is precisely because the economy was doing less well than we thought in January that we decided it was in need of some stimulus.

Do we ever hear the Opposition talking about the need for some stimulus, the need for some promotion of the recovery? No, not at all. That is because the Opposition wants to see this economy in a state of economic paralysis for as long as possible. What terrifies the Opposition beyond belief is that this recovery will take hold, that the economy will begin to improve, that the economic prospects confronting Australians will look considerably better and that, as a consequence, the political climate may vary in our favour.

Of course that is the reason. It is not an interest in the Australian economy; it is not an interest in the fortunes of Australian working men and women; it is not any regard for the future welfare of Australian people that drives the Opposition. The Opposition is simply intent on trying to talk down any suggestion of any glimmer of hope that there might be in the economy.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition of course gave the game away when he said, `You don't need to be an economist to know that the recovery will take place when confidence improves'. That is not bad coming from him. That is why the Opposition is about deflating and knocking any suggestion of revived confidence in the Australian economy. Despite the efforts of those opposite, despite their attempt to wreck this economy, despite their passion for postponing any recovery, the recovery is occurring. That of course is fairly gloomy news to those whose stock-in-trade is economic gloom. Although the recovery is as yet somewhat patchy and as yet has not taken root across all sectors of the economy, no-one that I am aware of is suggesting that the recovery has not begun.

Indeed, the range of private forecasts about growth in 1992-93 is from 2.5 per cent to 5.4 per cent. So the Government is certainly not alone, and indeed is not on any optimistic extreme as far as its predictions of growth in 1992-93 are concerned. But this is not really a debate on the Opposition's concern about the state of the Budget, because it knows in its more truthful moments that this Government is very well equipped to put together a Budget appropriate for Australia's economic circumstances.

What those opposite lament, and lament again, is that our policies are working and that Australia is working its way back into a period of growth. That is the thing which horrifies the Opposition; that is the thing which promotes the greatest gloom for it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Atkinson Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with interest to the comments of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). I hope that he may sit around and listen to some of the problems as I, as a member who spends considerable time in his electorate, see them. We have heard a lot about the clever country and clever people—
—I will read about it in the Hansard.

—It is interesting that the Treasurer wants to wander off and not listen. It does not surprise me, because he has been too interested in listening to his own rhetoric and that of the people advising him. I suggest that he get out and listen to some of the comments of the individual companies and company owners and some of the people who have suffered in our country, rather than wander off in the way that he has and just seek the advice of those who really have not done a productive day's work in their lives.

PARA.TAB: What he ought do is go out and figure out why the $600m in company collections has not occurred and why the $1.5m in individual collections has not occurred. He might find out that companies are not performing as well today as they were in previous years. One does not need to look too far to see those figures. I find it fascinating that this Treasurer would come in here and have the audacity to say that there is recovery even though recovery is patchy.
The reason why I asked the Treasurer to stay here was that in the One Nation speech by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, in the past 70 days my colleagues and I travelled around Australia, meeting business people, union leaders, State Governments and community organisations.

I find that whole process somewhat fascinating because I can tell honourable members that he did not meet a lot of people. To highlight one point, I want to read a short letter that I wrote to the Prime Minister in the genuine interests of businesses in my electorate and of my region. The letter was dated 8 January and was written as a result of information from the Prime Minister saying that he wanted to talk to businesses all around the country. My letter states:
Dear Prime Minister

I was delighted to read in this morning's newspapers that you have announced your intention to meet key business and union leaders in Melbourne next week to ascertain what is required in the proposed mini-budget. I was particularly pleased to read that you have decided to by-pass business lobby groups and instead speak directly to big and small businesses.

With this in mind, I take this opportunity to invite you to the electorate of Isaacs during your visit to Melbourne next week. Both the Moorabbin Industrial Estate and the Braeside Industrial Estate are located within the boundaries of Isaacs and together these estates comprise a substantial part of Australia's manufacturing sector. Businesses in this area have experienced the full brunt of Australia's current economic crisis and a meeting with them would be an invaluable experience for yourself, Mr Dawkins, Mr Willis and Senator Button.
I would be very pleased to arrange such a meeting and to arrange on-site visits at your request. Your early response to this invitation would be greatly appreciated.
I signed it. The interesting thing is that I have not had a response. It is asking a little bit much to get an early response.

PARA.TAB: The thing that concerns me with all of this is that we have heard the rhetoric of what this Government is going to do about talking to small business, but it never occurs on the ground. The reason why I wanted the Treasurer—probably shadow Treasurer after the next election—to stay in this place and listen to the comments is that I think the information I have got is more up to date than the information he is getting from his advisers.

I have spoken to all the real estate agents in my electorate, who are the people who are actually letting factories and collecting the money at the end of each month for rent. What worries me is that they say that currently they are 50 per cent down on their letting of factories on what they were previously. But, more importantly, these real estate agents tell me that more than 25 per cent of the factories that are let out are over six months behind with their rental payments. That signals a problem to me—it may not signal one to the Treasurer, who is more interested in producing rhetoric in this place—because if 25 per cent of those companies are six months behind in the payment of their rent, then how far are they behind with their creditors? What chance have those companies got of getting back on their feet even if we do see some of the recovery aspects that this Treasurer is talking to us about?

He is all too happy to come in here and to say there is patchy recovery but it is actually happening and he is willing this to happen; but the fact of the matter is that many of these businesses which are out over six months are out to that extent simply because they cannot close their doors. Do honourable members know why? It is because they cannot afford to make the payouts to their workers; they cannot afford to pay the redundancy payments. All of these things need to be talked about and need to be explained to this Treasurer, who is quite happy to look at the statistics, which do not explain that position and do not get across the message of where we are headed.

What concerns me is that I have written a genuine letter to the Prime Minister of this country saying, `Come down to our region, where in the electorates of Isaacs, Dunkley, Corinella and Holt there is 25 per cent of the manufacturing business of this country'. I would have thought that, when this Prime Minister and the members of Cabinet put together a presentation called One Nation, they would at least have had the decency to respond to the letter I wrote and had the decency to come down to the worst hit State in this country and the area with the highest level of manufacturing in this country to talk to some of these businesses and some of the people who are having problems to see what the real issues and the real problems are. But it has not happened.

The Government goes on in the One Nation statement under `Summary of Measures' in the back section to say that it is going to look at improving the skills training of people. That is laudable, but the fact of the matter is that in the Sandringham Secondary College in my electorate there are 47 students this year repeating the VCE who passed the VCE last year. It is incredible. The Government is talking about what it is going to do to educate people. These people have actually got their VCE, but because there is not work—26 of them have actually tried to get work, then went onto unemployment benefits and have now gone back to school—47 of these kids who went out into the community to get themselves a career have gone back to repeat

SPEECH.PARA: something that they have passed. They have done that in the hope that they will get a place at university because there are not the jobs available. I cannot understand the processes that the Prime Minister and his Treasurer are on about. All I can say is that maybe they have spent too long a time in their seats and have not got out to talk to the people in this community who they need to talk to—and that is not the advisers.

PARA.TAB: If one looks at the bankruptcy figures in this country, one sees that they are the highest they have ever been. I do not believe that this Government is on top of those issues at all. From an estimated $4.7 billion, the deficit blew out to $6.8 billion and then continued on to the present level of $9.3 billion. What we have to do to get the country going and operating is give people confidence. Businesses in this country are not going to get confidence when from this Government they get predictions that are 50 per cent out.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are 100 per cent out.

—They are 100 per cent out, as is pointed out by the honourable member for Curtin. In fact, the Treasurer, in his statement, made comments about possible increases in taxes. The fact of the matter is that he has no option. If he is not doing anything to resolve the problems of businesses and if businesses are continuing to pay less and less tax because they do not have the capacity, firstly, to generate jobs and, secondly, the profit, then obviously the tax collections have got to come from somewhere else. The whole exercise of this Government is based on rhetoric and not on fact.

PARA.TAB: The Government talks of 4.5 per cent growth. When we are talking about variations in the deficit and about the problems we have in the country at the moment, when we get down to talk to businesses at the level that I am talking to them—people in businesses do go and talk to the local real estate agents and find out how things are going—how in the heck is the Government going to get people to invest their half a million dollars or their million dollars for a small business, and more in bigger companies, in new equipment when they need to plan for five, 10 or 15 years and when we have a government that is talking about 4.5 per cent growth, which is not attainable? This Government really needs to recognise what it is doing to the community. I would ask the Treasurer, even though he is not here, to read some of the comments and consider what I have said about getting out and talking to some of the people on the ground.

We have had a fall in new car registrations this month. Last month, of course, the figure was terrific; it was growing. That was part of the growth pattern that the Government has of 9 per cent. This month it is down 12.6 per cent.

All of this misinformation that the Government is putting out gives people in industry in this country absolutely no confidence to get up and put money into investments for the future of manufacturing industry, which will give people the opportunity to get jobs—real jobs, not the sorts of jobs that are being offered under this Government's One Nation package. I believe that, at the end of the day, this Government will have to come to the realisation that its process of governing this country is not working. The only way that we are going to achieve anything in this country is to develop real jobs for real people. To highlight the point: it is very difficult to understand—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to note, in listening to the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson), just what the Liberal and National parties believe. They are determined to destroy any hopes of economic recovery at all costs. It was interesting in listening to the honourable member for Isaacs to note in particular his concern about manufacturing industry, yet at the very forefront of the Liberal's policy is a zero tariff regime that would decimate manufacturing industry in his own State. So let us not have any more of the nonsense about the Liberals' proposals as far as manufacturing is concerned, or their understanding of the needs of skilling the work force and training and educational opportunities. We have only to look at Fightback to see the way they would destroy those opportunities as well for the vast majority of Australians.

PARA.TAB: It is worth returning to what the matter of public importance is about in relation to the One Nation statement. The One Nation statement was designed to promote economic recovery. It was designed to ensure that the range of needs that applied across the community was accelerated: the needs for public infrastructure, the needs in relation to the aviation industry, the needs in relation to port facilities, the needs in relation to the national rail network, the needs in relation to the national electricity grid—things about which government in times of recession could take positive action to help ensure they occur, so that as we move into the recovery phase we get the sort of infrastructure that is needed for efficiency and to ensure that industry can grow and prosper. That is clearly what one should do when one is faced with the problems of recession. The Government—the public sector—rightly takes stock of that and moves towards meeting those needs.

It is interesting to note, when we look at economic conditions over the last 40 years, that we have had only three Budget surpluses in that time, and they have not come from the virtuous crowd on the Opposition benches. In all their time in government, those opposite could not produce a Budget surplus. All they relied on was deficit after deficit, inflation built into the system totally right through that period. They relied on that inflationary expectation being there to carry it through that period. That is what their whole economic structure was built on: no inflation fighting strategy, no capacity to encourage real growth, and no capacity to ensure that infrastructure was properly maintained and reinforced. At the end of that period, when they left office in 1983, we were left with a Budget deficit which was 4.1 per cent of GDP. That is what we inherited.

Even allowing for the change that has occurred of a cyclical nature in this period because of the recession, the Budget deficit is only 2.1 per cent of GDP. The net effect of that shows that what we really have is a Budget deficit which in real terms is less than half of what we were left by Fraser, Howard and his advisers.

What does that mean? It means that basically we now have a different set of arrangements. The change in terms of the deficit that we have now is of a cyclical nature—it is because of the current recession—unlike the situation we had in 1983, when the deficit we had at that time was because of structural factors. Those structural factors meant that the Liberals could never produce a Budget surplus. They never sought to produce Budget surpluses; they relied totally on the fact, as I say, that that inflationary expectation was there. That inflationary expectation was built into everything that the Liberals stood for. It was built right through the economy. It is only because of the low inflation expectation that we now have that we can genuinely say that the country can now plan and business can now invest on the basis of low inflation.

What does that mean? It means, as we established recently at the banking inquiry, that instead of the proliferation of lending for property we will get lending for quality business. Business investment will be based on growing and expanding business opportunities rather than on artificial property speculation and so on. That will be important for the financial system and the economic system as a whole. The net result of that is going to be more production, more investment, greater productivity and a more productive national economy. That is what One Nation is really all about. To suggest that somehow the Fightback strategy—the alternative strategy—is designed to do that is a nonsense.

It is interesting to note that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) spend day after day lambasting the Governor and the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank. They make the most outrageous statements about the role of the Governor and the Deputy Governor because of the speech the Deputy Governor made recently. What do we get today? Because there is one element in the Deputy Governor's speech in relation to growth, where the Deputy Governor has referred to a 5 per cent growth rate, those opposite use that as gospel. Yet throughout Question Time, day after day over recent weeks in the Parliament, we have had the Opposition saying that the Reserve Bank should be treated in all sorts of ways: it should be scrapped, it should be made to toe the line and its officers should be sacked if they do not reach certain inflation projections. Yet the only thing we can say the Deputy Leader of the Opposition relied on was the fact that the Deputy Governor of the Bank had said that a growth rate of 5 per cent was unrealistic.

One of the things we can say with absolute certainty is that the growth we will get coming out of the recession will be significant growth. Already, if we look at the range of data, there are clear signs of that growth starting to occur. The honourable member for Isaacs relies on one month's figures for car registrations to suggest that that is all illusory. He forgets the previous three months as far as car registrations are concerned. He wants to forget the growth in the housing area as far as bank lending is concerned. He wants to forget the recovery that is occurring across those areas. There is certainly scope for much more growth because of the very real recession we have had and the real pain we have had associated with that recession.

But we now have a number of things working in our favour. We have the lowest inflation rate in 20 years; we have the lowest interest rates in 20 years. Those opposite can say that all of those things do not matter, but the fact is that throughout the period when the cuts in interest rates have occurred, since February 1990, the Opposition has opposed every single one of those cuts. Every single time interest rates have been cut in the last 2 1/2 years the Opposition has said it is premature to be doing that; that the Government is doing it for political reasons; that the Reserve Bank is a tool of the Government in cutting those rates. Despite the Opposition claiming that on every single occasion, the gradual reduction in interest rates down to the present official rate of 6 1/2 per cent has had the effect of helping to bring the economic stabilisers into operation, as we would rightly expect in this phase of the economic cycle.

The net effect of all of that has been not the sort of run on the dollar and the risk to inflation that the Leader of the Opposition talked about through that time, but quite the reverse. The dollar has stayed stable through those cuts in rates; the level of inflation has been reduced to the level we have now, where for the last quarter we have a zero figure for inflation. What matters is that as we move into the recovery stage the growth we get is real growth—and it will be; that the investment we get is real investment in new business opportunities, as it will be; and that the impact throughout the economy is the creation of the jobs that the One Nation economic statement was all about.

A couple of factors came into effect in relation to the change in the projection for this year's Budget deficit. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has referred to that. I do not intend to dwell on that matter, other than to say that the changes relating to company tax collections clearly come to light only at this time of the year. It is not until we get to the last quarter of the year that we start to have any real understanding of where that particular company tax collection is going to be made. The change in relation to the tax file number is clearly another factor that we could not have foreseen earlier in the year.

What matters is that, as we get the growth coming out of the One Nation economic statement, that growth will be felt throughout the economy, in all the key sectors. The efficiencies that are delivered through One Nation will mean that companies can have real, efficient gains in terms of their business enterprises.

That is really what One Nation is all about. That is why the basic economic projections that are outlined in One Nation are valid; that is why the scenario that is set in One Nation, which provides for a budgetary surplus in 1995-96, can be achieved. Because the fundamental structure is sound and the economy is cyclical, growth starts to occur. As growth starts to occur, the revenue side of the Budget is retained. It has not been the expenditure side that has been affected by the current changes; it has been the revenue side. As growth occurs, the revenue side comes back to the rightful projections. As a result of that, the prediction in One Nation for a Budget surplus by 1995-96 will be achieved. That has clearly been the strategy that has been in place all along. The Treasurer is entitled to say that will be maintained. (Time expired)

Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to be able to move the introduction of a major piece of legislation on a matter which so deeply affects the lives and opportunities of people with disabilities.

PARA.TAB: The Disability Discrimination Bill will make discrimination on the basis of disability unlawful in Australia. The Bill will assist all people with disabilities to exercise their rights as Australian citizens and represents a landmark in achieving human rights for all Australians.

People with disabilities are entitled to the same rights and the same opportunities as all other Australian citizens. However, our society currently falls well short of realising this ideal. People are still subjected to discrimination purely on the basis of disability—discrimination which, I am sure all honourable members would agree, is socially damaging, morally unacceptable and a cost to the whole community.

Research has shown that people with disabilities still face a number of barriers to the equal enjoyment of human rights in many areas of life. These include employer and co-worker attitudes, access to premises and transport and the types of jobs available. During an extensive series of consultations about ways to address these barriers, people with disabilities, their families and advocates and service providers called upon the Government to introduce comprehensive disability discrimination legislation.

This Government has a long term commitment to achieving a better deal for people with disabilities. The Government began the process of expanding opportunities for people with disabilities in 1983 with the comprehensive review of programs and services for people with disabilities—the handicapped programs review. The outcomes of this review culminated in the implementation of the Disability Services Act in 1987. The Act requires that services for people with disabilities be provided in a manner consistent with their rights as Australian citizens and as human beings. These include the right to dignity, privacy, choice and the fulfilment of their capacities to contribute fully in community life.

The Disability Services Act is regarded internationally as a significant step forward in legislative support for services assisting people with disabilities. It was welcomed by people with disabilities, their families and representatives. The principles and objectives of the Act provided Australia with a set of ideals to strive for and today the Act has won widespread community understanding and support.

Now, at the end of the United Nations Decade of Disabled Persons, I think it timely to be able to introduce legislation which will extend these principles to all walks of life. The principles need to be taken up within society as a whole so that they reach all Australians with disabilities, regardless of whether they are receiving support services under the Disability Services Act. The Disability Discrimination Bill will be instrumental in continuing social change and will have far-reaching and long-awaited effects for people with disabilities.

I do not believe there is any better example of social justice than this legislation—legislation which provides the framework to eliminate the discrimination which prevents fair access for people with disabilities to jobs, education, sport and entertainment and which provides an effective means of overcoming perhaps the most significant barrier that people with disabilities face in this country—the attitudinal barrier.

The Bill recognises that discrimination against people with disabilities is a matter of international concern. It is another significant step in fulfilling Australia's international obligations under a number of United Nations instruments. These include the International Labour Organisation Convention concerning discrimination in respect of employment and occupation; the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights; the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights; and a number of related declarations.

However, none of this would have been possible without the commitment and courage of people who believed in the legislation. While I do not like to single out any particular individuals in the process, Mr Graeme Innes, Chairperson of the Disability Advisory Council of Australia and Ms Chris Ronalds and the representatives of the Disability Anti-Discrimination Legislation Committee bear special mention. Today, not 12 months after the establishment of this Committee, we are in the fortunate position of bringing this significant indicator of the Government's continuing commitment to social justice before the Parliament.

The overall response from industry groups and State governments has also been very positive. The Government has received extensive comment from interested parties in relation to the proposal to introduce legislation. The Bill will be left to lie in the House over the winter recess so that interested parties can make any further comments. This timing builds on the widespread discussions already undertaken on the legislation.

Legislative reform is vital if the very real, but unfair, barriers that prevent people with disabilities from playing effective and valued roles are to be broken down. The legislation would constitute the legal basis for the protection and promotion of the rights of people with disabilities and would subsequently help to overcome social and economic disadvantage by assisting people with disabilities to participate as equals in Australian society.

I turn now to a more detailed description of the Bill. The legislation would be grievance-based and fundamentally similar to the Commonwealth's existing anti-discrimination legislation: the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 and the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. The legislation would promote gradual structural reforms and attitudinal change—changes which would enhance the opportunities available to people with disabilities throughout community life.

The objects of the Bill are to eliminate, as far as possible, discrimination against persons on the ground of disability in the areas of work, accommodation, education, clubs, sport, the provision of goods, facilities, services and land, existing laws and the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs; to ensure, as far as practicable, that people with disabilities have the same rights to equality before the law as their fellow citizens; and to promote recognition and acceptance within the community of the principle that people with disabilities have the same fundamental rights as their fellow citizens. The legislation would therefore perform an important educative role and would further social awareness and change.

The legislation would cover both direct and indirect discrimination on the ground of disability and would also cover discrimination on the basis of association with people with disabilities. The legislation would apply throughout Australia and, in this regard, relies on all available and appropriate heads of Commonwealth constitutional power. In the preparation of this Bill, the Government has paid attention to existing State disability discrimination legislation and the role played by State disability discrimination machinery in eliminating discrimination.

Disability anti-discrimination legislation currently exists in differing forms in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia, Queensland and the Australian Capital Territory. Such legislation is proposed for Tasmania and the Northern Territory. However, there are considerable variations in the scope and coverage of the various Acts. National, comprehensive legislation is required in order to ensure that people with disabilities are not disadvantaged by their place of residence. Moreover, State legislation alone does not provide comprehensive coverage for people with disabilities, due to the limited ability of the States to regulate discriminatory practices against Commonwealth authorities.

The Bill includes a definition of disability that draws upon existing definitions in both Commonwealth and State legislation and includes the concepts of physical, sensory, intellectual and psychiatric impairment. The definition of disability includes the total or partial loss of a bodily function; the presence in the body of organisms causing, or capable of causing, disease, including HIV AIDS; total or partial loss of a part of the body; and malfunction or disfigurement of part of a person's body. It includes a disability which presently exists, existed in the past but has now ceased to exist, or may exist in the future, and a disability which is imputed or presumed to a person.

I will now describe the areas in which the Bill proscribes discrimination on the ground of disability. The legislation would make unlawful discrimination against applicants for jobs and employees generally and would include access to employment; the practices of employment agencies; the use of discriminatory questions in employment application forms; access to opportunities for promotion, transfer or training, or to any other benefits connected with employment; and dismissal of an employee or subjecting an employee to any detriment. The legislation would also cover the employment of agents and contract workers; membership as a partner in a firm; membership of a trade union; and any action of a licensing or a qualifying body with respect to the conferring, renewal or extension of any licence or qualification.

With regard to education, it would be unlawful for an educational authority to discriminate in the admission and treatment of students and in the provision of all levels of education, training and vocational or educational assistance, including financial assistance. It would be unlawful to discriminate against people with a disability in relation to the provision of access to premises, including vehicles to which the general public has access.

The legislation would also make unlawful discrimination in the provision of goods, facilities and services, covering the supply, and term of supply or provision, of goods and facilities and the provision of services, including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance; services relating to entertainment, recreation or refreshment; services relating to transport, travel or telecommunications; services of any profession or trade; selling or leasing an interest in land; and services provided by a government, government authority or local government body. Discrimination relating to the provision of accommodation, including access to any benefits associated with accommodation, would also be unlawful.

The legislation would mean that it would be unlawful for a club, the committee or management of a club, or a committee member, to discriminate on the ground of disability, including membership and access to the benefits associated with membership. The legislation would also apply to sporting and recreational activities.

The legislation would cover administrative practices adopted by people charged with the administration of Commonwealth enactments, where the enactment does not itself authorise the discrimination. The legislation would make it unlawful to require another person to provide information on which unlawful discrimination might be based, unless the information is reasonably required for a lawful purpose.

The Bill provides for two general exemptions: unjustifiable hardship and the inherent requirements of the job. These exemptions will be very significant in terms of the overall effects of this legislation on service providers, businesses and employers.

Under the Bill, employers, providers of accommodation, education, goods and services, clubs and sporting groups would be able to argue that action necessary to accommodate the needs of people with disabilities would impose unjustifiable hardship. In determining unjustifiable hardship, all of the relevant circumstances of a particular case would be taken into account. These circumstances would include the nature of the benefit or detriment likely to accrue or be suffered by any persons concerned, the effect of the impairment of the persons concerned, and the financial circumstances and the estimated amount of expenditure required to be made by the person claiming unjustifiable hardship. Any judgment made would allow for the financial viability of an employer having to meet additional costs even where, on the face of it, the costs would appear to be fairly small.

The legislation would not require that people with disabilities be given jobs which they cannot do. Subsequently there is an exemption which does not prohibit discrimination if the person is not able to perform adequately the inherent requirements of the job, even where reasonable accommodation has been made.

The Bill contains a provision which requires the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to take into account the provision of any action plan lodged by a service provider or educational authority when determining whether unjustifiable hardship exists in relation to a particular complaint. These plans are entirely voluntary, but the Bill indicates that they shall include certain provisions if they are drawn up. These include policies and programs to achieve the objects of the Bill; the communication of those policies and programs to persons within the body preparing the plan; the setting of goals or targets against which the success of the plan may be measured; the means of evaluating the policies and programs developed; the revision of the plan; and the appointment of persons charged with the implementation of the plans. The plans would be lodged with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and would be publicly available. The Commission will not be required to agree to a plan lodged with it, but the plan will have to be considered by the Commission when determining whether unjustifiable hardship exists in the circumstance that a complaint is made against the particular agency.

The Bill makes it clear that once a complainant has been able to show that he has been subjected to unlawful discrimination, a respondent claiming unjustifiable hardship would bear an evidentiary burden. Similarly, an employer will have to determine what the inherent requirements of a particular job might be. However, the overall legal burden of proof, in proving discrimination unlawful, will remain with the complainant.

Special exemptions include those special measures taken to assist people with disabilities to meet their particular needs; affirmative action measures which are designed to enable and encourage equality of opportunity; and insurance and superannuation where there is actuarial or statistical data to support a particular action. Acts done under statutory authority, in direct compliance with any other Acts, regulations, rules or by-laws, and acts done in accordance with determinations of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission would be exempt from the legislation for a period of three years.

Special exemptions would also apply to infectious diseases; to participation in sporting activities for people with particular disabilities; the provision of pensions under specific Acts; and to the recruitment of certain defence force personnel. Further, an exemption of three years would apply to telecommunications to allow for the impact of the legislation on Telecom and the proposed second carrier to be properly assessed.

Provision is also made for applications to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission for short term, renewable exemptions from all or parts of the legislation. The Commission would have the power to make interim determinations to preserve the status quo or the rights of the parties to a complaint.

Administration of the legislation would be vested in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The functions of the Commission would include holding inquiries into and making determinations on complaints; hearing applications for exemption from the Act; undertaking research and educational programs; and examination of existing and proposed legislation to ensure its consistency with the provisions of this legislation.

The Bill would establish a Disability Discrimination Commissioner who is required to investigate and conciliate complaints of discrimination on the ground of disability. The Commissioner would be empowered to dismiss a complaint if found to be unsubstantiated, or attempt to reach a settlement of the complaint. The Commissioner would have the power to summons witnesses to give evidence or produce documents and to call compulsory conferences. The aim of the legislation would be to promote resolution through conciliation wherever possible.

However, where the Commissioner was unable to resolve a complaint by conciliation, he or she would have the power to refer the matter to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The Commission would then consider the complaint and make a determination on that complaint based on the requirements of the Act. The determination of the Commission would not of itself be binding. Should a party wish to enforce the determination of the Commission an application would be made to the Federal Court. That court would then hear the matter again and make a legally binding judgment taking into account the same criteria taken into account by the Commission.

The Bill also contains provisions to allow for the making of disability standards in the future. Equivalent standards are provided for in both the American and Canadian legislation of this sort. These standards would not be made without extensive consultations by the Commonwealth with all affected parties. The Bill contains provisions requiring that account be taken of comments by State and Territory governments before such standards are enacted. A national public education and awareness campaign will accompany the introduction of this legislation in order to raise the level of understanding of people with disabilities about their rights.

The direct financial implications of this legislation relate to the establishment of the Office of Disability Discrimination Commissioner, the public education and awareness campaign, some minor additional public service staffing and additional resources for support and representative agencies. This is expected to amount to approximately $5.5m in the first full year. Costs to Commonwealth agencies affected by the Bill are not easy to predict but on the basis of previous State experience are not expected to be significant and would occur over a lengthy period of time.

As part of this Government's commitment to social justice for all Australian citizens, we have already passed legislation to provide protection for women and ethnic or racial groups who experience discrimination. It is now time to address the discrimination that people with disabilities have historically suffered. The introduction of this Bill is further evidence of the unwavering commitment of this Government to social justice for people with disabilities.

Our vision is a fairer Australia where people with disabilities are regarded as equals, with the same rights as all other citizens, with recourse to systems that redress any infringements of their rights; where people with disabilities can participate in the life of the community in which they live, to the degree that they wish; where people with disabilities can gain and hold meaningful employment that provides wages and career opportunities that reflect performance; where control by people with disabilities over their own bodies, lives and future is assumed and ensured; where difference is accepted, and where public instrumentalities, communities and individuals act to ensure that society accommodates such difference. Only then will we be able to say that justice has been achieved.

It is therefore essential that there is a legislative basis to enable people with disabilities to participate in the economic, social and political spheres of the community and subsequently to determine the direction of their own lives. This legislation would be a vital element in removing the attitudinal, physical, structural and institutional barriers that people with disabilities currently face. The realisation of this Government's social justice goals for people with disabilities will benefit not only people with disabilities, but society as a whole.

In the gallery there are members of the Disability Advisory Council of Australia and people who represent people with disabilities. This legislation is a major achievement for them, and it is a significant day for the Parliament when we are able to produce further legislation in terms of anti-discrimination that ensures we add to people's rights as citizens. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum for this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: This Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill, which I have been given leave to introduce, is a companion bill to the Disability Discrimination Bill 1992. This Bill enacts amendments to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 necessary to implement the Disability Discrimination Bill. These relate to making the Disability Discrimination Commissioner a part of the Commission which will now have six members. The Bill also makes a number of other amendments of a machinery nature.

PARA.TAB: The Amendment Bill also contains amendments to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act, the Racial Discrimination Act 1976 and the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 which bring those pieces of legislation more into line with current Commonwealth practice in areas such as the delegation of functions and acting arrangements. The Bill of itself has no financial implications. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Sugar Cane Levy Amendment Bill is to amend the maximum rate of levy on sugar cane to 15c per tonne, as provided for in section 7 of the Sugar Cane Levy Act 1987. The Bill has been prepared following a request from the Australian raw sugar industry. The request was made by the Australian Cane Growers Council, represented by Canegrowers, and the Australian Cane Farmers Association on behalf of sugar cane growers and the Australian Sugar Milling Council on behalf of the millers of sugar cane.

PARA.TAB: The Sugar Cane Levy Act 1987 provides for an industry levy on sugar cane produced in Australia and accepted for processing at a sugar mill, to provide funds for the activities of the Sugar Research and Development Corporation. The Act provides for a maximum rate of levy which is currently set at 10c per tonne of sugar cane.

The Government provides funding to match industry levies up to 0.5 per cent of the annual gross value of production, GVP, in line with established policy of encouraging increased rural productivity and profitability through research and the commercialisation of research findings.It is generally recognised that research and development in the sugar industry is underfunded at present when compared with Commonwealth funding of research and development efforts in other rural industries. Currently about 0.17 per cent of GVP is being matched in the sugar industry when compared with an estimated 0.5 per cent in the wool, meat, wheat and oilseed industries.

The sugar industry is committed to industry funded research and wishes to increase its commitment to the Commonwealth scheme through an increased levy in order to maintain its competitive export and domestic marketing position. The current rate of levy is 6c per tonne. However, the sugar industry has indicated its wish to increase that levy to 14c per tonne for the 1992 season. The current maximum levy rate of 10c per tonne is thus hindering this increase and so preventing the sugar industry from utilising the full potential of the Commonwealth R&D scheme.

The Government's rural research and development policy, which encourages increased contributions by primary industry, was established by the Government in February 1985 and reaffirmed in the May 1989 Government statement, Research, Innovation and Competitiveness.

The sugar industry is one of Australia's most important agricultural industries. Sugar is Australia's third most valuable export crop, after wheat and cotton, and 75 to 80 per cent of raw sugar production is exported. Production in 1991-92 was 3.2 million tonnes of raw sugar from a drought affected crop of 21.3 million tonnes of sugar cane, with a gross value of production estimated at $585m. This is well below the record level of 3.8 million tonnes of sugar produced in 1989-90, but production is expected to rise again, with increases in the area of land under cane.

About 95 per cent of total Australian sugar production is based in Queensland with the remainder drawn from northern New South Wales. The Bill will come into force on royal assent.I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
