SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the initiative announced in the One Nation statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to alleviate the problems small and medium sized Australian firms have experienced in obtaining patient equity capital. It also reflects changes to the announced program made to enhance its attractiveness.

PARA.TAB: The Bill provides for the establishment of investment companies, to be called pooled development funds, which will provide patient equity capital for eligible activities in Australian companies with total assets not greater than $30m.

One of the concerns of industry expressed most frequently to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) is the failure of the Australian capital market to provide long term development capital for productive investment. The problem was raised again during the consultations that Ministers had with business prior to the One Nation statement. It is difficult to prove the case about the lack of development capital, but the anecdotal evidence is quite strong.

There is a compelling need to improve the flow of development capital to revitalise and restructure mature industries by the application of new technologies, new processes and new management; assist the growth and development of new industries and firms; and provide basic competence in generic technologies such as biotechnology, information technology, new materials and manufacturing technologies which will be fundamental to industry competitiveness in the 1990s.

Small and medium sized firms are the wellspring from which much of the future growth and prosperity of the Australian economy depends. The potential for growth of these firms is influenced by their ability to fund investment to expand production capacity or to enter new markets.

The Government recognises that there are imperfections in the capital market and that small and medium sized firms often have difficulty in obtaining equity capital, especially those that are technology based or those that are in the early stages of potentially rapid growth. Suitable development capital is often unavailable for such firms because suppliers of capital are risk averse and often have a short-term investment outlook; they do not have access to the same range of sources of capital as do larger firms, particularly as there is no reliable and easily accessible market for trading equity in small businesses; and adverse economic conditions have encouraged investors to concentrate on established, larger and safer businesses. This program is an important element in the Government's overall strategy of removing impediments to the growth of Australian industry and improving the employment prospects for all Australians.

This Bill establishes a Pooled Development Funds Registration Board, comprising a chairperson and four members drawn from the private sector and an officer from the Department to administer the program. The board will advise the Minister annually and at other appropriate times on the operation of the program.

Australian companies with access to appropriate management expertise and sources of capital may apply to the board for registration as a PDF. The application will need to provide details of the company's investment plans, capital raising strategy, management team and other matters. The Government has decided not to limit the pool of capital that may be invested through the PDFs. Any number of PDFs may be registered and the PDFs can raise as much capital as they can attract.

To encourage investment in PDFs, the Government has decided to tax PDFs at 30 per cent rather than at the general company tax rate of 39 per cent, and to allow investors in PDFs to elect to receive their dividends either as tax exempt or through the imputation system. The latter feature is a significant modification of the program since its announcement, and will provide improved benefits for shareholders facing a tax rate below 30 per cent. It has also removed the taxation based inhibitions on low tax investors, such as super funds, from investing in small and medium sized businesses via PDFs. In addition, any gains on the sale of shares in PDFs will be tax exempt. Further details on these incentives will be provided on introduction of the Bill to amend the tax laws to give effect to these and other initiatives in the One Nation statement.

The tax benefits will not come into play until the investment activity by the PDFs is successful. In effect, the Government and the shareholders will share the benefits of the PDFs' activities through a lower tax rate and tax exempt returns to shareholders. The benefits to the Government and the economy will come from the expansion in business activity and growth in employment in the PDF investee businesses.

PDFs will be required to comply with certain rules set out in the Bill. The tax benefits are conditional on the PDFs complying with those rules and this will be monitored by the board. While the ultimate sanction for breaking the requirements will be revocation of the PDF status of a particular company, the board will have other discretionary powers to ensure that the spirit of the program is not breached.

There have been some useful suggestions by investment and fund managers to features of the PDF proposal announced in the One Nation statement. One of the suggestions relates to the nature of the proposed tax incentive, and this has been addressed in the modifications to the tax treatment mentioned earlier.

Other comments have concentrated on improving the commercial flexibility of the PDFs. The Government has also taken notice of these suggestions by both changing some of the parameters announced earlier and providing the board with discretions to allow it to waive some of the requirements for particular PDFs in certain situations.

Previously it was announced that apart from life offices and banks, no investor could own more than 10 per cent of a PDF. Furthermore, a PDF could not invest more than 10 per cent of its funds in any one business. Both of these parameters have been changed to 20 per cent. In addition, in certain circumstances PDFs will be able to invest in previously owned shares.

In relation to discretions, it is expected that the board will exercise these only where the commercial realities require such action. For example, the intention is that PDFs invest in small and medium sized companies and $30m in total assets has been chosen as the benchmark. However, the board may allow a further investment in companies if the value of the total assets in the investee business exceeds $30m where it is clear that the further investment is desirable to protect earlier ones. These discretions in no way undermine the integrity and objectives of the Government's program.

PDFs may invest only in companies and only for the purpose of establishing new businesses or substantially developing new production capacity or markets for established businesses. There is no requirement for PDFs to seek approval for individual investments. The PDFs may not invest more than 5 per cent of their assets in start-up businesses.

The Government considers that there should be a wide choice in the industry spread for investments by the PDFs. Accordingly, the Bill provides that PDFs may invest in any area of business activity other than:

SPEECH.PARA: .retailing operations; and
.real estate investment other than property investment which is integral to broader eligible activities.

PARA.TAB: The Government expects there will be a broad range of investors in the PDFs. Potential investors, such as corporations and super funds, will have the opportunity of deriving non-tax benefits. Corporate investors derive benefits from emerging technologies and new products that fit their own business activities and expansion plans. Super funds can take advantage of the expertise of the PDF management teams.

The Government is aware that this program will not meet all of the needs for channelling capital to small and medium sized firms. In setting up the program, the Government was mindful of the need to contain costs, yet make it sufficiently attractive to ensure its viability. The Government is also aware that in a market economy capital will always be a scarce resource. I believe that the program will become an important vehicle for marshalling capital for small and medium sized businesses, and assist in the process of economic recovery.

Additional expenditure of some $400,000 annually will be incurred on an ongoing basis to cover extra costs associated with the administration of the program. Tax revenue forgone is estimated at $5m commencing in 1994-95, with higher levels being possible as the program develops. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Development Allowance Authority Bill was foreshadowed in the announcement of the development allowance in the Government's One Nation statement of February this year. The Government gives a high priority to the introduction of this and the related One Nation initiatives legislation. Passage of this legislation, in establishing the Development Allowance Authority, the DAA, to facilitate investment and reform in major projects, in conjunction with related amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, brings the development allowance to working reality.

PARA.TAB: The development allowance itself builds on the advantages of the accelerated depreciation measures also announced in the One Nation statement. The development allowance will achieve this by promoting an early upturn in investment in new plant and equipment for projects which offer particular benefits for our competitiveness in world markets.

The development allowance has two key economic objectives. First, it seeks to encourage an early upturn in investment in new plant and equipment. Second, at the same time, it looks to encourage reform both within those companies receiving the allowance and in the economic environment in which they operate.

The allowance is modest in its direct impact on firms—providing a 10 per cent deduction against assessable income for eligible plant expenditure once incurred. But its indirect effect is potentially much greater. The allowance provides firms looking to undertake large projects with additional leverage to negotiate progress against a broad best practice agenda. Ideally, these reforms will work their way through our industrial system to impact positively on the operational environment for those projects not benefiting directly from the allowance.

The DAA in prequalifying a project for the allowance must be satisfied that the project's contribution to our competitive standing is both sufficient and achievable. Importantly, the development allowance best typifies a central theme of One Nation—development initiatives being contingent on efficiency gains being achieved. Put simply, the development allowance rewards success and represents a conscious rejection of those policies of the past which underwrote loss and failure.

After One Nation, Bill Scales, the new Chair of the Industry Commission, reported to the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) on the operational aspects of the development allowance. This Bill follows from that report. The Bill establishes the DAA and sets out the scope of the Authority's role in assessing the eligibility of projects to prequalify for the development allowance. While the DAA is to determine what plant expenditure, once incurred, will prequalify for the allowance, the final decision as to eligibility will rest with the Commissioner of Taxation.

The DAA is to be a one-member statutory authority operating within the Treasurer's portfolio. The Treasurer will make an announcement shortly as to who will hold the office of the DAA. The DAA will receive support from a secretariat—the Development Allowance Authority Secretariat—that is being established within the Treasury. The cost of the development allowance is estimated to be approximately $40m in 1994-95 and $70m in 1995-96.

The Bill sets out a working example of an applicant progressing through the various steps towards obtaining a prequalifying certificate from the DAA. This example highlights how the work of the DAA and the process for obtaining eligibility are framed around a timetable of key trigger dates. These dates reflect the underlying objectives of the allowance.

In brief, a project proponent first applies to the DAA to register a project that is expected to meet the eligibility criteria and, unless the project has substantially commenced by end 1992, the competitiveness tests for the development allowance. The DAA then assesses the applicant's case against the criteria set out in the Bill. Once registered, the next stage involves the applicant providing the DAA with documentation that demonstrates that the project has the necessary approvals and authorisations to substantially commence.

The final phase involves an application and project report to the DAA for a prequalifying certificate. An entity holding a prequalifying certificate claims the development allowance, subject to the relevant tax tests, from the Australian Taxation Office once the expenditure is incurred. I turn now to the key elements of the Bill—providing for the DAA's assessment of a project against the objectives I have outlined.

Central to the legislation is the concept of a project. The allowance is available only to large projects. A threshold has been set of a gross capital expenditure of $50m or more. Gross capital expenditure is total expenditure of a capital nature that is incurred, or will be incurred, in carrying out the project. Encouraging projects of this magnitude will induce confidence in our economic future. As mentioned before, large projects will be better placed to use the allowance as a lever to secure reform and best practice, both within their operations and the economic environment in which they operate. Further, the demonstration effect of reform secured by these large projects will be substantial.

The Bill sets out the meaning of carrying out a project for the purposes of the development allowance. A project may involve establishing a new productive facility in Australia, or establishing two or more related productive facilities that make up either a discrete or vertically integrated project in Australia. A project may also involve expansions, improvements or upgrades of a substantial nature at a new or existing productive facility. Environment upgrades will be eligible. However, projects involving ongoing maintenance-related investment or the aggregation of investment in unrelated productive facilities will not be eligible.

A productive facility is defined as a facility used primarily by the operator for the production or distribution of the same or related goods or services. It is also required that plant expenditure is to be incurred wholly or principally for carrying out the project for which the entity is seeking a prequalifying certificate. The intention here is to quarantine the allowance to that plant expenditure that is genuinely for primary use in the eligible project.

The basic eligibility test reflects the fact that the development allowance is an initiative conceived in the emerging low tariff environment. Certain activities, largely in the non-traded sectors and specified in the Bill, are excluded from eligibility for the allowance. In addition, projects which are heavily assisted are also excluded from eligibility.

The Bill sets out a clear test to be applied in establishing whether the project benefits from substantial assistance. This test involves an applicant satisfying the DAA that the project does not have a nominal or effective rate of assistance—taking the lower—exceeding 10 per cent. These are accepted measures of assistance, and are to be calculated in a manner consistent with the methodology used by the Industry Commission. The calculation will be based on the level of tariff or other foreshadowed levels of assistance that are to apply on 1 July 1996.

Where the entire productive facility fails the basic eligibility test, then none of the expenditure will be eligible for the allowance. If only a part of the project falls within this category, then only that expenditure related to the excluded sector is ineligible.

The competitiveness test is the linchpin for the wider benefits of the development allowance initiative. There are two parts to the test. First, the DAA must be satisfied that the project's labour-management arrangements substantially reflect world best practice and, second, that the prices of key inputs to the project's operation are economic and efficient. Key inputs could include, for example, products from a statutory marketing authority or private supplier for which the project involves their further processing; the transport by government or private rail systems of those inputs and final product to the market place; and electricity or other infrastructure support. The key input prices test does not apply to inputs of land, labour and capital. If the DAA is satisfied that a registered project has substantially commenced by the end of 1992, then in order that the project not be further delayed the project will not be required to meet the competitiveness test.

Importantly the Bill enables the DAA to facilitate the allowance approvals process. The DAA, with the consent of the applicant, may approach a third party to advise it that its action, or inaction, has prevented or may prevent the project from prequalifying or registering for the development allowance. The goal here is to help the applicant secure the reforms that are part of the objective of the allowance.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Key Trigger Dates—Registration, Approvals and Certification

PARA.TAB: For a project to be considered by the DAA, the DAA must be satisfied that the project had in no way or form been commenced by the entity or a related entity before 27 February 1992. This is intended to reinforce the objective of the allowance: to bring forward investment in new plant and equipment. Proponents are required to have applied to the DAA for registration by 1 January 1993.

The Bill sets out the procedures for an applicant to register a project with the DAA. The applicant is required to provide a written application and project report setting out such information about the project as required by the DAA. An application needs to be signed by the chairperson, in the case of a company, or a person of equivalent authority for a non-company entity. This requirement is to help ensure that the proponent is genuinely committed to the project.

The Bill also specifies the criteria against which the DAA assesses an application for registration. These criteria are intended to ensure that the applicant has a genuine intention to proceed with an eligible project within the specified time frame: for example, the project did not commence prior to 27 February 1992; has passed, or is reasonably likely to pass, the $50m threshold test; will not operate in a protected or ineligible sector of the economy; is reasonably likely to be completed; and, further, there is reasonably likely to be a substantial commitment to the project's completion by 1 July 1996.

By 1 July 1995 the applicant must furnish the DAA with approvals and documentation that demonstrate that the project has the necessary authorisations and approvals in order to substantially commence. This is an important precursor to the DAA being satisfied by 1 July 1996 that there is a substantial commitment to the project's completion.

The cut-off date for applying for a prequalifying certificate is 1 August 1996. Importantly, in addition to meeting the basic eligibility and competitiveness tests, the project needs to have substantially commenced; that is, there is a substantial commitment to the project's completion by 1 July 1996. The Bill specifies factors which the DAA may take into account in making this assessment. For example, a substantial commitment to complete a project would not be taken to have occurred where contracts for only a small proportion of the project's total cost have been entered into and where there is no substantial physical evidence that the project has commenced.

The Bill sets out the procedures for an applicant to obtain a prequalifying certificate. As in the case of registration, an entity must lodge a written application and project report setting out such information as is required by the DAA to assess the project. An application will not be accepted from an entity that has not registered and has not met the conditions attached to the registration; for example, that final documentation relating to approvals have been provided by 1 July 1995.

The Bill also specifies the criteria against which the DAA assesses an application for a prequalifying certificate. These criteria are intended to ensure that the applicant has met the relevant tests and that there is a substantial commitment by 1 July 1996 to the project's completion.
Finally, and this is a test for the Commissioner of Taxation under the Tax Act, the plant must be in use or installed ready for use by 1 July 2002.

To ensure that the DAA does not spend time assessing applications which would not in any event be eligible for the allowance under the relevant tax tests, the Bill allows the DAA to apply a prospective deduction test to determine whether the entity's expenditure is reasonably likely to be deductible under the Tax Act.

Underlying these processes is the requirement that the entity must satisfy the DAA that the tests have been met. This will involve the entity furnishing the DAA with adequate information and/or documentation in order that the DAA is satisfied that the project has passed the relevant tests. That information will be provided by the applicant to the DAA primarily in the application form and the project report. To ensure the DAA is well positioned to assess each case against the relevant information set, the DAA has powers to request that an entity provide additional information or documentation. If an applicant fails to meet such a request, the DAA is empowered to refuse to consider the application.

In light of the degree of intellectual rigour needed to apply the policy objectives reflected, for example, in the competitiveness test, the Bill allows the DAA to draw on the expertise of consultants and Commonwealth authorities, for example the Industry Commission, in assessing the eligibility of applicants.

The Bill also provides for the suitable handling and treatment of commercial-in-confidence information. The entity may apply to the DAA to have certain information treated as commercial-in-confidence, and the DAA is required to accede to that request unless the DAA considers that the public interest suggests otherwise.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Transfers and Variations—Registration and Prequalifying Certificate

PARA.TAB: The Bill also allows applications to be made by a range of commercial entities, including companies, partnerships, joint ventures, and company groups in the case of a vertically integrated company group project scheme. The project definitions, applying to these entities, is structured to ensure that a genuine project is being proposed by the commercial entity.

The Bill is structured to reflect that the DAA operates amidst commercial reality whereby a genuine transfer in the responsibility for completing a project or a project's modification may warrant corresponding changes in the registration and certification documents. While complex in appearance, underlying these provisions is an intention to ensure that the DAA can operate flexibly when such changes are demonstrably based on commercial realities and are genuine endeavours to complete the same, or substantially the same, project as was originally registered or certified. For example, the Bill enables the DAA to transfer registration or certification to a new or restructured entity in certain circumstances, including where the transfer of the project's responsibility is genuine, for genuine commercial reasons and the project is the same or substantially the same as that originally registered or certified.

The DAA may cancel or terminate a certificate in certain circumstances. In the case of a failure to comply with an information request the DAA may terminate a certificate or cancel a registration. Termination of a certificate only impacts on expenditure incurred after the date of termination. Cancellation has the same effect as if registration or a prequalifying certificate had never been granted. If an entity provides the DAA or a Department officer with false or misleading information, then the DAA may cancel the registration or certificate. The DAA is also required to cancel a registration or terminate a certificate at the entity's request.

The key link between the work of the DAA and the entity finally obtaining the development allowance from the ATO lies in the prequalifying certificate. The prequalifying certificate will specify the elements of the project. The plant expenditure that once incurred will prequalify for the allowance. As previously mentioned, prequalifying under this Bill does not automatically entitle the entity to the development allowance. That determination is ultimately one for the Commissioner of Taxation.

The DAA is required to notify the Commissioner of Taxation of any action taken under this Bill which impacts on the operation of the development allowance provisions of the Tax Act. For example, if a certificate is cancelled, the DAA would advise the Commissioner of Taxation in order that the Commissioner of Taxation can reassess any allowances already claimed.

The Bill sets out the procedures for reviewing decisions made by the DAA. The key feature of this part is that a request by an applicant to review a DAA decision is first subject to reconsideration by the DAA itself, before being considered by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. An applicant may request in writing a DAA review within 21 days of the applicant being advised of a DAA decision. The DAA is then required to reconsider that decision within 40 days. If a decision is not made within that time, the decision is taken to have been confirmed. This is intended to ensure that a request is not held up by the DAA and may be subsequently reviewed by the AAT.

The Bill contains provisions whereby both the Minister and the Parliament are kept well informed of the operations of the DAA. The DAA will be required—up to 1 July 1997—to prepare an annual report which is to be tabled within 15 sitting days of its receipt. In addition, the DAA will be required to provide the Minister with quarterly reports on the operation of the DAA up to 1 January 1997. Following that date, the DAA will be required to provide a periodic report and/or annual report at the request of the Minister. The variation in the reporting requirements over time reflect the anticipated workload of the DAA in line with the key trigger dates for registration and certification.

In terms of the administrative framework, the Bill provides for a full or part time DAA office-holder until 1 January 1997. It is envisaged that the initial appointment will be on a full time basis. The Bill allows for the Minister's providing a written determination to the Governor-General to terminate a full time appointment if the Minister considers that the workload is insufficient to justify a full time appointment. The Bill also enables the DAA to delegate its powers and functions to a SES officer in the Department.

Post-1 January 1997 and until 1 July 2002, the office of the DAA may be undertaken on an acting basis by an SES officer in the Department of the Treasury. From 1 July 2002, the office of DAA may be undertaken on an acting basis by a SES officer in the Australian Taxation Office. These provisions reflect the anticipated workload and responsibilities of the DAA against the operational trigger dates for registration and pre-qualifying certification.

The Bill also contains adequate conflict of interest provisions. In particular, if the DAA has an interest related in any way to a matter to be considered by the DAA, then the DAA is required to advise the Minister and take no further action until the Minister has determined, within 28 days, whether that interest will conflict with the DAA performing its functions. Should the Minister consider that the interest would conflict with the DAA effectively performing its functions, then the Minister shall direct the DAA to delegate the matter to a SES officer in the Department.

Finally, miscellaneous provisions of the Bill provide for regulations not inconsistent with the Bill, and that if a document is given to one partner then it can be assumed to have been given to the partnership.
To sum up, the Development Allowance Authority is the conduit to our securing the potential benefits of the development allowance—

SPEECH.PARA: .A relatively modest initiative but with a profound indirect effect.
.Having received the allowance, project operators stand on their own. The allowance is self-liquidating so that it does not see firms entrenched in a handout mentality.
.The allowance both stimulates and rewards success.

PARA.TAB: To conclude, the establishment of the DAA represents the Government's moving into a mature phase of development initiatives in a low tariff environment. Underpinning this shift is a rejection of the handout mentality of the past. In its place is the acceptance that government alone cannot forge the reform agenda. Business must itself internalise a reform agenda for the economic and institutional environment in which it operates. The DAA and the development allowance will be a catalyst for broadening the best practice agenda which will secure efficiency and productivity gains. It is those gains and reform mentality that will lay the groundwork for income and employment growth and job security.
This Bill provides for the establishment of the DAA to ensure the development allowance operates to secure the above ends. Mr Speaker, I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Prosser) adjourned.
Bill presented by Mr Baldwin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will amend the taxation laws to implement several measures outlined by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his One Nation statement of 26 February 1992. It will change the taxation provisions to make investment in Australian industry more attractive. This is, of course, part of the Government's strategy to assist Australian business to become more competitive in the international arena.

PARA.TAB: The Bill will amend the depreciation provisions in a number of respects. Taxpayers who install depreciable property on crown leases will no longer be denied depreciation deductions only by reason of the fact that the property is attached to leased land.

Capital expenditure on the construction of buildings used for short term traveller accommodation and industrial buildings will be able to be written off at an accelerated rate. The Bill will also extend depreciation eligibility to certain structural improvements at the 2 1/2 per cent rate accorded income producing buildings. The Bill also provides for the taxation treatment of the proposed development allowance and pooled development funds.
Also provided for in the Bill are the taxation measures to provide the facility for certain new transport and electricity projects to be financed by means of non-assessable/non-deductible borrowings.

Another One Nation initiative to be provided for by this Bill is amendments to the bad debt provisions to remove some uncertainty as to the operation of the taxation law. In addition to these One Nation measures, the Bill will amend the definition of primary production and the research and development provisions of the taxation law.

The definition of `primary production' will be amended to include taxpayers engaged in horticulture. `Horticulture' will include the propagation or cultivation of plants for themselves or their commercially useful parts and includes the use of intensive and artificial growing techniques.

The research and development provisions of the taxation law are to be amended to confirm that prospecting, exploring or drilling for minerals, petroleum or natural gas is not as such research and development (R&D) for the purpose of the special R&D deduction of up to 150 per cent of expenditure.
The Bill will also make changes to the arrangements for the administration of the reasonable benefit limits as set out in the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987.
I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.

This Bill amends the depreciation provisions so that taxpayers who install depreciable property on crown leases will no longer be denied depreciation deductions only by reason of the fact that the property is attached to leased land.

Under existing law, taxpayers who install depreciable property on crown leases can be denied depreciation deductions because, owing to the degree of attachment of the property to the land, the law treats the Crown as the owner, and not the taxpayer who actually incurred the expenditure. Taxpayers must own the property for which deductions are sought.

The law is to be amended to treat taxpayers in those circumstances as owners of the property for depreciation purposes, so enabling them to obtain deductions for the income-producing use of such property that occurs after 26 February 1992.

A number of consequential amendments will be required to the capital gains tax provisions as the result of the changes to the depreciation provisions to ensure that the two provisions treat property on crown leases in a consistent manner. Those consequential amendments will be introduced during the Budget session of the Parliament and will apply from the same date as the depreciation changes, 26 February 1992. These depreciation amendments are not expected to have a significant impact on the revenue.

The capital cost of buildings used in the provision of short term traveller accommodation is to be evenly deductible over 25 years at the rate of 4 per cent per annum, up from 2.5 per cent per annum. The higher rate will also apply to extensions, alterations or improvements.

The amendment applies to hotels, motels and guesthouses that contain at least 10 rooms available for short term use by travellers. It also applies to buildings containing not less than 10 apartments, units or flats, and associated facilities, for short term use by travellers. The higher rate will be available where construction commences after 26 February 1992.
The estimated cost to revenue of these amendments is nil in 1991-92 and 1992-93; $2m in 1993-94; $6m in 1994-95; and $12m in 1995-96.

The rate of deduction for buildings used in industrial activities is also to increase from 2.5 per cent per annum to 4 per cent per annum. Industrial activities encompass manufacturing operations and certain closely related activities. They also include the processing of primary products, such as minerals, wool, timber and foodstuffs. Printing and similar activities are also included, as is the production of energy either for sale or for use in manufacturing and related activities. Buildings not covered by the amendments, such as offices and shops, will continue to be deductible at the rate of 2.5 per cent per annum.

The amendment applies to buildings, extensions, alterations or improvements to buildings commenced to be constructed after 26 February 1992. It is estimated that the cost to revenue will be nil in 1991-92 and 1992-93; $3m in 1993-94; $9m in 1994-95; and $18m in 1995-96.

Deductions are to be available for the cost of income producing structures on land that are not presently deductible under existing capital allowance provisions in the law. The rate of deduction will be 2.5 per cent per annum, the same as for most income producing buildings. Examples of structures to which the concession will apply include roads, runways, bridges, dams, walls and fences, including earthworks integral to the installation of those structures.

The amendment will not apply to other non-depreciating earthworks and artificial landscapes such as grass playing fields and fairways. The amendment applies where construction commences after 26 February 1992.

The Bill includes measures to reactivate and amend the former investment allowance provisions to allow a deduction for a restricted period of 10 per cent of capital expenditure on plant and equipment acquired by taxpayers for certain large scale Australian projects. This proposal, which was announced in the One Nation statement on 26 February 1992, is designed to promote an early upturn in investment in new plant and equipment for projects which offer particular benefits for Australia's competitiveness in world markets.

The Development Allowance Authority Bill 1992, which was introduced earlier, is integral to the operation of the taxation provisions covered under this Bill. The Authority will determine whether the criteria have been met to enable the allowance of a taxation deduction. A certificate issued by the Authority is a prerequisite to any taxation deduction. The estimated cost of this measure is expected to be $40m in 1994-95 and $70m in 1995-96.

This Bill will also provide for the taxation of pooled development funds, and the tax effects for persons investing in PDFs. By this measure the Government is facilitating the provision of equity capital for small and medium sized firms.

PDFs will be companies registered by a board established under a Pooled Development Funds Act. The scheme will be administered by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. The Pooled Development Funds Bill was also introduced earlier.

PDFs will be taxed on their taxable income at a concessional rate of 30 per cent. Their taxable income will be calculated on the same basis as that of other companies. The imputation provisions of the income tax law will apply to PDFs in the same way as they apply to other companies. Dividends paid by PDFs will therefore be frankable.

Unfranked dividends paid by PDFs will be exempt from income tax. In the case of franked PDF dividends, shareholders will have the choice of claiming the exemption or using the imputation credits attached to those dividends by including the dividends in their assessable income. Shareholders will also be exempt from tax on any profits or gains on the disposal of PDF shares. Correspondingly, no deductions will be allowable for any losses incurred on disposal.
There is not expected to be a revenue cost for the first two years for this measure. The estimated cost for 1994-95 and 1995-96 is $5m in each year.

The Bill creates a category of borrowings—described as infrastructure borrowings—that will be available to finance the construction of certain new land transport, seaport and electricity generating facilities.The tax benefits provided by this measure will facilitate private sector investment in the construction, ownership and operation of infrastructure that in the past was normally undertaken by the public sector.

Infrastructure projects of the type specified typically have a long construction period and do not produce revenue for some years. This can mean that companies borrowing to develop such projects will not be able to obtain a deduction for interest costs in the year in which they are incurred. The measure will assist the financing of the projects by effectively allowing the borrowing company to transfer the benefit of its interest deduction to investors. Such a transfer reduces the financing cost to the borrower.

The transfer of the benefit of tax deductibility for interest will be achieved by the interest on the infrastructure borrowing being freed from income tax in the hands of investors, with the interest paid by the borrower not qualifying for deduction. Investors in infrastructure borrowings will also benefit by not having to pay income tax on any profits on the disposal of their interest in the borrowing. They will not, however, be able to claim a deduction for any loss on disposal. Importantly, the Government has decided to further encourage private sector investment in the specified areas by allowing a tax deduction for interest on borrowings to invest in infrastructure projects.

The measure, as indicated, is targeted to genuine private sector projects in the areas specified. It is not designed to promote new forms of financing the public sector. Eligibility is based on the private sector infrastructure provider deriving assessable income in consequence of the public being charged a fee for the use of or output from the facility. The tax benefits of an infrastructure borrowing will not be available for projects where there is a form of public underwriting of the risks associated with construction, ownership or use.

Infrastructure borrowings will be able to be used to finance the construction of one of the specified facilities by a company, a corporate unit trust or a public trading trust that intends to own, use and effectively control the use of the facility to generate assessable income for at least 25 years. Companies whose sole purpose is to invest in bodies constructing one of the specified categories of infrastructure facility will also be able to raise infrastructure borrowings.

The maximum period of an infrastructure borrowing, including the refinancing of an infrastructure borrowing, will be 10 years. The estimated revenue cost of this measure for 1993-94, 1994-95 and 1995-96 is $10m, $35m and $100m respectively.

This Bill will give effect to the Prime Minister's announcement in the One Nation statement to amend the bad debt provisions in the income tax law. The Bill will clarify that the writing off of a bad part of a debt is an allowable deduction. It will also ensure that a deduction will be allowed for swap losses where the debt is extinguished on or after 27 February 1992 as a result of entering into debt-equity swap arrangements. Under the proposed amendment, debt-equity swaps may be arranged even though the debt is not yet bad.

The swap loss is the difference between the book value of the debt and the value taken in exchange for the debt. The value of the equity will be its market value or the value recorded in the books of the creditor, whichever is greater. The Bill will also ensure that any profits or losses subsequently realised from the disposal, cancellation or redemption of the equity acquired through debt-equity swaps are assessable or deductible.These measures will enable some debt restructuring for debtors in difficulty without requiring trading to cease and should, therefore, result in some reduction in the number of cases where businesses are liquidated.
The amendment will have no long term cost to the revenue. Some deductions from debt-equity swaps could be brought forward at a small but unquantifiable cost to the revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Expenditure on research and development activities

PARA.TAB: The Bill will confirm that the cost of prospecting, exploring or drilling for minerals, petroleum or natural gas is not as such research and development expenditure for the purpose of the special R&D tax deduction of up to 150 per cent of expenditure. The amendment will ensure that, if the purpose of the prospecting, exploring or drilling activities is to discover, determine more precisely the location of, or determine the size or quality of, deposits, then the activities are not research and development activities.
The amendment will have no effect on revenue.

Taxpayers engaged in the cultivation or propagation of plants in media other than soil do not qualify as primary producers under the income tax law. The Government believes this is inequitable. The Bill therefore proposes an amendment to the definition of primary production so as to include taxpayers engaged in horticulture. The proposed definition of horticulture will apply to taxpayers who are engaged in the cultivation or propagation of plants, including fungi, for themselves or their commercially useful parts, and expressly includes propagation or cultivation in media other than soil. The definition will not apply to activities other than in the course of, or for the purpose of, a business. The estimated cost to the revenue of the inclusion of horticulture in the definition of primary production will be $0.5m per year from 1992-93.

The Bill will make changes to the arrangements for the administration of the reasonable benefit limits, RBL, as set out in the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987. The RBL apply to the total amount of retirement benefits receivable on a concessionally taxed basis. The payment of amounts in excess of the RBL are identified by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner and communicated to the Commissioner of Taxation for tax assessment purposes.

The Bill proposes that only RBL determinations made by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner that result in an income tax liability for the taxpayers be notified. At present the Act requires that all determination decisions made by the Commissioner be individually notified to taxpayers. The Bill also proposes that determinations which do not give rise to a tax liability can be notified upon the initiative of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. The existing right of taxpayers to request a copy of a determination will remain.

Almost 600,000 determinations were dispatched for payments made in 1990-91. It is estimated that the effect of the proposed changes will be to reduce the number of determinations required to be notified by approximately 50 per cent. This will result in substantial reductions in the administrative burden on ordinary taxpayers, particularly when completing their tax returns.There will also be reductions in ISC administrative costs other than a small cost increase to be incurred next year to cover implementation. The changes will be advertised widely in the press before 30 June so that taxpayers are aware of them in time for the lodgment of tax returns. The combined cost of implementing the proposed measures is estimated to be $70,000 in 1991-92 and $0.3m in 1992-93. Estimated savings for 1993-94 and following years are estimated at $0.1m per annum.
I present the explanatory memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Reith) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the main Bill in a package of six Bills that will, as part of the simplification of the sales tax law, replace the existing sales tax legislation. It represents a major overhaul by the Government of the existing sales tax law. Overall, the package of Bills will replace the 27 Acts which currently deal exclusively with sales tax. The Sales Tax Assessment Bill 1992 will replace the 11 Assessment Acts, and the Sales Tax Procedure Act, that are necessary to administer the law under its current structure.

PARA.TAB: The main features of the measures are:

SPEECH.PARA: a significant reduction in the number of persons required to pay sales tax;
a complete restructuring and redrafting of the WST legislation, in plain English, to make it simpler to use and more certain in its application;
a streamlining of the system for acquiring business inputs and other conditionally exempt goods free of tax; and
a significant strengthening of the anti-avoidance provisions of the law.

These changes will complement legislation introduced late last year to expand the range of business inputs which are exempted from tax. The simplification of the sales tax law will bring substantial benefits both for taxpayers and the Australian Taxation Office which is responsible for administering the tax. I now turn to the more important changes.

PARA.TAB: The exemption for small business has been considerably widened so that it will offer to the majority of taxpayers the option of not paying tax. Exemption will now be available to all persons liable to pay sales tax if their liability does not exceed $10,000 per annum. This is a considerable advance on the present concession, which is mainly limited to manufacturers and has a generally lower threshold. While the concession will be optional—some small businesses may wish not to take up the concession so that they may continue to acquire their business inputs free from tax—it is expected that a significant number of small businesses will avail themselves of the concession. This will result in savings to those businesses which will no longer be required to lodge returns and make small tax payments to the Australian Taxation Office. It will also reduce the costs of collecting the tax.

Under the existing law it is compulsory for persons liable to pay tax to be registered and quote their certificates of registration. This compulsion will be removed by this Bill. Registration of taxpayers will be optional, as will quotation by those who elect to be registered. This will remove the need for penalties for non-registration or for failure to quote a certificate. It will also relieve taxpayers from the threat of penalty in situations where they are not certain whether they should register or quote a certificate. However, because of the general advantages of registration it is expected that most taxpayers who are currently registered for sales tax will remain registered. Moreover, certain exemptions from tax in the area of business inputs will be restricted on purchase to registered persons.

The Bill will provide a much simpler set of rules for persons who are currently entitled to exemption from sales tax and will continue to be under the new law. Such persons will, in some cases, be able to be registered and simply quote a sales tax registration number to obtain goods tax-free. In other cases they will quote in a similar fashion to the existing conditional exemption system except that there will be authority for it in the law. This will make quotation for persons entitled to exemption more certain. The new system will, however, impose a liability on any person who provides an incorrect certificate. This is considered appropriate bearing in mind that the person providing the certificate should be aware of the purpose of use of the goods and whether or not exemption applies. The new system will also benefit vendor taxpayers who will no longer have a liability if they accept an incorrect certificate in good faith.

Consistent with the Government's policy to stamp out tax avoidance, the Bill will contain a general anti-avoidance provision to catch schemes designed to avoid the payment of sales tax. The general provision will replace a number of provisions that are directed to particular schemes but which do not cover the field of tax avoidance.

The basic aim of the sales tax law is to impose a tax on all goods going into use in Australia for the first time unless they are specifically exempted. There are some gaps in the present law in reaching this aim and the law is to be tightened in certain areas to ensure that all goods that should bear tax do so. This will be achieved by strengthening the provisions relating to royalties and catching certain manufacturing costs that presently fall outside the tax base.Additionally, a liability will be imposed on the sale or use of goods that ordinarily would be subject to tax but somehow have managed to bypass a taxing point without payment of tax.

In revising the existing law, a significant number of Commissioner's discretions have been removed with the object of making the law more self-assessing. Commissioner's discretions have been retained only where it is essential for sound administration or to avoid the need for unduly complex law.

There are a number of other changes to the law which will make it easier to follow. The rules relating to leases have been considerably simplified to bring them into line with sales of goods. A number of complex deeming provisions relating to the making-up of goods from materials supplied by a customer have been removed and replaced with a simpler system. There will be new rules for selling goods tax-free to Australian residents intending to travel overseas which will clarify this situation.

While the new law is a considerable simplification of the existing law there are still some areas which will remain reasonably complex. This is unavoidable with a wholesale tax that is imposed only on goods. However, it is the Government's position that in the field of indirect taxation it favours the present wholesale tax because it enables essential goods such as food and clothing to be exempted from the tax and it leaves important service industries which are vital to the growth of the economy, such as the tourist industry, largely free from tax. It is also much easier to collect, having far fewer collection points than a retail or general consumption tax.

This Bill not only simplifies a relatively complex taxation law but it represents a considerable advance in writing law in a plain English style that can be easily understood by the general public. The new law will not commence to impose tax until three months after it has received the royal assent. During this time the existing law will continue to apply. The delayed introduction will allow the Commissioner of Taxation sufficient time to publicise the changes to the existing law and to set in place the new arrangements that will be necessary for its administration.

Additionally, members of the simplification review will be making themselves available during this period to meet with key bodies and taxpayers' representatives to discuss the new law and to identify any concerns with it. The Government is aware that, in a project that has seen the complete restructuring and re-writing of the sales tax law, it is likely that some errors and unintended omissions or changes are unavoidable. These will only emerge after detailed analysis of the new law over an extended period.

Finally, I would particularly draw honourable members attention to the explanatory memorandum accompanying these Bills. While all of the changes made by the Bill are explained in detail in that document, the aim of the simplification review has not merely been to improve the sales tax law but also to improve the traditional explanatory materials brought forward to explain it. One example of this is the explanatory memorandums for these Bills. They have been specially designed, after discussions with representatives of their users, to meet concerns expressed about the structure and shortcomings of earlier explanatory memorandums. In particular, the memorandums seek to provide, in a form easily accessed by all users, a detailed explanation of all the changes proposed to the existing law as well as the reasons for those changes. Recent advances in computer technology now enable far more professionally presented and better structured material to be brought forward. Maximum use has been made of this technology by the review team. I also note that there is a separate explanatory memorandum which sets out quite comprehensive tables which identify where provisions of the existing law are dealt with in the new law, and vice versa. I commend the Bill to the House.

These three Imposition Bills will have the effect of imposing tax on the assessable dealings that are liable to tax under the Sales Tax Assessment Bill. Three Imposition Bills are necessary because of the requirement of the Constitution that a law imposing taxation shall deal only with one subject of taxation and that laws imposing customs duty and laws imposing excise duties deal only with those duties.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is part of a package of six Bills that make up the new simplified sales tax law. Its purpose is to provide for the necessary transitional arrangements that are essential to ensure a smooth change over from the existing law to the new law. More specifically, the Bill will terminate the old law from the day before the first taxing day under the new law. It will provide that in certain situations goods taxed under the existing law will not be taxed under the new law. Where goods can be taxed under both the existing and new law a credit will be available for tax paid under the existing law. The Bill will also deal with the position of goods acquired tax-free under quote from the existing law but which are not dealt with in a taxable manner until after the first taxing day of the new law.

PARA.TAB: To reduce the burden on taxpayers who are presently registered for sales tax from applying for fresh registration under the new law, there will be provision for existing registrations to continue. Registered persons will not have to reapply for registration. A further transitional provision will preserve the operation of the current small business exemptions to ensure that no small business is disadvantaged by the changeover to the new law. The Bill also covers other minor transitional arrangements.

Finally, in the event that there are some matters not adequately covered by the transitional provisions, there is power for regulations to be made to deal with them. The Government is taking every step to ensure that in the general operation of the sales tax law, no taxpayer will be disadvantaged as a result of the changeover. The operation of the Bill is explained in more detail in the explanatory memorandum circulated with the package of Bills. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the second major Bill in a package of six Bills which make up the new simplified sales tax law. This Bill needs to be read together with the other Bills to which it is linked.

PARA.TAB: The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Bill will identify those goods which will be exempt from sales tax, either absolutely or in certain circumstances. It will also classify the remaining goods for the purpose of determining the rate of sales tax to be paid on them.

The Bill will contain guidelines clarifying the circumstances in which exemption may be claimed to make it easier for persons to decide whether they are entitled to claim exemption. The Bill will require persons claiming exemption to intend to use the goods in circumstances for a minimum period.

The Bill will also require goods generally to be used for more than 50 per cent in exempt circumstances in order for exemption to apply. Other goods will be exempt if they are for use exclusively in a stipulated way. Some goods will be exempt if they are for use to a sufficient extent in a specified way.There will be a further requirement that, apart from leases, the person who claims the benefit of an exemption will be the person who will have to actually use the goods in the exempt way.

Another change which will make the application of the sales tax laws more certain is the use of standard terminology. In the existing law, different terms with similar or overlapping meanings are used to describe similar concepts. In the new law, in keeping with the policy of plain English drafting, key concepts which recur in descriptions of goods will be expressed in uniform or standard terminology each time those particular concepts are referred to.

Although the scope of existing exemptions and classifications will be preserved as nearly as possible, the adoption of standard terminology will result in some small changes to some items. These changes are explained in detail in the explanatory memorandum circulated with this Bill. In the course of reviewing the existing law some obsolete items have been identified and these have been omitted.
The new law will make a number of changes to the classification of goods as a result of the simplification review. Some goods which are taxable will now become exempt. These are:

SPEECH.PARA: .natural mineral water
.pallets for transporting or storing goods
.gases
.works of art.
Some goods which are presently exempt will become taxable. These include:
.plastic and rubber sheeting
.switch lamp holders
.some sensors and thermostats
.pet food for dog and cat breeders.
In addition, exemptions have been drafted in simpler language. The structure of the exemption schedules has been altered so that similar kinds of goods will be grouped together and easier to find.

PARA.TAB: Finally, there will be some adjustments to the scope of the exemptions for goods for use in business or industry. One of the main changes will be in the presentation of the exemptions. There will now be separate references to each industry or activity covered by the business inputs provisions although the structure of the exemption for each industry will be similar. This will overcome many of the inconsistencies in the existing treatment of different industries. Much of the complexity and duplication within the existing exemptions for `eligible business goods' and `aids to manufacture' will be removed.

The last point which should be noted is that some exemptions for business inputs will be available only for registered persons. This will be done to encourage regular users of these exemptions to register and quote a number which is a simpler system than quoting an exemption declaration.

An explanatory memorandum containing detailed information on this Bill is being made available to honourable members and further details on the changes made by the Bill will be found in that document. I commend the Bill to the House.
