Bill presented by Mr Baldwin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

A major element of the Government's reform agenda since taking office has been the comprehensive reform of the Australian taxation system. When this Government took office in 1983, there was a widespread view that the Australian income tax system operated unfairly. In 1985 the Government introduced major business and personal tax reforms which addressed a large number of longstanding flaws in the tax system. The Government has continued to build on these reforms with the objective of making the tax system fairer and more efficient. The 1988 business tax reforms further encouraged economic efficiency. Since 1985, the Government has developed a comprehensive system for taxing foreign source income and there has also been reform in such areas as superannuation and depreciation.

Unquestionably, the tax system is now one of the fairest and most secure in the world; however, reform does not end there. The Government is committed to ensuring that the Australian tax system continues to meet the community's expectation of fairness, certainty and efficiency at the highest possible level.

In the context of the study of options for simplifying the income tax system, announced on 15 February 1990, the Government decided on a major overhaul of the present self-assessment system of taxation. Australia has had a self-assessment system of taxation since 1986. This Bill will provide real benefits for taxpayers by making the system fairer and more certain.
This Bill implements the Government's decision, announced in the Treasurer's statements of 13 December 1990 and with the 1991-92 Budget, to improve existing self-assessment arrangements.
The Bill proposes changes to the law to:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)introduce a new system of binding public rulings applicable to income tax, withholding taxes, franking deficit tax, Medicare levy and fringe benefits tax;

(b)introduce a new system of binding private rulings for completed or proposed transactions or arrangements. The new system will apply to rulings dealing with income tax, withholding taxes, franking deficit tax, Medicare levy and fringe benefits tax;

(c)introduce a new system of reviewable private rulings which will allow taxpayers to have unfavourable private rulings reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, AAT, or court—subject to there being no assessment which covers the matter dealt with by the ruling;
(d)limit objection rights against an assessment to avoid duplication by preventing a further review of a matter that is the subject of an objection against a private ruling;
(e)extend the period within which a taxpayer can object against an assessment from 60 days to four years, and provide a similar objection period for private rulings;
(f)allow the Commissioner of Taxation to rely on statements made by the taxpayer in a request for an amendment;

(g)introduce a new system of penalties for understatements of income tax liability. The penalties will be based on the requirement that taxpayers exercise reasonable care in carrying out their tax obligations. A more rigorous standard, the reasonably arguable position test, will apply to items which affect tax by more than $10 000;
(h)introduce a new interest system for underpayments or late payments of income tax, based on commercial principles and market interest rates;

(i)reduce late payment penalties to take into account the new interest system. This will allow for the separation of interest and penalties while providing an incentive for taxpayers to pay income tax on time;
(j)provide deductibility to all taxpayers for interest payments made to the Australian Taxation Office, ATO; and
(k)remove, in most cases, the requirement for taxpayers to lodge notices of elections or other notifications with the Commissioner.

PARA.TAB: In determining the final form of the changes the Government, through the ATO, has consulted extensively with taxpayer and tax professional representative bodies. In responding to concerns expressed about current self-assessment arrangements by these representative bodies, the Government released the consultative document A Full Self Assessment System of Taxation as part of the Treasurer's tax simplification statement of 13 December 1990.

Following careful consideration of the submissions and extensive consultation with interested parties, the Government summarised the broad features of the proposed measures in the August 1991 information paper Improvements to Self-Assessment—Priority Tasks. The Government again showed its commitment to a consultative process by agreeing to continue consultation on the technical details. The Bill represents the outcome of that process. The measures contained in the Bill will apply from the later of the date of royal assent or 1 July 1992. I now turn to a more detailed discussion of the measures.

Taxpayers who are genuinely uncertain about the tax effect of a completed or proposed arrangement will be able to seek a private ruling from the Commissioner. The Commissioner will be bound by the ruling to the extent that the tax that would be payable by the taxpayer will be reduced to reflect the tax that would be payable under the ruling. The Commissioner will continue to issue public rulings. These will be binding in the same way as private rulings will be binding on the Commissioner.

The Commissioner will only be able to withdraw the benefit of a ruling on arrangements that have not yet been entered into, except where it would be grossly inequitable to allow a taxpayer to continue to benefit from an incorrect ruling.

A taxpayer will be able to have an unfavourable private ruling, even on a proposed arrangement, reviewed by the AAT or courts. When the review process is finalised, the decision of the AAT or court will be legally binding and conclusive as to the application of the ordinary provisions of the legislation to an actual arrangement not relevantly different from the proposal or arrangement to which the private ruling related.
Taxpayers will be able to object against a private ruling within the later of 60 days after receipt of the ruling; or four years from the due date for the lodgment of the relevant return.

The new system of binding and reviewable rulings will promote certainty for taxpayers, and thereby reduce their risks and opportunity costs. The new system will also be fairer because taxpayers will be able to object to private rulings and have the matter reviewed by an independent tribunal or court.

The Bill extends the period within which a taxpayer can object against an assessment from 60 days to four years and, as I mentioned above, provides a similar objection period for private rulings. The four-year objection period corresponds with the Commissioner's power of amendment. These changes represent enhanced rights of objection and appeal for taxpayers.

Taxpayers will have full rights of review either against the private ruling, where there is no assessment, or against the assessment, except to the extent that the taxpayer has already objected against a matter in respect of a private ruling. By allowing taxpayers to object to private rulings, the Bill provides the opportunity to bring forward in time the resolution of matters in dispute.

The Commissioner will be able to rely on statements made by the taxpayer in a request for an amendment in amending the taxpayer's assessment in the same way as the Commissioner can now rely on statements made by the taxpayer in a return when making an assessment. However, the Commissioner may decide not to accept statements in the request for amendment or made elsewhere and, for example, make inquiries as to whether the amendment is necessary. The Commissioner is obliged to amend the taxpayer's assessment where the Commissioner is satisfied that the amendment is necessary to reflect the correct tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Where a taxpayer self-amends, the Commissioner will have four years to review the item amended.

PARA.TAB: These changes will provide opportunities for efficiency gains in the administration of the income tax law by reducing duplication of work where it does not add value.
The key features of the new penalty provisions are:

SPEECH.PARA: .all taxpayers will be required to exercise reasonable care in conducting their tax affairs. Failure to exercise reasonable care will attract a penalty of 25 per cent of a tax shortfall or franking tax shortfall caused by the failure;

.taxpayers with large claims—generally $10,000 tax or more—will, in addition, be required to ensure that the positions they adopt are reasonably arguable. Failure to have a reasonably arguable position will attract a penalty of 25 per cent of a tax shortfall or franking tax shortfall caused by the failure;

.a taxpayer who has received a private ruling from the Commissioner on a matter but does not follow the ruling when preparing the return will also be liable to pay a penalty of 25 per cent of a tax shortfall or franking tax shortfall caused by not following the ruling;

.taxpayers who behave recklessly with regard to their tax affairs, or who set out to deliberately evade tax, will also be penalised—at 50 per cent and 75 per cent respectively—in respect of any tax shortfall or franking tax shortfall caused by their behaviour;

.taxpayers who enter into arrangements for the sole or dominant purpose of avoiding tax will be liable to pay penalty of 50 per cent of a tax shortfall caused by the arrangement, reduced to 25 per cent if the position taken by the taxpayer is reasonably arguable. This will be so, irrespective of the provision of the Income Tax Assessment Act used by the Commissioner to defeat the arrangement;

.understatement penalties may be increased by 20 per cent of the penalty if there are aggravating circumstances, for example, a taxpayer hinders the Commissioner's inquiries, or decreased by 20 per cent of the penalty if the taxpayer discloses a tax shortfall or scheme to the Commissioner during an audit;
.taxpayers who voluntarily disclose a tax shortfall or scheme to the Commissioner before the Commissioner inquires into the taxpayer's affairs will have the penalty reduced by 80 per cent;
.understatement penalties will be subject to the Commissioner's discretion to remit the penalty in whole or in part;
.understatement penalties will be subject to full review rights.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Reasonable Care and Reasonably Arguable Position

PARA.TAB: The whole idea of the new understatement penalties is to ensure that people do not get penalised when they have made an honest and genuine attempt to correctly determine their taxable income. The Bill replaces the existing system where penalty is automatically attracted at the rate of 200 per cent and remitted at the discretion of the Commissioner. In so doing, it reduces the risk of penalties for taxpayers, provided taxpayers adhere to the standards of reasonable care and, where appropriate, reasonably arguable position.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasonable care standard requires a taxpayer to exercise the care that an ordinary person would be likely to have exercised in the circumstances of the taxpayer. Reasonable care requires taxpayers to make a reasonable attempt to comply with their tax obligations. The effort required is commensurate with all the taxpayer's circumstances, including the taxpayer's knowledge, education and skill.

The Government has opted to favour equity in this area by choosing a standard which has regard to the taxpayer's circumstances. However, following experience in the United States, the Government considers it appropriate that a more rigorous standard apply where the item at issue is very large, for example, generally more than $10,000 in tax. Where the interpretation of the law for such large items is in issue, we expect taxpayers to exercise more care; that is, the taxpayer must have a reasonably arguable position on the matter.

The reasonably arguable position standard will, because of the $10,000 threshold, apply only to relatively few taxpayers. The crux of the standard is that taxpayers should not take positions at law which, at the time taken, are not about as arguable as an alternative position. All said and done, the standard is about analysing the law and its application to the facts. If there is a strong argument to support the taxpayer's position, that may be enough. However, the Government does not want taxpayers to take positions which are not defensible or which do not have reasonable prospects of success.

PARA.TAB: Where a taxpayer perceives a serious risk that the taxpayer's preferred position may not be reasonably arguable, the taxpayer is able to seek a private ruling from the Commissioner.

While the Bill provides a set of rules and accompanying penalties, there may be cases that will not fit neatly into a category of behaviour, or for which the prescribed rates of penalty are inappropriate. For this reason, and as a result of the consultative process, the discretion which the Commissioner has to remit penalties is not removed by this Bill. The Commissioner will retain the flexibility to provide concessional treatment where it would be fair and reasonable to do so.

As a result of the consultative process, the Government agreed in the August 1991 information paper to put on hold the proposal in the December 1990 consultative document that there should be tax agent penalties. A review is in course to determine, amongst other things, whether tax agent penalties or some other form of regulation of tax agents is appropriate and, if so, the level of those penalties or the form of regulation.

Pending the outcome of that review, and as an interim measure to protect the revenue, the Bill maintains the current position that a taxpayer is liable to penalties for understatements of tax caused by the negligent or delinquent behaviour of the tax agent in dealing with the taxpayer's affairs. However, a taxpayer who is liable to penalty in these circumstances is able to sue the tax agent to recover both penalty and interest.

The penalty for late payment is to be reduced from the current 20 per cent per annum to 8 per cent per annum, but will be complemented by the new interest system. The reduced late payment penalty, together with the new interest system, should ensure that the revenue is not used as a financing vehicle. It also provides an effective reduction in the level of late payment penalties for most taxpayers.

By reducing the penalty and introducing the new interest system, the Bill will allow for the separation of penalties and interest so that they can be applied separately as appropriate to the circumstances of each case. It also allows for a more commercial approach to be applied to the payment of tax.
This penalty does not apply to debit amendments other than late payment of the increase in tax. Like other penalties, the Commissioner will have the power to remit the penalty in whole or in part.

The Bill will provide for interest to be paid by taxpayers in relation to the underpayment of tax, including debit amendments and the late payment of tax. Interest will apply irrespective of whether a taxpayer is subject to understatement penalties. The basis of the interest system is to compensate the revenue for the time value of money for the period in which it is denied the use of funds.

To reflect a more commercial approach to the payment of tax, the statutory interest rate is based on market rates. The rate of interest payable by taxpayers will be set by reference to the weighted average yield for the 13-week Treasury note tenders plus 4 per cent. The extra 4 per cent reflects administrative costs and the fact that most taxpayers would not be able to borrow at the 13-week Treasury note rate.

Given that interest is meant to compensate the revenue for the time value of money, the rate at which interest is to be paid by taxpayers will be varied periodically to reflect interest rate movements in the market.
The Commissioner will have the power to remit interest.

In effect, interest at the 13-week Treasury note rate plus the 4 per cent would make most taxpayers indifferent to borrowing from a bank to pay tax or being liable to the interest at that rate. The late payment penalty encourages taxpayers to pay tax on time.

As a result of the consultative process, and to make the system fairer, interest paid by taxpayers to the ATO will be tax deductible. This will remove the present lack of symmetry in the tax treatment of interest paid by taxpayers to the ATO and interest paid by the ATO to taxpayers.

Interest on funds borrowed to pay tax are deductible for certain categories of business taxpayers, but not for other taxpayers. To benefit those taxpayers who are not entitled to a deduction for interest on funds borrowed to pay tax, the Government is considering amendment of the law to exempt from tax interest paid by the ATO on overpayments of tax to such taxpayers, with the prospect of changes being introduced after the Budget.

It is estimated that the new interest system, including reduced late payment penalties and deductibility for interest payments made by taxpayers to the ATO, will cost the revenue $20m in 1993-94 and $64m in 1994-95 and subsequent years, based on existing late payment penalty and statutory interest rates. However, the actual cost to the revenue in any year will depend on the interest rates prevailing in the particular period. These costs could be higher or lower depending on whether interest rates are higher or lower than current market rates.

In most cases, taxpayers will no longer be required to prepare and lodge written notices of elections. However, the taxpayer's records will need to reflect the decisions taken in calculating the taxable income.
The August 1991 information paper foreshadowed other amendments to the taxation laws. These amendments are not yet finalised and will be included in a separate Bill to be introduced later this year.

The Government believes these measures to be genuine tax reform which will improve the current self-assessment system of taxation. I present the explanatory memorandum, which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the motion which effectively brings into place the guillotine. There will be a subsequent motion to this that will declare the Bills urgent and after that a motion allotting time. As is almost invariably the case at this time of the year, this is necessary because of the impact upon Government business of the Senate declaration that by the end of this week no further materials will be considered by it. I think there is one Bill which is outside that consideration, but basically that is the position that has been put upon us. The Senate has been placing this restriction on us since 1987, really, and since that time there has been quite a dramatic increase in the numbers of Bills guillotined in this way.

PARA.TAB: Very briefly I want to say, because I think it is reasonably within order in this debate, how much I regret the fact that my opposite number who abuses me on these occasions is no longer the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife). He is an ornament to this Parliament. He is one of those individuals oppositions ought not deliberately try to lose at any point of time; that is, an experienced person in government. Even though he never had a kind word to say to me in these circumstances, I think he was a very effective representative of the Opposition in that shadow portfolio.

Nevertheless I am delighted to see that he has been replaced by the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), with whom I have had experience in the past in other portfolios. I know he will have an interest in facilitating the proceedings of the House.

This motion is also made necessary by the changed sitting patterns that we have these days. We no longer sit three weeks on and one week off; we have two weeks on and two off. Whilst technically speaking the same numbers of hours are available to the Government, the reality is that that is not the case. We do not have the opportunities to operate late into the evening on nine separate occasions, as opposed to seven, that that situation provided and, of course, the Government has been much more generous with private members' time. All these Bills are matters of great moment to this nation. They must get through this session and they must get to the Senate on a timetable which the Senate finds acceptable.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Opposition Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I firstly make reference to the remarks the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) made about my colleague the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), who is not in the chamber. We are all saddened to see that he is not here, but his service is not lost to us. One of the things he said to me when I took on this job was to make sure, when the guillotine comes up, that I tell them what I really think.

PARA.TAB: Whilst we have had to repeat this speech over a considerable period of time, the intensity with which we deliver it has not been diminished by the number of times we have had to deliver it. I cannot hear the interjections, but I am sure that if the honourable member seeks leave of the Chair to speak at a later time probably he will be given that indulgence and I will have the chance to answer him then.

The Leader of the House knows that the question of the guillotine is not so much a matter of saying, `It is regrettable that we have to come forward again' and, `It is all the fault of the Senate' and, `These matters have to be dealt with', as indeed they do. But it really comes down to a matter of management of the business of the House. Indeed, it is a broader issue than just the management of the House. It is really a management of the Cabinet. Part of the problem is, of course, that the legislation—there have been several years now of this position arising—needs to go through the legislative committees of Cabinet at a far speedier pace in order that it may be brought to this place so that honourable members on both sides of the chamber may have the opportunity to debate it at length.

We are going to sit until after midnight for three nights this week, and that is not acceptable. We are also going to be guillotined or gagged, and a number of honourable members who might want to speak on these Bills will not be able to do so. Last November we saw 37 Bills in four days subjected to the urgency motion. Today there are over 17. Later in the week, I understand, there will be even more, with the momentous tax changes that the Government is proposing. We must be concerned about the short-circuiting of the legislative process that this motion envisages.

Some time ago the Leader of the House provided some figures to my colleague the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr). I have been looking at these figures, and they will be instructive for the House. From 1976 to 1982 there were only 17 Bills declared urgent. During the period this Government has been in office, from 1983 to the end of 1991, there have been 401 Bills declared urgent. The Leader of the House has already put forward some reasons for that, but that does not explain it completely.

In the period of the predecessor to the present Leader of the House, we see that not nearly so many Bills were declared urgent as there have been under the current stewardship. The number has increased, and 1991 was the winning year for the number of Bills declared urgent and forced through this place. The curve goes ever upwards under the present Leader of the House who, because of the way he forces legislation through, would have to be described as the axeman of the Parliament.

All of us know the pressures that are upon the Parliament, but there is nothing more precious in this country than having the opportunity to deal in some detail with complex legislation. On the list of Bills before us today we see that a number of them are extremely important in terms of export opportunities for this country. Coal, wool and dairying feature quite prominently, together with some transport and communications legislation. Here we have three specific major items of export earning that are very important for this country, and very important for the producers in those industries. The lack of opportunity, particularly for honourable members on this side of the House, to discuss in detail the impacts of the dairy industry changes and the impacts of changes on the coal mining industry—one of our largest exporters—is deplorable. Putting all the primary industry Bills together and having them driven through this House delivers a broader message. Part of the message is that the Government does not want the Opposition to detail the failure of the Government's policies as they relate to these areas.

There is a management process breakdown. We are seeing the Parliament used as a cipher. We are seeing it used for the benefit of the Executive rather than for the benefit for which it was established, and that is to be a debating forum in which both sides of the Parliament are given an opportunity to explore in depth particular issues as they relate to major pieces of legislation. The Leader of the House himself just said that these were major pieces of legislation.

But it is the trend that ought to be concerning all of my colleagues. In 1991, 101 Bills were declared urgent and the guillotine was applied, and we are going to see it happen again later this week. It ought to give us all cause for some concern. It is not something that ought to be an enduring feature of this Parliament. Regardless of which side of the chamber we sit on, we cannot take pride in this process. We are denying the people we represent the opportunity to have their views expressed. That is why the parliamentary process was established. Surely it is time for the Leader of the House—whoever that person might be—to take hold of this issue and to look at changes, which are obviously extremely necessary. The Opposition opposes the use of the guillotine each time it is proposed, and we will do so again this evening, because it ought to be opposed. We stand for the broader principle of detailed, open and lengthy debate. We do not wish to see these matters pass through the House in the way proposed.

Late last night, after having read the Standing Orders for the fourth time in one day, I was reading an article in Time magazine. The front cover of the magazine tells a story. It talks about Labor's identity crisis. The feature article makes the point that the Labor Party is not as relevant as it was to the people who have traditionally supported it. When we ask why we are having these important Bills rushed through the House, and why debate is being denied, we have to understand the broader political objective that is being pursued here.

The Labor Party recognises that it is becoming increasingly irrelevant to the broad population. In trying to ensure that Bills that have a major impact on the rural community are not subject to major debate, the Government has come up with the solution to gag this chamber and to stop democracy working. It is grappling with its own identity crisis and the uncertainty of how to deal with it, and the ills of the policies that it is visiting upon the Australian community. It is all part of the overall Labor Party political dilemma. I think that in part explains why we are seeing more and more abuses of the normal forms of the House.

I make an appeal, and perhaps pose a challenge to the Leader of the House: even he must admit that the procedures which he and the Cabinet are following are denying honourable members—including those on the Government side—the opportunity to discuss these weighty matters. The Government has political problems. We hope they continue. Ultimately they will be the cause of its demise. But each and every one of us in this place does have an obligation to ensure that the Standing Orders—imperfect though they be in many ways—are not used and abused in a way that is going to deny the fundamental right, regardless of which party we represent, that each and every one of us ought to be able to pursue in this place, and that is to have open and reasonable debate. This motion by its very nature denies that. That is why the Opposition yet again will be opposing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) in opposing the guillotine motion that has been moved by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) here today. The Leader of the House is getting very good at and very used to moving this motion. He has been doing it regularly since he became the Leader of the House—far more so than any former Leader of the House in the history of the House of Representatives. The honourable member for Bass has highlighted the number of times this Government has introduced the guillotine, and compared it to the previous coalition Government. It is also worth going back a little bit further in history and discovering that only once during the Menzies years of government did the number of times the guillotine was imposed exceed double figures. Indeed, only once was it used during the post-Menzies years prior to the Whitlam Government coming into power.

PARA.TAB: So up until more recent years the guillotine has been a very rare and unusual event in this Parliament. But increasingly under this Government we have seen it become the order of the day. It tells us a story that the Leader of the House tries to fudge. He blames all the problems that have led to the introduction of the guillotine on the Senate, and on the requirement that the House of Representatives conclude its business for the consideration of the Senate some time in advance of the Senate's rising.

However, he is not really telling the full story there. As we all know, the mismanagement of the affairs of the House of Representatives is the principal reason why the guillotine is applied so frequently today. This mismanagement has extended beyond just the affairs of the House of Representatives to the affairs of the nation. It is for that reason that we have such things as one million unemployed persons in Australia today, that we have such disastrous levels of business investment, that the economy is not growing and that rural communities are as badly off as they are today.

It is the mismanagement of the Government, which is reflected in the state of the Australian economy and in our society, which permeates its way right through the system, even into the management of the House of Representatives. This Government—formerly the Hawke-Keating Government and, in the last six months, the Keating Government—has no respect for the norms of our Parliament or the institutions of our society. The Parliament is the most important institution in our society today. It is the symbol of our democracy. It is the thing that people look towards for good and proper government and for fairness. Unfortunately, it would appear from the way this Government tries to deny people the opportunity of free speech that those people can be disappointed as to the level of democracy they are getting from this Government.

The guillotine motion that has been moved this evening denies members of the House of Representatives their right to speak on issues that they believe to be important to them and to their constituents. It means that the institution of the Parliament, the symbol of our democracy, the thing that guides our country, is being broken up by this Government. It is, of course, not just that institution of the Parliament that this Government is trying to erode; it is so many other institutions—the flag, the Queen or any other important symbol—in our nation.

The only institutions that these people in the Labor Government believe are important are the institutions of mateship and factions. It is that mateship and those factions which are leading to so many of Australia's problems. We have seen in the last few weeks Senator Richardson being forced to resign over his mateship arrangements with so many others. I am sure we will see more of that type of thing over the weeks and months to come.

With the introduction of the guillotine into the House, we see the sort of hypocrisy that we have become used to. When the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) became Prime Minister we heard him tell us he was going to give us a better standard and that he himself was going to improve his own personal performance. We heard Mr Hawke tell us after the 1990 election that he was going to improve the standards of the Parliament. What have we seen? We have seen the standards of the Parliament further eroded by the actions of this Government, be it in the introduction of the guillotine or even throughout Question Time.

In Question Time we continually see the erosion of the parliamentary democracy that we believe to be important. Today in Question Time we have five or six questions, if we are lucky, asked on behalf of the Opposition. In times gone past, when I first came into the House, it was not unusual for the Opposition to ask nine or 10 questions during Question Time. Those nine or 10 questions were dealt with in 45 minutes. The five or six—or at the very best, seven—questions that the Opposition can ask during a Question Time today take up to an hour and a quarter for the Government to answer. There is no doubt at all that Question Time is being eroded and that the standards of the Parliament during Question Time are being made a farce because of the way this Government treats the institution of our Parliament.

It is all symbolised by the way this Government runs Question Time and by the way it brings into the House these dozens of Bills which will be debated in a short space of time, denying honourable members—elected representatives of the people—the opportunity to speak on those issues which are important to them. It is for that reason that I am pleased that the Opposition will oppose, as it has for so long now, the guillotine motion that has been moved by the Leader of the House.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Beazley's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES AND NORTHERN TERRITORY GRANTS (RURAL ADJUSTMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Mr Crean:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Amendment Bill 1992 gives effect to changes that have already been made to the rural adjustment scheme, the RAS as it is commonly known, through an agreement between the Commonwealth and the States. Under section 27 of the Act these amendments can be introduced prior to an amendment of legislation to allow much faster assistance for farmers who are in dire financial straits.

PARA.TAB: The assistance is certainly desperately needed but, unfortunately, still desperately inadequate. The rural adjustment scheme has become increasingly necessary under the Federal Labor Government due to a string of failed, and failing, Labor Party policies. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) induced this recession that we had to have by propping up the Australian dollar, promoting high interest rates such as this country has never seen before and failing to implement a comprehensive tax and economic reform package.

The Labor Government has failed in its waterfront reform; it has failed to implement effective anti-dumping legislation; and it has failed to instigate an industrial relations policy that promotes reward, incentive and productivity. The result is a depression in the bush, unprecedented since the Great Depression of the 1930s.

I am very pleased to see the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) in the House tonight. He is issuing press releases saying that the Government is spending more money—and in the next 12 months, over the full year, more than $60m of new money will be spent on rural assistance. That money is certainly welcome, but I think it begs the question: why is the provision of such amounts necessary? It is necessary because of the failings of nine years of Labor government.

We live on the driest continent on earth, yet this Government has failed to recognise that droughts occur in Australia. Mention of drought or severe drought has been removed from the national disaster relief legislation. On the one hand the Government recognises cyclones, floods and earthquakes under this legislation but does not recognise drought or even severe drought. I have to ask the Minister why. On the other hand, we on this side of the House can, and do, recognise extreme drought as a phenomenon, as something that Australia does go through and will continue to go through because it is one of the consequences of living on the driest continent on earth. We will ensure that under the national disaster relief legislation droughts will be recognised.

The rural adjustment scheme has become an elastic bandaid, a means by which the Government can hide its successive failures. Unfortunately, the bandaid has now fouled and the rural adjustment scheme really is in need of major surgery if it is to address the problems that will confront agriculture in the next five to 10 years. We do not need another bandaid added to the already overburdened rural adjustment scheme which is trying to cope with the problems in rural Australia.

Testament to the failure of the rural adjustment scheme is the fact that of the $10m set aside this financial year to assist farmers to gain the unemployment benefit through modification of the Job Search allowance, only $200,000 has been expended at this stage. This Government cannot even spend the allocated amount of money on a very specific targeted assistance project. Why not? Farmers in my electorate and across many electorates, including those of honourable members on the other side of the House, are also asking why not. I say it is because of poor policy making and lack of thought.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, who is in the House tonight, promised, alongside the now fallen Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Richardson, on 29 October last year that 2,000 desperate farmers would receive assistance through the Government's reformed Job Search allowance. As a matter of interest, I think the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy may have made that statement in Toowoomba, just on the edge of my electorate—probably one of the worst drought areas last year. That region suffered one of the worst droughts seen since records have been kept. At the end of April the number of farmers who were granted Job Search under the modified assets test arrangements totalled 101. Honourable members will remember that in October last year 2,000 farmers were going to receive this targeted assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many applied?

—After considering the criteria for eligibility the question is not why so few farmers took up the offer but why so many farmers did not meet such unrealistic and unbelievable requirements. Let me explain it to the Minister. The Job Search allowance does need modification—I think the Minister may be the first to agree—if this targeted assistance is to work and be directed to those very deserving farmers in desperate straits right now.

PARA.TAB: The rural adjustment scheme is broken down into three components: part A, the interest subsidy component, part B, carry-on finance; and part C, household support and money to adjust out of farming. In order to be eligible for the Government's so-called farmer dole, the applicant must have no further borrowing capacity and must be considered viable in the long term. I am not sure how a farmer would meet both those criteria. If a farmer is to be viable in the long term, he or she is ineligible for the interest subsidy and forfeits any chance of accessing the unemployment benefit. Who, then, qualifies for the amended Job Search allowance? All available evidence suggests the benefit will be granted only in quite exceptional circumstances. I believe the fact that 101 farmers are receiving this assistance is testimony to that assertion.

Let us suppose for a moment that the Government's amended Job Search allowance did assist 2,000 farmers instead of the paltry 101 farmers who are receiving it now. Less than 4 per cent of farmers qualify for the unemployment benefit in the worst year on record for farm incomes and in the worst drought in many parts of the country since records have been kept. It is not hard to deduce from such figures that the Government's assistance program has failed completely. It has failed so many desperate farmers. I certainly have many of those in my electorate. I am sure that the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls), who has just come into the House, would understand what I am talking about because he would also have many farmers in desperate need for some income support at this very time.

I put this failure down to the complete misunderstanding—perhaps ignorance—of this Labor Government. It does not understand the Australian farm sector, and I believe it does not want to understand it. If it did, this problem would have been addressed prior to Christmas last year. Had those in government listened to this side of the House and taken on board our proposals, this situation could have been averted.

The average Australian farmer is 57 years of age or, if we look at some other studies, 54 years of age. The Government's revised Job Search allowance takes no account of those farmers over the age of 65 years. Because they are of retirement age, they are deemed ineligible for the unemployment benefit. This is an example of how inappropriate it is to extend assistance to financially destitute farmers through the Job Search allowance.

I can assure the Minister and the honourable member for Kennedy that many such farmers over the age of 65 are actively working their farms today. They are not thinking of retirement—they cannot afford to retire. They are desperate to hang onto their lifetime's work. They are also desperate to hang onto the family home. If they are forced off the land they will lose not only their lifetime's work, but also the family home and a roof over their head. To that group of farmers aged over 65 the Government is saying, `Tough luck, you are on the scrap heap. You cannot access the Job Search allowance or farmer dole schemes'.

Amendments within this Bill also provide special assistance for crop planting. This assistance has been made available since March this year under part B of the scheme. This assistance is in the form of a 75 per cent interest subsidy on growers' commercial crop planting loans. When I first heard about it I thought—as did many farmers in my electorate—that this would be of some genuine help. It is certainly long overdue. Under the terms of the agreement with the States, farmers must be profitable in the long term but unable to obtain sufficient commercial carry-on finance to undertake normal cropping programs.

The figures to date show that only 160 out of an estimated 40,000 cereal and grain farmers across Australia have applied for the subsidies to help with winter wheat plantings due to the stringent requirements. I think many of them have been through the process already. They have been in to see their bankers and the rural adjustment authorities. I believe that, in many cases, even the rural adjustment authorities are saying, `Look, you are really better off going in and dealing with your bank. There is so much red tape I don't think you are going to qualify. You are really wasting your time and effort and that of your accountants in putting these figures together'.

The figures confirm what we are saying about this scheme. Out of 160 applications, 67 have been approved, 29 have been rejected, and 64 are still pending. In fact, the Prime Minister's disregard for the problems forced on the rural sector was illustrated in his February economic statement. It is interesting to note the amount of money that was allocated for this scheme in the Prime Minister's One Nation statement. I must say that if it were reasonably accessible to farmers it would be a tremendous help to them. But the unfortunate facts are—and this is supported by the figures—that farmers are not able to access that money because of the stringent requirements.

I get back to this point: the Prime Minister's statement in February allocated almost twice as much money to Western Australian sewage treatment than to the crop planting assistance program this year—$20m for a sewage treatment program in Western Australia and $10m this year and $6m next year to the crop planting scheme.

We are talking about an export industry which has the capacity to generate $2 billion to $3 billion worth of export income and create countless jobs right across Australia—not just on the farms, but on the wharves where the wheat is loaded, the railways which cart the wheat into the ports and for the truck drivers who bring it in from the farms. It is a great creator of jobs, yet so little of this assistance is flowing to the wheat and cereal growers of Australia.

The coalition's message is quite clear: in times of financial crisis welfare payments cannot be extended to farming communities through unemployment benefits. Generally, the farmer and his spouse are actively employed on the property from daybreak to dusk, regardless of whether they receive any income. It is, therefore, not practical to offer the Job Search allowance as a means of assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —How come 4,200 are receiving it?
—I am sure that the Minister will have his chance to speak.
—I will not. You've cut me out of time.
—The Minister has plenty of opportunities. With dorothy dixers from the back bench—
—Whose fault is it that we are guillotined?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Order! If the Minister is cut out of time, it is the Minister's responsibility, not that of the honourable member who is on his feet. I suggest that the honourable member be allowed to make his speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that if the Minister wanted extra time he would be able to get it. All he would have to do is go to see the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) and I am sure he would be able to extend the time if the Minister is genuine in wanting to get up and address the problems of rural adjustment.
—But we are under the Government's guillotine.
—Yes. This Government has allocated half an hour for the debate on this important matter of rural adjustment in Australia. The Minister should not tell me that I am cutting him out of time—
—I am just saying that you have got your facts wrong.
—The Minister will have his opportunity. He should make more time available—
—Why don't you answer the questions?
—Order! The Minister will stop interjecting. It is a limited time debate.

—The entire charade of Job Search allowance for farmers could have been avoided had the Government retained the 1977 coalition Government's decision to introduce household support as an income tested, but not work tested, welfare payment for a 12-month period, followed by a loan for a further 12 months. I am sure that answers the Minister's continued interjections.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, because of its ignorance or bias, the Labor Government changed the whole concept to household support. It has engaged in an active policy of eliminating farmers and accelerating the rate at which many of them will be forced to leave the land. This decision resulted in a complete lack of welfare provisions for farming couples who wished to remain on the land, in contrast with the situation in urban areas.

I think this is a terribly important point. Unemployment benefits are payable to a married couple in a city, no matter what the value of their residential property. On the other hand, a farming couple becomes ineligible for unemployment benefits once the value of their farm exceeds $157,500.

The need for fast track household support reform is therefore crucial if farming families are to keep food on the table and if the rural infrastructure is to survive this very desperate period. A coalition government would allow farmers to access the same benefits as every other Australian. The coalition recognises that there is a role for rural adjustment in Australia in order to assist the Australian agricultural sector in overcoming problems unique to it. We recognise the need for rural adjustment. There will probably always be a need for this rural adjustment.

The Labor Government has created the majority of problems which are facing the farming sector today. It has attempted to gloss over these by forcing onto the rural adjustment authorities problems which have their beginnings in the Labor Party Caucus room. However, it could not get even this right and it bungled an ideal opportunity to provide assistance to farmers who are in genuine need. I go back to the Minister's statement and that of the now departed Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Richardson, who said that 2,000 farmers would access this modified Job Search allowance.

There are lots of other problems that I think the Government must look at. It certainly must look at encouraging farmers to better manage their situations prior to drought, because one of the reasons why we have a rural adjustment scheme in place is that there is a lack of programs, programs which the coalition had in place to encourage farmers to put money aside in good times to see their way through the bad times and, more particularly, the droughts. In many cases the Government has taken such measures away. It is something that we must look at more closely and the Government must look at, because it obviously has the power of the treasury bench. We must look at assistance such as 100 per cent write-offs for grain and hay storage measures for drought mitigation.

I think that, if we can give tax incentives for land care, we should also be able to give the equivalent tax write-off to encourage people to put these facilities in place so that they can store their fodder, which will better enable them to get through the droughts. Income equalisation deposits are a very important part of drought management strategy. From a government point of view, income equalisation deposits today are not effective.

There is another aspect of this whole question of rural adjustment that I hope the Minister looks at. Rural adjustment really has been added onto, yet some of the problems that are still inherent out there in rural Australia are problems that rural adjustment cannot adequately cover. These include income equalisation deposits, the 100 per cent write-offs for drought mitigation measures for the storage of fodder, for increased water storage capacity and for the reticulation of water around farms to avoid many of the disasters that we have seen in the current drought.

In contrast to the Government, the coalition does know and does have the understanding of the rural sector. It can solve the great many problems facing rural Australia today. We would be in there restoring farm profitability through the implementation of a comprehensive tax reform and economic package the like of which this country has never seen. We would have an effective industrial relations policy which would give reward for effort, which every Australian wants. We would encourage people to work. The more people work and the harder they work, the more they will earn to take home to their families. We would do that rather than continue the restrictive work practices that Government members have encouraged and nurtured for years and years.

We would certainly fast track the anti-dumping legislation which the Government has in place, because dumping contributes to the corrupt world trade and pricing mechanisms. Part of the problem the agricultural sector is confronted with today is ineffective anti-dumping legislation. The problem with our anti-dumping legislation is that it takes too long to implement. If we compare Australia with other countries, we find that we are in the Third World country area when it comes to anti-dumping. I say to the Minister that our anti-dumping policy would put countervailing duties into place much faster on those people who want to cheat our system and access our markets. It certainly would still allow those people who want to play the game and have fair trade to access our markets to do so.

In conclusion, I do ask the Minister to look at the real problems confronting so many farming families right across Australia. We may have seen a return to some better prices in some commodities, but the problem that many farm families face today is one of walking off their farms with nothing to show for a lifetime's work. I believe it is up to each and every one of us in this House to look at how better to target the Job Search allowance and the whole rural adjustment scheme to assist those who are still in genuine need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hulls Mr R.J.

PARA.TAB: I must say that people in rural Australia are indeed sick and tired of hearing coalition members, particularly National Party members, telling farmers in rural Australia that they will look after them when they know full well that the coalition's Fightback package, with its blanket commitment to zero tariffs and a crippling 15 per cent goods and services tax, will devastate many if not most farmers. SPEECH.PARA: New provisions within the rural adjustment scheme of debt reconstruction and interest subsidies could be particularly helpful.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion—I understand the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) wants to respond in relation to this matter—it is fair to say that this Bill, which deals with the rural adjustment scheme, is proof of this Government's commitment to rural Australia. STATES GRANTS (TAFE ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1992
HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1992]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I understand it is the wish of the House to debate the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill concurrently with the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill. There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill are Bills from a Government which is comprehensively failing the young people of this country in providing education and job opportunities.

PARA.TAB: When one looks at the Government's record in this area, it is not at all difficult to understand why the Government is so keen to truncate debate in this vital area. After nine years of Labor in office, the young people of Australia are among the least skilled in the Western world. They are unemployed for longer at comparable stages of the business cycle than are their peers in other countries. More than one in three of them are unable to find work and perhaps as many as 200,000 who wish to upgrade their knowledge and skills at either university or TAFE are unable to gain a place at these institutions even though they are fully qualified to do so.

The Government justifies its performance in education and training by pointing to the increased retention rates in the post-compulsory years of schooling and the increased participation rates in tertiary education and training. There is no doubt that rates of retention and participation have increased.

There are two things to be said about this: the first is that the increasing commitment by Australians to education predates this Government and will continue after the Government's eviction from office at the next election. In many ways it is the tragic failure of the Government's economic policy, leading to unprecedented levels of unemployment, which has forced the most dramatic increase in retention and participation. In other respects increased rates reflect the operation of forces beyond the Government's control. Even so, they are still below international levels.

The second point is that throughout this period the Government has been concerned with quantity rather than quality. The level of community concern at the state of Australian education and training has risen to the point where education is now second only to unemployment as a problem area that the Federal Government is being called upon to address—and to address in very different ways from the policies that this Government has pursued.

I will address my remarks firstly to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill. This Bill seeks to put in place increased capital grants to non-government schools. The proposed increase of $15m is manifestly inadequate in terms of the needs of these schools. The National Catholic Education Commission, whose schools accommodate some 20 per cent of all enrolments, has estimated its capital requirements for projects already planned in the four years 1991 to 1995 at $635m.

The Government's commitment contrasts starkly with that of the coalition which, in its Fightback program, has committed itself to double capital grants for non-government schools, including an additional $81m in 1993-94 compared with an additional $8m in One Nation. The coalition's commitment has been welcomed by the National Catholic Education Commission, the National Council of Independent Schools Association and, indeed, most of those in the non-government sector.

The approach taken by Labor to the non-government school sector in the past nine years has been driven by political ideology which is unwaveringly hostile to the concept of non-government schools. Given that some 28 per cent of enrolments are in the non-government sector—that is, more than one-quarter of all families exercise their right to choose an alternative to government schooling for their children—the consequences of that ideology impact adversely on a sizeable proportion of the electorate. Ultimately, it is parents—and in the systemic schools parents and parishes—that must shoulder the extra burden.

There is a myth peddled by Labor that the non-government sector is somehow, to use the Government's preferred pejorative, elitist. There is ample evidence to show that children in the non-government sector come from families spanning the entire socioeconomic spectrum. In total, it is estimated that the operation of non-government schools reduces public outlays on education by some $1.6 billion annually. It is therefore easy to see what a drain there would be on the public purse—and a public purse already dangerously depleted and running into dangerously high deficits at present—if the students currently attending non-government schools were to attend government schools. There is a clear irrationality in current policies, such as the new schools policy, which aim to limit the right of parents to choose the school which reflects their values.

We in the coalition are unequivocal in our view that support for students attending non-government schools is a matter of basic equity and justice. The Commonwealth funding programs for non-government schools are a key expression of that view. Unless proper guarantees of support for non-government schools can be given in a rearrangement of Commonwealth-State relations, this program must remain a central element in any policy to ensure the reality of parental choice. We are also conscious of the role of the government school funding program in providing a balanced program of school support.

Non-government schools can prosper only when they have secure long term funding and a high degree of financial independence, including the right to work to improve the level of provision without penalty, the right to independence in the management of the school and the right to establish objectives and to give expression to a system of values and a curriculum attractive to those who choose the school from amongst those available. An environment which adequately supports these conditions does not exist in Australia today. Despite this, DEET projections indicate that the non-government sector is still expected to grow significantly faster than the government sector, showing the demand that exists from parents seeking schooling that reflects their values.

In the Fightback package, the coalition has provided a comprehensive plan for schooling in this country, government and non-government, which will resource schooling, government and non-government, at levels significantly above those levels currently planned or projected by the Labor Government. Central to that policy is the right of parents in both sectors to exercise choice in the school to which they send their child. In the non-government sector, in addition to the doubling of capital grants, there will be very significant increases in the per capita grants to students attending all categories of non-government schools.

There are signs that the Government is receiving advice to abandon its restrictive new schools policy. Will it heed the advice—for example, the criticism in the Hudson report; indeed, every report that the Government receives on education and training seems to strike at the heart of the Government's policy—or is the Government a prisoner of the restrictive political ideology which seeks to inhibit diversity and constrain choice?

This Government's record in the schools field does not withstand close scrutiny. It is a matter of public record that Commonwealth assistance for non-government school building projects has decreased steadily since Labor came to office. The annual total of Commonwealth capital grants has declined in real terms by 12 per cent during the life of this Government. When the grant is expressed in dollars per student in non-government schools the decrease is 29 per cent.

The shortfall in meeting the demand for capital funding is well illustrated by the experience of Catholic schools in 1990, which submitted 329 applications for assistance, with the funding of building projects seeking grants totalling $169m. The block grant authorities which administer the capital grants program were able to recommend to the Minister only 117 projects for total grants of $49m, that is, only 29 per cent. These demands come not from schools which draw their students from high income backgrounds but from schools whose overwhelming majority of students come from low income families—schools in the needs categories 10, 11 and 12 under current arrangements. I foreshadow at this point that at the end of my speech I will be moving a second reading amendment to this Bill in accordance with the terms now being circulated.

I turn now to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill, in which there is a furtherance of Labor's ideological theme to seek to curb diversity and impose control from the centre. It is here in higher education that this thinking has had perhaps its most disastrous, and certainly its most visible, consequences. Few people would pretend to argue that our higher education system in any respect resembles sound health.

Yesterday's report on higher education released by the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, Australian Universities in a Changing World, which was quoted at length in today's Australian Financial Review, reveals the depth of concern higher education has about threats to and attacks on its quality. The rigid ideological adherence to an over-regulated system and the funding arrangements which have been criticised as fundamentally flawed by the Industry Commission have as their own disgraceful monument the 50,000 qualified young Australians who are locked out not only of higher education but of opportunity because of this politically imposed rigidity. But will the Government be relaxing its regulatory approach? No, of course it will not; and, even worse, it promises more of the same.

Professor McKinnon, the President of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, has expressed his concern that the Government is about to intervene even further in trying to impose new commencement quotas forcing universities to allocate a specific quota of places to school leavers, mature age students and postgraduates. Of course, this is the quick fix at work again—a piece of politicking that sweeps aside any pretence of developing a workable and viable strategy for the development of higher education in favour of being seen to be getting more people into the universities in an election year.

This strikes at the very heart of the problem, because what we have in higher education now is an artificial shortage of places, created by political and bureaucratic regulation and interference. It will not be solved by more of the same. In fact, such an approach will only worsen the situation, create further distortions and place intolerable burdens on the already overstretched resources of the universities. It is abundantly clear that the Government's current arrangements, arrangements which underlie every aspect of this legislation, cannot adequately provide for the rational development of the system of university funding in Australia. Both the November statement and the One Nation statement comprehensively fail to address any of the structural impediments which have resulted in the unprecedented levels of unmet demand in Australia today.

The failure of the Government to provide adequate tertiary places, both at university and at TAFE, remains a serious obstacle to achieving and to increasing skill levels in the labour force, with probable consequences for unemployment in an internationally competitive environment. The OECD country study of Australia noted, as many have before it, that skill levels here are generally lower than in other industrialised countries and that Australia's backwardness in this area—a backwardness marked internationally and underlined by the OECD after nine years of Labor—may account for the longer duration of unemployment here compared with Canada and the United States.

This is no abstract statistical observation. It is cogent evidence that the people of Australia, and especially the young, are paying an unacceptably high price for the monumental failings of this Government. The Opposition will not oppose this Bill, but it is my intention to move a second reading amendment in the terms which are now being circulated. I shall move that amendment at the appropriate stage of the debate later this evening.

Finally, I will turn to the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill. This Bill is intended to appropriate funds for TAFE in accordance with the November statement on the economy and employment and to provide supplementation of grants for 1992. It is instructive to measure what the Government is saying about TAFE and training against what it is actually proposing, and therein, of course, lies a staggering mismatch. It is by now quite clear that the Government is struggling to achieve some finality in its policy on TAFE as a result of the unwillingness of the States to agree to the Government's proposals in One Nation to hand over the TAFE systems to the Commonwealth. The Government, of course, will deny that this is what it is proposing, but if people believe that 100 per cent Commonwealth funding means anything other than 100 per cent Commonwealth control over TAFE, they are only deceiving themselves.

When the Premiers last met they were not prepared to do what the Federal Government was suggesting, that is, hand over to the Commonwealth all the resources that they devote to TAFE in order to obtain the increment that the Government is proposing. They naturally questioned whether this was a very good deal from their point of view.

Just what the Government proposes as a fall-back option is yet to be revealed, but let me say at this point that the coalition has been explicit and up-front about its proposals. It has on the table as part of Fightback a comprehensive funded strategy to create an open and flexible training market. There is nothing conditional in our approach. We have accepted the targets for growth in TAFE as outlined in the Finn report, and we will in government work with and not against the States and Territories to ensure greater resourcing and greater freedom for TAFE institutions to respond to the needs of local industry and local communities.

Labor has left it very late in the day to discover TAFE. For far too long it has been the neglected child of education and training. The Government has been far too preoccupied with its vandalism of higher education to be concerned with TAFE. Again, this failing has impacted most heavily on young people, who now find themselves, if they have jobs, largely under-skilled in terms of international comparisons or in the dole queues at the Commonwealth Employment Service.

I refer again to the OECD, which in its economic survey recognised the deficiencies in the Government's approach. It cites insufficient skills or greater skill mismatches as a contributing factor to extended unemployment. Further, participation rates in post-compulsory education amongst 18- to 19-year-olds are lower in Australia than in the United Kingdom or New Zealand, and Australia generally lags behind comparable estimates in America and Europe.

Australia is lagging badly in education and training behind those countries which are now our international competitors. We are lagging both in the commitment to education measured by participation rates and in the quality of the education which is being offered. Even though participation rates have been on the rise, we are still well behind other comparable countries in the proportion of young people in formal education and training. For example, West Germany in 1987-88 had more than 65 per cent of 18- to 19-year-old males in education and training; the USA had 58 per cent; Japan, 50 per cent; Sweden, 43 per cent; and Australia, 30 per cent. It is no wonder that the OECD reports that much remains to be done to improve labour force skills in this country.

The Opposition will not oppose this Bill, but again I propose to move a second reading amendment, which is now being circulated. The Bills now before the House are from a Government which has manifestly and comprehensively failed to develop a strategy and a framework on which we as a nation can upgrade our education and our skills in a manner appropriate to an internationally competitive economy in the late twentieth century. In stark contrast to the coalition, the Government has failed to give education and training the priority that it requires. Within the Fightback program we have shown that it is possible to deliver the vast majority of the services and programs of the Commonwealth Government, much more efficiently, with better quality, at lower cost than is being done at present.

We believe that over the rest of this decade, however, there is scope for increased investment in education and training by the taxpayer and the private sector. We are able to reflect that priority because we have taken an attitude that government spending requires rigorous review and that there has to be a genuine effort to set proper priorities.

The Government stands condemned for its approach to education and training as a playground for experiments in social engineering; it has used it as a sacrificial lamb on the altar of the accord. It has left a mess in its wake. It decided that universities were elitist, so it wilfully dismantled the system of vocationally oriented colleges of advanced education and turned them into universities. It decided that non-government schools were elitist and sought to curb their expansion and growth at great cost to the public purse. It has neglected TAFE and allowed our skills base to decline to a standard perilously close to the Third World. As policy failures, they are as bad as they come. But it is the human cost that will remain as the monument to the Hawke-Keating years. A whole generation of young people who have been betrayed by Labor will not forget. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House deplores the failure of the Government to adopt an adequate policy for the development of the non-government school sector and, in particular, the House deplores the Government's:

PARA.TAB: (1)restrictive New Schools Policy;
(2)excessive accountability requirements;
(3)divisive recurrent funding policy; and
(4)failure to recognise the real capital needs of non-government schools".
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—I rise to speak in support of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992, the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992 and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1992. I found the discussion of the shadow Minister for education, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), quite extraordinary. He talked about the Government's achievements in education and derided them. We on this side of the House understand that.

PARA.TAB: Nobody understands it better than Queenslanders. I remind this House yet again that the majority of Queenslanders over 42 years of age have not enjoyed the benefits of a high school education, let alone a tertiary education. Opposition members may well ask why. It was due to 30 years of neglect by a government that believed that education was the hallmark for the privileged, that it was only for those who could pay. The other great attribute of that government was that it believed that education was not necessary for anybody, because people could rip off the system and make money; if they could rip off other people and get into government, they could stay there, and they did not need an education for that. Apart from that, if people were educated, they might actually question what that government was doing.

Tory members in this House have talked about education and decried the Government's role in education and the extension of the retention rates in our secondary schools and our universities. I remind members of the Opposition that in this Government's term of office, in but a decade, we have created an extra 17 universities with extra places. That is no small achievement. But the Opposition has to deride that. It has to deride our youth. We have heard it cite the most ridiculous unemployment figures as reasons for people staying on at school and going to university. Why should people not make a willing choice to stay on in the secondary school system and make a choice to go to university? `Oh no', the Opposition says, `Nobody would do that. They are forced into it by a whole load of factors'. That is a nonsense.

We see yet again tonight the stark contrast between the Government and the Opposition. We heard talk about the level of community concern. I will tell those opposite about the level of community concern. The other evening I was at a function where a well-known member of the National Party congratulated this Federal Government for being the first Federal Government that had ever put money into vocational training for people in the hospitality and tourism industry. She said, `I will be derided by my other Party members, but I have to speak up and I have to be honest'. For the first time in our history, we have a government that reflects the concerns of the community and is about a share for all. The kinds of notions that we hear expressed in terms of equity and access are mouthing of platitudes. They are not real.

We have also heard great weeping about the non-government sector and, in particular, the Catholic sector of education. I am sure that it is no secret to anybody on our side of the House that Labor politicians used to do three good things: they went to mass on Sunday; they followed Rugby League; and they voted Labor. So when it comes to Catholic education and the role which it has given many of us on this side, we know a great deal more about Catholic schools, Catholic schools in poor areas and the whole Catholic system.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very sectarian.

—I find quite extraordinary the kind of sectarian nonsense being espoused by the shadow Minister. The other day I was at the opening of a Catholic college to which this Federal Government had given $3m. We heard this kind of nonsense being trumpeted by people such as the shadow Minister for education. We know why the Opposition is concerned about the non-government schools and wishes to change its categories. It is because we do not fund those rich private schools. We do not fund them because why would schools that can raise $40,000, $50,000 or $60,000 at an afternoon fete need the taxpayers to assist them? Schools scratching to make $500, $600 or $700 at an afternoon fete are the kinds of schools that we are concerned about and that we want to ensure have full support and full resources.

PARA.TAB: We are not in the business of helping the rich get richer. The Opposition does that. We know about that. We know why people who are rich have access to education. The nonsense and platitudes that are being mouthed in terms of the voucher system says exactly that. That is the kind of thing that the Opposition wants to do. It wants to turn back the tertiary sector so that it becomes once more a question of whether people can afford it.

It would also open up the university sector to charging what it feels like, while lacking any sort of accountability. We know that members opposite do not like accountability. We have heard them say that they are not interested in accountability demands or fancy universities having to address issues of school leavers or mature age students, people who did not have the opportunity for education. Fancy asking the taxpayers to fund such a thing! Can one believe it? Here we have those retards from the nineteenth century who believe in privilege in the Victorian way and who really dislike Labor teachers, Labor lawyers, Labor doctors. Why? Because the Opposition thinks that we should not be there. We know; we are used to those opposite; and we understand it very clearly.

Let me tell Opposition members that we are going to continue to expand education, school retention rates, university places and university access, because we believe in the inherent right of every young Australian, irrespective of the wealth of his parents or the kind of voucher the Opposition may give him, to have access to universities.

It is very interesting as well to hear members of the Opposition discuss TAFE and its being the cinderella in education. It is this same Opposition that displays flags with the British Union Jack, the butcher's apron, in the corner. Why is our TAFE system as it is? Because it is one of our great British legacies; the heritage of our supposed British culture.

TALK.START.PARA: —What? TAFE is the fault of the British?
