—It is. People generally were given only a basic level of proficiency. Any education beyond that was deemed to be a privilege. We understand it; it is documented; it is monitored. Hence the whole thing—
—You're 50 years out of date.

—The honourable member is the one who is 150 years out of date, so do not worry; we understand. We know where he comes from and we know what he is about. He is about returning to the dark ages. We know that, we understand it and we hear him clearly. The people of Australia and the youth of Australia understand that Opposition members want to return to a system of education for the privileged, for the rich, with no accountability, with vouchers for those attending university and unfettered money for the richest schools in our community. They go around constantly decrying the rise in retention rates, the expansion of the university sector and the demise of the binary system and saying, `What hide the Government has to suggest that colleges of advanced education should be expanded and given university status. Is it not terrible that these people are getting above themselves?'—in the same way that we suggest education is a right and not a privilege. There is nothing as stark as the contrast between the Government and the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: I support all the Bills. Clearly they are a reflection of Labor's commitment to our youth and to ensuring that the school system will expand, that the TAFE system will expand, that our universities will continue to expand and that the access and equity which we talk about will not be limited by parents' income or by some voucher that a person can use down the street. Of course, with a 15 per cent consumption tax on kids' school shoes, school bags and school clothes—we must not forget their school lunches—how much more limited will access be as we see yet a further imposition on people in our community who have young children and school children in particular.

We on this side of the House understand very clearly what we are about in education. We are about ensuring that Australia moves into the twenty-first century, that all our young people can have access to universities, that our TAFE colleges will expand. It is not a question of the kind of familial income that is the dictator; rather government policy has to ensure that all of us have a right to education—not only those who are privileged.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak in this cognate debate on the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill, it is important that I comment on tonight's speech by the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) because, quite clearly, she does not understand—obviously she has not read the coalition's policy—the Opposition's position on this matter. The honourable member spoke about the rich. I presume she understands that there are double the number of children from rich families attending government schools as there are attending private schools in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Labor Party's policy position is that it is more important to subsidise rich people than to provide for better education. The honourable member for Forde indicated in her speech that it is more important to subsidise a whole range of rich families in terms of education. That is nonsense. The coalition's policy provides freedom of choice to parents as to where to send their children. The fundamental issue is not whether a school is rich or parents are rich; it is whether parents have the choice to send their children to the school of their choice. Under Labor that choice is very much restricted because of its new schools policy which prevents parents from establishing new schools in Australia and so denies them the choice. The honourable member's comments in that respect have no basis at all.

The honourable member also said that the Government wants to provide access to tertiary institutions to all students and there are now 50,000 to 70,000 students who are unable to get in. The Government says that it wants to provide access. Why has it not achieved it? Never in Australia's history has there been more money going to be injected into education than under Fightback. There will be $2 billion more for new programs over and above the present Government's projections. No matter what the Government says about it, that is the biggest injection of money into education that Australia has seen. The coalition has a very clear policy on this—that is, until we pump more money into education to enable people to be better educated, the competitive edge of Australia will not improve in global world markets.

Another thing which has to be said in regard to funding and providing places is that the Government's One Nation strategy is unfunded. Where is the money coming from? It is not available. In addition, over the last five or six years the Government's policies have got so off track that there has been a built-up need for more money in education. Because the economy is so off track—instead of a Budget deficit of $4.7 billion it is going to be $9.3 billion—we cannot provide for the impetus of the retention of young people in our schools going on to tertiary institutions. If the Government had set the economy in place, it would have had the money to do that. However, that is the reality; that is the bottom line.

If the Government's economic policies had been correct, the money would have flowed into the Government. The retention rate has improved and we support that. Contrary to what has been said, we do not decry retention rates. We are pleased that there are more young people being retained in our schools, but they have to be provided for when they go on to tertiary education. This Government did not have the foresight to provide the financial assistance so that could be achieved. In addition, the administrative arrangements which the Government wants to apply in the tertiary sector mean that it will control the university campuses. The Government wants to dictate to the university vice-chancellors as to how they will run their institutions—as if that will give the best advantage to Australian university students. That is the reality and it simply does not work.

The only way we will provide better opportunities for young people and the only way universities will use the funds which this Parliament provides for education at the tertiary sector is to allow those institutions greater freedom to do so in the best possible fashion. The Government believes that these things can be controlled from a centralised bureaucracy out of Canberra; that the conditions in Tasmania, Western Australia, northern Queensland or the Northern Territory are similar and that it can dictate to each individual institution from a centralised control system. We know that that does not work and that the universities do not want it, that they want more freedom. I am absolutely certain that, given more freedom, they can drive the taxpayers' dollar much further. The coalition's policies will give them that freedom so that they can drive the taxpayers' dollar further and not be hemmed in by the Government's industrial approach.

There has been a vitriolic attack on the coalition for seeking to provide extra money to private schools. What is wrong with providing extra money and a doubling of funding to private schools for capital works? At present the Government provides $81m. Under our Fightback program we will provide $162m. Obviously the Government does not want that money to go to the private school sector.

Yet when surveys are carried out of parents they say that, if they had the financial opportunity, they would like to send their children to private schools. The surveys in the ACT indicate that, if given the opportunity, 50 per cent of parents who presently send their children to government schools would like to send them to private schools.

I cannot quite follow the logic of the Government when it decries the coalition putting an extra $2,000m into education over the next six or seven years. Tonight it is saying that the coalition is on the wrong track. Not only are we going to do that; we are also going to fund it.

The Government has a package before the Australian people at the moment that is not funded. The One Nation package is not funded. The Government's economic policies have led Australia to a point now where we have this huge debt occurring—

TALK.START.PARA: —They've left nothing.

—Obviously. It goes back to the 1972-75 period, where the Budgets blew out, and it has just got worse. That is exactly what is happening now. This year the Budget blow-out will be double. It will be $4.7 billion going up to at least $9.3 billion. It will probably be $10 billion by the time we get there. We have 70,000 young people wanting to get into tertiary education but the Government has not provided for them.
—So much for the clever country!

—Absolutely. So much for the clever country. At the last election the then Prime Minister said in an election speech that we want a clever country. It is certainly not a clever government that has got us into a situation where so many of our young people want to go to university but are unable to do so.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that the Government's policies are seriously flawed in the education sector. They have not been forward looking and they are not forward providing for young people. It is a great tragedy that we are not providing for our young people who desperately need new skills and new knowledge. We need our young people to be at the cutting edge in the world in their knowledge and their skills. The Government has failed, and failed miserably, to provide for these young people.

We all know that Australia has an increasing overseas debt which has rapidly expanded under this Government. In fact, more money is being spent on repaying the interest on our debt than on the whole of the education budget. That would not be the case if we had policies in place. If the Fightback package were in place, we would be able to provide education facilities for the young people who want to use them.

Unfortunately this debate has been guillotined tonight. It is a very important debate and it goes to the nub of Australia's future in terms of providing a better education system at preschool, primary school, secondary school, college, university and in the TAFE sector—the whole lot. We have very few debates on education, yet this debate tonight has been guillotined to 1 hour and 50 minutes. We are debating the future of young people in Australia, the lack of provision and the lack of foresight by the Government, and the prospects of the coalition being able to provide an extra injection of $2,000m into education between now and the year 2000. We are able to fund education; the Government is not.

I will not spend any more time on this issue because there are many other speakers in this debate. I make the point that unless Australia really provides for its young people in this way we will never be competitive in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating cognately three different education Bills: the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill, the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill. All these Bills involve additional expenditure on education, particularly in the higher education field. I was interested to hear the comments of the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) and the shadow Minister for education, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp). I would like to correct some of the points that have been made.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I think a few facts need to be brought to the attention of the House with regard to the performance of the Government in the last eight or nine years in the higher education sector. Listening to what the honourable member for Braddon had to say, one would have thought there had been no growth at all. Yet when we look at education in this country, we see that there has been massive growth in higher education and in tertiary places funded by this Government.

I will give some statistics. The number of students at Australian universities has increased from 348,000 in 1983 to 534,500 in 1991—a massive increase in the number of tertiary places available to Australian students. A continuing growth in student numbers is proposed—a further 25,000 between 1992 and 1994.

Commonwealth funding through the Department of Employment, Education and Training has increased by $1.2 billion or 41 per cent in real terms in that period. No-one could disagree that that is a significant increase in funding for the higher education sector in particular. A further $300m, or 7.2 per cent, in real terms is planned over the next two years. Capital funding is up by 444 per cent and research funding is up by 260 per cent. How anyone can say that this Government has not substantially increased the amount of money allocated to education is beyond me. The figures stand for themselves and prove that point.

Although we have the line being used that 50,000 applications for university places could not be met this year, it ignores the fundamental reason behind that: too many students are applying for tertiary places when in fact they should be seeking places in the vocational education and training field. It is in that area that this Government is determined to address the needs of those students who are applicants for places, and it is in that area that the country needs to progress and develop considerably. The major focus for all education debate in the next two to three years in this country is what we are going to do for the vocational education and training sector.

In the last 12 months in particular three important reports which have come out have addressed the developing needs in the vocational education and training sector. First of all, we had the Finn committee report. Subsequent to that I and my colleague the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) had some part to play in the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. The Committee came down with a very important report which brought together a lot of the different threads of the debate about vocational education and training. We then had the release of the Carmichael report, which was also a very important contribution to the debate, about where we are going in apprenticeship training and vocational education and training in this country.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee recommended a number of important things: an expansion of training on a nationally consistent basis into areas not traditionally training oriented and the development of a single integrated entry level training system which would provide enhanced career opportunities for the great majority of young people who are not bound for university, and that is a very important point. Most of the 50,000 people who applied for university we do not really want to go to university. We do not need that number of university graduates each year in this country. We need people who are trained and who have the skills and the vocational education and training to fit into the work force. We do not need a massive oversupply of university graduates; we want skilled workers to fulfil the needs of our developing economy.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee also recommended the development of a wider training market outside the public sector which, subject to assurances about quality and standards, will provide even greater training opportunities. That is an important point because it is clear that the existing TAFE system in this country is not able to meet the demands that are being placed on it now and will continue to be placed on it. We need to support some growth in the private training sector to accommodate the needs of those young people.

We have to deliberately embark on encouraging recognition of the importance of vocational education to correct the imbalance which exists at the moment and which ignores and devalues a significant proportion of the skills and knowledge held by people who have gone through the TAFE sector. That is an important point to make. A very low number of people seek to go into TAFE because people do not believe TAFE is an appropriate or suitable venue for their training. In some cases I would agree with them that the TAFE sector has not been able to meet its requirements or its obligations, but in many other ways the TAFE sector is producing some excellent courses and some excellent programs and should be supported. We need to be educating the community about the importance of technical and vocational education and the fact that it is a viable alternative to university study.

The House of Representatives Committee also recommended the development and refinement by industry of national competency standards across all occupations to meet industry standards and needs and to make sure that they are national standards that are applicable across the whole nation. That is one of the fundamental issues that need to be addressed in the next two to three years.

Earlier I mentioned the fact that unfortunately in our community we have too many students who believe that university is the only place for them to go. A survey of youth and community attitudes indicates that there has been a massive decline in young people's interest in TAFE—from 20 per cent of 15- to 17-year-olds in 1984 to only 13 per cent in 1990, which is an unrealistically low level. The Finn report says that 50 per cent of young people between 15 and 19 should be going to TAFE and that places should be found for them in TAFE. Unfortunately, most of them do not wish to go to TAFE because they do not believe that TAFE is appropriate. That is a problem we have to address very quickly.

In the One Nation statement released in February, the Commonwealth set out to make an offer to the States to substantially address the growth needs in the TAFE and vocational education and training sectors. It made an offer to the States to assume full financial responsibility for vocational education and training across Australia and to develop a new system of institutes of vocational education, building on the existing TAFE sector. It is a very generous offer, and it is being negotiated with the States at the moment.

It commits the Commonwealth to establishing an assured and stable basis of triennial funding. It promises a total of $720m over the next three years on top of existing financial allocations. Brian Finn in his report indicated that the vocational education and training sector will need growth of the order of $1 billion a year for the next 10 years to accommodate the training needs of this country. The substantial offer of funding that has been made in the One Nation statement very much addresses those targets that Brian Finn set. I would encourage all State governments to accept the offers that the Commonwealth is making, because it is in that area that our real needs have to be addressed over the next few years. There is no need for any substantial new growth in university places. The need for growth is in the technical and vocational education and training sectors.

I would like briefly to talk about the schools funding area, because that is an issue that has been of concern to constituents in my electorate. A few points need to be made in response to some of the comments of the honourable member for Braddon. He indicated that he felt that this Government had in some way restricted choice for parents. Nothing could be further from the truth. There has been a massive injection of money from the Commonwealth Government into the non-government sector over the last eight years. In fact, this Government spends $1.3 billion a year supporting 850,000 students in 2,468 non-government schools. Of those schools, 250 are new schools which have been funded since Labor came to office. How anyone could suggest that this Government has not met the commitment that it is required to meet for the funding of non-government schools, and that in some way we have restricted parental choice, is beyond me, and the figures prove that that is not so.

Two years ago this Government announced increased funding for all non-government schools through to the year 2000. That is budgeted at over $100m, and is fully costed and accounted for. There has been real growth each year over and above the rate of inflation in the amount of grants that this Government has given to the non-government sector. There have been no cutbacks; there has been real growth. We are providing full parental choice.

The honourable member for Braddon made some comments about the new schools policy, and suggested that supporting the Opposition's Fightback policy—which abolishes the new schools system that this Government has in place—would somehow improve parental choice. The honourable member for Braddon should realise that in fact there are large sections of the non-government school community which do not support the Fightback proposition. They understand and realise that by having an open door policy, which is what the Opposition is suggesting—that we abolish the new schools committee structure that reviews each application for funding and determines whether a new non-government school in a certain area will be viable—we will have quite a reckless waste of government resources because unlimited numbers of new schools will open up in competition with existing non-government schools and existing government schools. This will lead to massive duplication of resources and waste of government money. It will create enormous problems for existing non-government schools as well as existing government schools. I would not have thought that the Opposition would support such a massive waste of government resources, leading to such an enormous amount of duplication.

I believe that the existing policy of this Government in carefully scrutinising all applications for funding for new non-government schools is worthy of support. We will find that most people in the non-government sector throughout the community do not support the Opposition's policy on the abolition of the new schools process. I realise I have gone a little over the time I was allotted, so I just commend the three Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear that over the past decade Australians have finally come to grips with the concept that education is valuable. But this understanding by Australians, and their warm embrace of education at all levels, has caused us a few problems. Last week, on 23 May, Geoff Maslen, education writer for the Age, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The cruel reality facing thousands of Victorians qualified for university is that their chances of admission are getting worse each year. . . This year, the number of students who failed to win a place in the State's higher-education institutions was more than double that of 1991.

PARA.TAB: Figures compiled by the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee show that up to 19,000 hopeful students were turned away from higher education in Victoria, 38 per cent of the national total and a 110 per cent increase in unmet demand from 1991.
Many of those denied a place applied to a TAFE college but the TAFE system has been forced to turn away even more students than the universities.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that up to 50,000 qualified students have missed places in university this year. Perhaps as many as 100,000 potential students have been denied places in TAFE. I am delighted that the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) is at the table tonight, because I want to talk about the very special needs of a very special area in Victoria for higher education and higher education funding. My electorate of La Trobe encompasses Mount Dandenong and the ranges and has special needs to the north in the outer east and very special needs to the south in the south-east.

PARA.TAB: For almost two years I have been involved with a council of people from industry, politics, education and the general community lobbying government for facilities at a tertiary level in the outer east to the top of the mountain. We have been successful and we will now have new university facilities. I address the rest of my remarks to the south-eastern growth corridor of Victoria, which has one of the lowest participation rates in Australia and is the lowest major area in Victoria. The Mornington education district, which includes Berwick, Pakenham, Cranbourne and Dandenong, has the lowest participation rates in tertiary education in Melbourne and the surrounding area.

Last year the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission, in a report on patterns of participation in higher education in Victoria, found very wide variations in the 17- to 24-year-old age group of 30 per cent participation in Camberwell and Brighton and 4 per cent in Cranbourne. In the figures for 17- to 24-year-olds attending university we have such anomalies as 32.7 per cent for Camberwell, 24.7 per cent for Doncaster-Templestowe, 28 per cent for Hawthorn and 28 per cent for Kew. In the south-eastern growth area, the figures are: Berwick, 5.7 per cent; Cranbourne, 4.2 per cent; Dandenong, 8.9 per cent; and Pakenham, 9.5 per cent. It is discouraging.
The projected growth rate in the south-eastern growth corridor is almost twice that for any other designated education area in Victoria. The VIPSEC report dated April 1991 said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in a limited number of cases where participation is low and substantial long term growth is expected additional higher education campuses could be established. An obvious example of this kind of development is at Berwick which is central to a major growth corridor, some distance from existing campuses, and where a major co-operative TAFE/Higher Education development could occur. In this case the likely growth is such that adequate provision would need to be made for major developments in both sectors in the longer term.

It seems obvious, to me at least, that our system is out of balance and that we need to address this crying need of our students. We have made representations to the Minister; we have made representations to his Department; we have made representations to the Victorian Minister for higher education; and we have made representations to his Department. As a result of this VIPSEC report, it became obvious that we desperately needed facilities located in Berwick next to the TAFE campus. Therefore, we formed a planning council in the south-eastern growth area.

PARA.TAB: Leading on from that council, a working party was established, made up of representatives from the Federal Government, DEET, the Victorian Government, VIPSEC, the player university—that is, the university responsible for that area, Monash—and from Dandenong TAFE, being the TAFE component already establishing a major campus at Berwick. Over the past nine months, that council and that working party have worked to try to define the necessary element for growth and the need for a new campus. We have made representations to the Minister. The working party, unfortunately, has not yet been able to bring down a formal report, because all of this initiative began with a need in the growth area. The growth area starts in Dandenong and runs down past Pakenham towards the valley. It includes Cranbourne and Pakenham but is centred on Berwick.

Monash facilities, the majority of which are at Clayton, with some at Caulfield next door, run to Frankston and then to Churchill. Berwick presents itself as a centre of the demographics for the area that Monash would serve for students. Some 150 acres is available at Berwick on a railhead—that is, a rail station on an established rail line—and on a major national arterial road with on-off ramps nearing completion. On that 150 acres we can combine tertiary education at university level with tertiary education at TAFE level and create these pathways and links between training and university education that we talk about today as being so important.

We were well down the track towards having DEET, the Minister and the State Minister agree to the capital funding for 1994 to establish the campus that Monash has requested. Unfortunately, all of a sudden the issue became political. The honourable member for Holt, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), decided that for State political purposes it would be wise for him to support such a campus of Monash in the city of Dandenong, which is very close to the existing campus of Monash at Clayton.

We now have a political issue in which we have a major politician, the Attorney-General, trying to win a campus location for a university in what we believe to be a less advantageous location for our students. Make no mistake, our students are crying out for university places, and there is a 5 per cent participation rate in the 17- to 24-year age group. It is a crying shame. They want to go, but the transport problem is so difficult from Mount Dandenong and regions surrounding it. It takes so long to get to any major campus by train or bus. The train lines do not run to Monash, because in the past we built universities where it was convenient, not where it was intelligent. We did not think about the needs of the community 20 or 30 years ahead.

As I said before, Berwick is in the centre of the highest growth region in Victoria. The number of students will double in only a few years. I believe the growth rate today has surpassed that of the Gold Coast. It is an area that is crying out for tertiary places. We have available in one place land in an abundant quantity to fulfil the needs of a grassroots tertiary facility, next door to a new major TAFE campus which will support ultimately some 4,000 or 5,000 equivalent full time places. It has a railway station that is established and it is on major bus routes, with a bus depot at the front door of the proposed university.

The site has major car access to a national arterial road which dumps off at the location of the proposed site. The people from that area request both the State and Federal Ministers to quickly ask their working party to complete its report and its recommendation for a Berwick campus of Monash University, and to fund that campus through the 1994 capital funding which the Government is now intending to roll into recurrent funding. It is my most sincere request of this Minister that he act to the best benefit of all the students in all the areas and that he act quickly so that we can have the additional places that we so desperately need in an area that is crying out for access.

TALK.START.PARA: —In listening to the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) earlier tonight, we got the same turgid diatribe that we tend to get about education issues from the shadow Minister for education—a failure to reflect upon the real success, the real commitment that has been shown to education at all levels, the real commitment that has been shown by the Government during its time in office to the training and skilling of our young people to enable them to enter the work force, and a complete failure to acknowledge the real achievements that have occurred across these sectors, particularly—if I can just apply a regional focus to my remarks for a short time—in the area of western Sydney where, historically, the participation rates, the access to and equity in higher education were at lamentable levels.

PARA.TAB: It is pleasing to note that one of the great achievements that we can point to with the University of Western Sydney is the opening up of opportunities to young people from that region to higher education. They suffered from many of the difficulties relating to transportation, the lack of role models for children there because of the limited number of people who had completed secondary education let alone done any further training, and the limited opportunities that existed. When we came to office only one in three children completed secondary school.

There were significant disincentives in the system that prevented young people from being able to complete secondary school. That whole culture has been changed largely because our Government has recognised those particular priorities. It has recognised that, in order to be advantaged, our young people need to get equity in their educational opportunity. That has been a foundation stone upon which our education policies have been built.

It is worth contrasting that with the voucher concept that the Opposition is proposing in areas such as education. If we look at areas such as western Sydney that I represent, we will find that a voucher system or some form of loan arrangement would be very much to the detriment of the people there because they are the ones who would not get access to higher education. We would go back to the bad old days when those people did not have the opportunity. Conservative governments in the past perceived that those people did not even have the right to aspire to higher education.

The provision of Bills such as those we have before us tonight is part of ensuring that those young people do have that opportunity. In the high cost courses, the sciences, engineering and so forth, a voucher system would be the very last thing we would want to encourage or promote if we were really trying to encourage opportunity, excellence and equity.

For those reasons I believe the people of Australia would be well placed to read carefully the implications of Fightback for the education sector. Once they do that, I have no doubt that the vast majority of Australians will conclude, as any fair-minded person would, that a voucher system approach would fundamentally cut at the bone of what equity in education is all about.

In the brief time available to me tonight, I particularly want to refer to the area of TAFE training. If there is one sector that really has a need, that is crying out for attention and for which this Government has faced up to providing an effective regime, it is the TAFE sector. For far too long we have allowed TAFE to be left to the performance, or lack of performance, of State governments. Not enough scrutiny has been paid to the results that should be sought from the TAFE system, not enough regard has been paid to the need to develop an effective training regime and not enough regard has been paid to the need for the TAFE system to be integrated with other areas of our education system. For far too long TAFE has been the poor relation.

In the One Nation economic statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) we set about changing that; we set about changing the culture of TAFE; we set about building on the report of the inquiry by the Education Council Review Committee into young people's participation in post-compulsory education and training, known as the Finn report, building on the Deveson report and also recognising the most recent efforts of the Employment and Skills Formation Council, the Carmichael committee.

That is particularly important because the whole area of TAFE depends on that greater vocational focus. It depends on having the resources at a national level to give TAFE the credibility it deserves, and it depends on developing the pathways that are so critical in the linkage between TAFE, the school system and the work force.

The way of achieving that, as was outlined in the One Nation statement, is to make an historic commitment at the Commonwealth level towards the adequate funding of our TAFE sector. That commitment does a number of things. It provides an extra $310m per year by 1995 above the Commonwealth-State provision for TAFE in 1991. This represents an additional injection of $720m over the 1993-95 triennium. It paves the way for a new higher status, better resourced system for vocational education and training. The Commonwealth is offering to take over full responsibility for vocational education and training, including the transformation of TAFE into a new and expanded system of institutes of vocational education.

A process of reform to entry level training arrangements will involve the Commonwealth, the States and Territories, the industrial parties and training providers. We are seeking the involvement of the States, industry and training providers to address the emerging needs of industry for advanced training for higher level technicians. Part of that process is to open many more apprenticeships and training places within the system. It includes $18.3m for an additional 9,000 first year apprentice places in 1992, raising employment incentives from 3,000 to 5,000; $10.1m for an additional 10,000 places for the Australian apprenticeship system in 1992; $5m to retain second year apprentices at risk of retrenchment, and so on. There is a whole host of measures all designed to target the labour market area effectively and to ensure the TAFE system is able to meet the demands and challenges it faces.

If we look at the proposals of the Federal Government in relation to TAFE, it is disappointing to see the failure of the States to this point to respond adequately to the visionary approach that we have sought to adopt in the TAFE sector. Clearly, the States are more driven, as is so often the case, by their own individual rights and responsibilities, rather than the longer term needs of young people and the opportunities that an effectively resourced TAFE system provides for many young people.

Developing a flexible and diverse range of opportunities for young people, relying solely on students getting places at universities and expecting all students to complete the full period of secondary school and then look for places in universities is a flawed strategy in educational terms. There needs to be a variety of options. All of us who have had experience in education—no matter what sector that experience has been in—would recognise that the training opportunities need to be across that broader range. In my fairly recent experience, as one who was teaching in an academic institution, I can relate to the needs that exist in higher level education and the TAFE sector that necessitate being addressed in a comprehensive way.

The way we do that is to try to get those linkages within the system to be more flexible, to provide more opportunities. Some of the artificial barriers that were there in the past with the old binary system of higher education need to give way to a more contemporary approach. That is something that has been the hallmark of our reforms in these areas.

At this stage I believe TAFE is the key ingredient in that approach. It is clear that we need to be able to realise the objectives set by the Finn report in relation to TAFE training. We need to be able to ensure that we achieve far more than the very mixed results that the States have achieved in relation to TAFE in recent times. The One Nation economic statement and the measures outlined tonight go a long way towards providing the sorts of TAFE opportunities that are needed: the new vocational courses, the flexibility to move to where there is a real demand for new courses. In my own area there is a shortage of places in areas such as the hospitality industry, in growing industries and in growing employment opportunities. Part of resourcing the TAFE system in this way is to provide opportunities for young people seeking to move into those fields.

When we go to the broader issue of higher education and, despite the demands, we look at just how much has been achieved by this Government in higher education, we see the massive increase that has occurred in the number of places provided in higher education—an increase from 348,683 to 534,500 places in universities and the college equivalents through that time—and the amount of expenditure that has been committed to the higher education sector over that time. That has amounted to $1.2 billion, a 41 per cent real increase in funding for higher education—and more is planned in that area.

The recent economic statement and the further plans in higher education demonstrate the Government's ongoing commitment in this area and the ongoing commitment in relation to Austudy, to ensure that there is equity, to ensure there is opportunity for participation in education. All of those things have been part of that chapter of achievement I have referred to.

The contrast is stark compared with what the Opposition would do in terms of that access and that equity. For those reasons, it gives me pleasure to support these Bills. The Government has an excellent record in the provision of educational funding to the school sector and the higher education sector. Through the measures that have been initiated in recent times, we are committed to ensuring that that commitment is very real in the TAFE sector. There should not be a person in this Parliament who is not just as committed as the Ministers have been to ensuring that our TAFE system gets the sorts of resources that it deserves and that the students who are aspiring to train there deserve as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little puzzled by some of the statements made by the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott). Prior to my being elected to parliament 18 years ago, I had spent all of my life, from the time that I started to attend school, in the education system in one way or another—as a teacher, lecturer or administrator. Since my election to parliament I have been very involved in policy and administration matters relating to education.

PARA.TAB: It is quite illogical for the honourable member for Parramatta to be critical of the Opposition's policy. One of the things that I find most exciting about the Fightback program is the extraordinary commitment that it gives to education and the development of education in this country. We are a young country which depends very much on its skills for its ability to maintain its trading position and, with that, its standard of living. We have a highly literate population and, compared with many other countries in the world, we have always had a very high level of skills and training amongst our work force. It is that which has given us our trading position, not only in the technological area but also in the primary industries area. Therefore, education is central to the future of this country. It is quite illogical for the honourable member for Parramatta to be critical of the Fightback program in that sense.

Fightback promises that the Liberal and National parties will commit themselves to Commonwealth expenditure of more than $3 billion on new education and training programs over this decade. Without a doubt, in the nearly 10 years that the Labor Party has been in power in Australia there has been an alarming run down in the priority accorded to education.

I would like to pick up a number of specifics which Government members have raised this evening in the context of trying to put forward the suggestion that the Government's programs are unsatisfactory, under-funded and undirected. I turn, first of all, to one of the early speeches by a Government member, namely, the honourable member for Forde (Mrs Crawford). She is about to inherit, through a redistribution of boundaries, a significant part of my present electorate of Moncrieff, namely, the northern end, which is the urban sprawl area of Beenleigh and Eagleby.

The honourable member for Forde and I were both educated in Queensland and she must have traded on no Queensland-educated Opposition members listening to her speech, judging from the extraordinary things she said. She pointed out that people above the age of 42 who had been educated in Queensland had no high school education, or a very low level of education. She blamed that on the National-Liberal Party Government.

A little bit of quick arithmetic—and I did teach mathematics—shows that those who were aged 42 in 1991 were born in 1949. They did what was called the old scholarship examination in 1962. They are part of the baby boom generation. I was just a little earlier than that—not very many years earlier—and I did scholarship in 1955. I went to an independent high school simply because the government schools in Queensland were slums when I went to high school. One got a desk, a chair and 49 compatriots in one's class at high school and that was it. Of course, that was in the days of a State Labor government. It is absolute nonsense to be blaming that sort of past tense in Queensland on a National-Liberal Party government.

In its first three years in government—from 1957 to 1960—that National-Liberal Government built more than 60 schools. By the end of its next three years in government—by the end of 1963—it had built nearly 100 new schools. We had a Labor government that knew that a baby boom was coming and we already had atrocious conditions in our schools—particularly our high schools. There were three government high schools in a city of half a million people. The independent high school I went to was not a palace; compared with today's standards in any school, it was a slum. There was no government support. It was an enormous sacrifice on my parents' part for me to go to that school. But they wanted me to have an education, which I was not going to get in a government school.

That is not putting down the government school sector today, but it is telling honourable members what it was like under a Labor government. I do not want to hear the honourable member for Forde in here again making any reflections on the Liberal and National parties in Queensland in educational terms. It was the Liberal-National Government that lifted the school leaving age to 15 years. It was still 13 in the late 1950s in Queensland—the only State in Australia in that position, thanks to many years of an atrophied State Labor government.

We have the signs of an atrophied Commonwealth Labor Government now, particularly in the education area. It is quite clear that our educational system is not coping with the new demands of technology and the new demands of education generally. It clearly cannot cope with growth.

I come from the growth State in Australia. I recognise what the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), who spoke before me, said about growth in his area. He said that he thought it was actually higher than the Gold Coast. If we take just the Gold Coast—just that little coastal strip—yes, it possibly is; but when we take the region a couple of miles away from the coastal strip, we find the fastest growth rate in Australia. Of course, we also have the most under-funded education. That is against the fact that the census shows that we have, overwhelmingly, two age groups in that part of the world—one is the retired people, who do not have major educational demands; the other very concentrated age group, whose number is well above the national average, is made up of young families. The demand for education in that part of the world is huge.

I come back to the honourable member for Forde, who is about to inherit the northern part of my electorate—a huge growth area and a low income area: the Beenleigh-Eagleby area. The honourable member will probably get a very rude awakening when she inherits Canterbury College, for example—one of the new independent schools in that part of the world. Under the extraordinary structure that the Labor Party put on the independent schools program back in the days when Senator Susan Ryan was Minister, it decided to entrench a disadvantage for any independent school. The rationale was that the Government did not want independent schools taking funds away from government schools. That rationale did not take account of the high growth areas where there were virtually no independent schools and where the demand was bound to come from.

In my electorate overall—going down to the Gold Coast and out into the hinterland—in my time as a member of parliament a very high number of independent schools have opened. The extraordinary thing about that area is that there were so few independent schools prior to the mid-1980s. But they have come with the huge growth in the number of young people in the population. Some very exciting things are happening there. But every one of those schools suffers from an historical disadvantage. They are not, as the honourable member for Forde said, `rich' private schools; they are average independent schools.

Parents choose to send their children to these independent schools for all sorts of reasons—notably, all of them are Christian schools, and I think that is a major motivation behind parents sending their children there—and they have the right to the same level of funding as an inner-Brisbane school. These parents are no more advantaged and their children are not necessarily any more advantaged; but the schools are disadvantaged, though not classified as such, which then disadvantages the parents and the children. It makes their fees higher because they cannot qualify for the same level of funding given to schools classified as disadvantaged. Therefore, the fees have to be higher and that counts out a whole lot of children from lower income families. The Labor Party's policies on independent schools in 1983 and 1984 were, frankly, based on prejudice and a wish to stop the growth of independent schools. There is only one reason why the independent school sector has grown as much as it has: it offers something that a number of people want. That is in no way a put-down of the government school system.

I have a number of excellent government schools doing very exciting educational things in my electorate; I do not put them down. In fact, government schools can have an enormous natural advantage. Because they tend to be large, if they are in a growth area, they can offer very particular programs that smaller schools—notably, independent schools, which tend to be smaller—cannot do. There is a place for both. But the matter of choice is, of course, fundamental. The essence of the matter, and the reason the Labor Party is so far off track, is that it cares about the system, not the students. It is really all about education. Schools are all about educating young people. Post-secondary education is about educating youngish people and some older people. But we must get away from the sorts of prejudices that exist at the moment or we will continue to have the skewed and unsatisfactory situation that we have at the moment.

In these growth areas of Australia, the Government's programs in relation to schools certainly cannot cope, and this applies also in the tertiary area. Again I come back to my part of the world, not only because I want to talk about my part of the world, which I usually do, but because it illustrates a future, and if we stay in the straitjacket we are in at the moment we will just get more and more distortions in the system. We have a new university on the Gold Coast which was established only a few years ago. The extraordinary thing about the announcement of the Government's decision to fund the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education—and heaven knows we had been pounding on the doors for a while on that—was that there was not any sign of getting that college until Bond University was announced. I remember people who had been fighting to get the college for some time going into despair when Bond University was announced. They said, `That is the end of it. Now we are going to have Bond University we will never get our college'. I said, `Hang on. I think the best thing you have going for you, if you want to get a college of advanced education, is Bond University'. I was right. The Government had to set up a government institution because there was going to be a private institution there to show the Government up.

That institution has done extraordinarily good work, particularly in hospitality tertiary education—contrary to what the honourable member for Parramatta was saying. It has always taken more students than it has been funded for. It is cramped for space. It has worked so hard because it has an enormous motivation towards the needs of local education. But the overall straitjacket of funding of tertiary education under this Labor Government has severely limited it. Like many other tertiary institutions, last year it took a lot more students than it was funded for because the pressures were so enormous. It meant that this year it could take very few more because it was already grossly overcrowded. But, even though the demand had been established and the abilities of the students were established last year, still there was no give in the system this year.

The honourable member for Parramatta talks about what his Government does. His Government does a number of things—he can put figures on it—but I notice he does not mention, or discount at all in the figures he quotes, the amount of money that has been collected, for example, through HECS, which has to be considered whenever one looks at increases in funding. If we do not say that a certain amount of this was taken out of new

SPEECH.PARA: revenue collections for this reason, we are not telling the whole story.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I want to express a concern about structures. If ever there is a sign of a government getting hardening of the arteries it is when it concentrates on structures and tags in the education area versus outcome. I feel quite ambivalent about the old binary system. I worked in university administration. I lectured at the Queensland Institute of Technology, which was a college of advanced education. I have lectured in adult education. I have seen the whole thing, and I have had a close association with it in my time in Parliament. There were some rigidities in the binary system, but for the honourable member for Parramatta to say that, by doing away with the binary system and putting all the education systems into one, we have done away with rigidities is nonsense. The rigidities did not lie in the terminology of universities or colleges of advanced education but in the attitude one had to the other or which one thought the other had to it.

If there is one thing that persistently occupied the attention of people in colleges of advanced education, it was what they thought university people thought of them. Prestige and so on is always an issue. There is some essence of truth in that if it goes through into the policy-making process—if that thinking permeates attitudes. I do not think, by and large, it did. It did lead to some rigidities. For example, the Queensland Institute of Technology had some excellent courses and it was restricted to some extent in how far it could pursue very exciting and worthwhile research programs. That needed improvement. I am not convinced that just by renaming a sector one has eased it up or added anything to it. It really would not worry me if colleges of advanced education were called universities if I were satisfied first that the function that colleges were set up to meet was being met and, secondly, if I were not very afraid, as I am, that TAFE is going to move to fill a vacuum. Already technical and further education colleges are starting to call themselves colleges of technology or institutes of technology, and it is the next step. I just see a vacuum left by not having addressed what CAEs were first set up for in that renaming process, which was very much a vocational tertiary education. The vacuum is there—although it is not as big as it was prior to the CAEs—and without a doubt TAFE is going to move to fill it. Already it is very clear that there are people in the TAFE sector who have the same chip on their shoulder now—they have inherited it from the CAEs—and will try to move up and be pseudo CAEs by calling themselves something else. I would not care about any of that ego stuff if it were not for the students; that is what bothers me.

TAFE was set up for post-secondary students who did not want to go into a tertiary—as in university or college—area. It has developed—not as fast as it should have; it has been the cinderella—and done some very exciting things. There are some very good people in the TAFE sector who are very highly motivated. But they have been dealing essentially with students who either were in transition situations to tertiary or did not want academic training but wanted post-secondary training—and good training. I am very concerned that, in this labelling or whatever it is, and the massaging of the ego—as we do here in Parliament—of the education establishment, once again we are going to forget about the students.

In my 25 years as a professional in education, including my 18 years in parliament, over and over again I have seen that in all the debates about education, essentially carried out by educators, the educatees are not part of them. We must always in this Parliament remember that the education system is about educating people, and those people are the ones we have to concentrate on. I do not think the Government has got it right. I think we need great imagination. We need to accept the very exciting initiatives that are coming from the independent sector. I had hoped tonight to talk about a couple of very exciting things that are happening in the independent sector in my part of the world, but my time is running out.

Let me say just quickly that at Jimboomba there is a quite new secondary development—it will, of course, be in Rankin after the next redistribution—called the South Queensland College, which is part Japanese students, part Australian students and totally Japanese funded. It has huge establishment costs and provides an immersion course in Japanese for the Australian students and an immersion course in English for the Japanese students. The honourable member for Parramatta talks about exciting things, but it has developed a golf management course which will go to what it calls grade 13. It is going to be taking students from the hospitality sector at the Gold Coast University College and training them there on the scene. I think that is very exciting. Some people will snigger about it, but with the number of golf courses we have in our part of the world, which are attracting millions of dollars in tourism, and the number of jobs golf is providing, it is very important indeed. It has been left to a private institution to do it.

We should never take away from the importance of the dual sectors and how they stimulate one another to innovation. I support the amendment to the second readings to all of these three Bills moved by the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), and I look forward to the day after the next election, when there will be real imagination and real expansion in the education sector in Australia.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important that the Opposition register its great concern at the way in which the Government has handled the management of its training policy. The second reading amendment drew the attention of the House to the fact that, after nine years of Labor, the Government has demonstrated a continuing inability to establish a practicable policy for raising the skills of Australia's young people. For the first six or seven years of the Government there was virtually a total neglect of TAFE. Throughout the period of this Government, while participation increased in schools and in universities, participation in TAFE courses remained virtually static.

PARA.TAB: Finally, it was brought home to the Government that Australia was lagging very badly behind other countries in the skills of its young people and that this lack of skills was a significant factor in making it difficult for young people to find employment in jobs that could be sustained against international competition. So the Government, in a flurry of activity, called upon several inquiries to provide it with reports. There was the Deveson inquiry and the Finn inquiry, and earlier this year the report commissioned by the Employment and Skills Formation Council, the Carmichael report, was issued.

So there is no lack of information available to the Government about the disastrous situation that Australia finds itself in. The Deveson committee informed the Government and the community that so far as skills development was concerned Australia was at the back of the pack internationally. The Finn committee reviewed the whole area of post-compulsory education and training and drew the Government's attention once again to the fact that Australia is well behind in comparison with other industrialised countries. Indeed, it concluded that in the schools area there is incontrovertible evidence that very large numbers of young people are coming out of the schooling system with inadequate basic skills of literacy and numeracy.

The Government has received a plethora of advice. Much of this advice has drawn the Government's attention to the need for much more effective monitoring of the skills which young people have which are relevant to their employment in the work force. Indeed, this need was a key element in the report of the Finn committee. Yet it is very striking when one looks at the statements of the Government in this area, whether they be in relation to secondary schooling, post-compulsory years of secondary schooling or to TAFE training, that the Government is remarkably hesitant to commit itself to the need for effective monitoring of skills.

Of course, the reason for this is the Government's dependence through the accord process on support of the union movement. It finds in the education area that there has been a continual resistance by its union mates to provide the community with effective and accurate information about the level of skills being achieved either in the schooling or post-schooling systems.

Although the need for effective monitoring was a major theme in the Finn report, little has been said about it by the Government. The Meyer committee is meeting and investigating this area and it also is finding that there is enormous resistance to developing effective systems for making sure that young Australians have skills at international level.

What the Government has done in each of these areas has been to return to those kinds of decisions that it finds much easier to take, which are in accord with the ideology of particularly the Left faction of the Government which delights in central bureaucratic controls, which loves to see Canberra dominating the education and training institutions in this country and which sees in increased central supervision an opportunity for the Government to pursue the agendas and the shibboleths of the Left. In this area of higher education we see, tragically, a Minister drawn from that faction pursuing these policies in a very rigid and ideological way.

In relation to TAFE, what we see is the Government putting forward some proposals committing funds conditional on the States agreeing to accept Canberra's dictate. This was the Dawkins agenda for schooling which led to the collapse of trust between the States and the Commonwealth in relation to primary and secondary education. This same agenda today has been taken up in relation to TAFE.

The Government makes much of the fact that it was prepared to commit in One Nation an additional $420m to TAFE investment—$420m that, of course, like every other promise in that One Nation policy, was completely unfunded. It is money to be drawn out of the air, as it were, to be devoted to additional development of training opportunities. But the sad thing was that that money was made entirely conditional on the States agreeing to hand over control of their TAFE systems to Canberra. They have not agreed to do so. There have been several discussions, there has been a meeting of the Premiers, and there is still no agreement. Maybe there will be an agreement at some stage.

We know one government—the Kirner Government in Victoria—is desperate for some of that money, because it says that its re-election chances may be affected by its ability to put additional money into the TAFE training area. The other States, however, are much wiser and their financial situation is not quite as desperate as Victoria's, and even the Labor States have expressed their grave reservations over the meaning of this promise of money by the Commonwealth.

So, instead of a government which is able to tell the Australian people what it is going to do in the TAFE training area, what we find and what this second reading amendment draws attention to is the continuing inability of the Government to actually establish a policy in this area. No-one knows what the Government's policy for TAFE is. No-one knows the terms on which this $420m will be made available, or indeed if it will be made available at all if the States do not agree to the Commonwealth's terms as spelt out in One Nation. So after nine years of Labor, with Australia still at the back of the pack, with Australia still with one of the least skilled work forces in the Western world, we find the Government pursuing an approach which is causing dissension and division within the ranks of the Labor Party between the Federal Government and the States, and which has still not eventuated in a practicable agreement as to how TAFE expansion is to be funded.

What a dramatic contrast this is to the fully funded and developed strategy for TAFE and training which is spelt out in the coalition's Fightback program. In that program there is a commitment of funds to TAFE which is not conditional on the States agreeing to surrender their authority, which is not conditional on centralising control over TAFE, but which, on the contrary, recognises that if we are going to build up training institutions which have the flexibility to meet the needs of their local communities, which are going to be able to attract additional resources from the private as well as the public sectors to provide additional places in TAFE for Australia's young people, it is necessary to provide those institutions with a much greater independence and autonomy. That is what TAFEs want.

TAFEs around Australia are giving the Government a very clear message that they are highly suspicious of the package now being promoted by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley). They have no expectation that the situation which will emerge from these discussions will be favourable to their development as institutions and, consequently, they have the gravest concerns over the future of training in this country. It is for these reasons that the coalition moved its second reading amendment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the following amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1992:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House deplores the Government's continued mismanagement of higher education and, in particular, the House deplores the Government's:

PARA.TAB: (1)determination to maintain a flawed system of funding for higher education;
(2)failure to provide a satisfactory regulatory framework for the development of higher education;
(3)failure to provide adequate opportunities for young people to lift their level of knowledge and skills and thereby to address a significant contributing factor to youth unemployment;
(4)pursuit of a policy which prevents some 50,000 qualified Australian students from gaining places in tertiary institutions; and
(5)failure to address the serious inequities of current arrangements".

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned in my speech on the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill, there is probably no area of education and training, no level, in which the Government's failure is more evident to the community than in the higher education area. As a result of the White Paper of 1988 there has been an upheaval in the higher education system. The vocationally oriented colleges of advanced education have been forcibly merged with the pre-1987 universities, to the enormous detriment, in many cases, of the provision of satisfactory and targeted vocational education in many regions of Australia.

PARA.TAB: We in the coalition do not say that there are no grounds and never were any grounds for any mergers at all; what we do say is that whatever amalgamations took place between institutions should have been voluntary and there should have been recognition of the need for a diversity of institutions in this area. We have not had that. We have had instead an ideological assault on so-called elitist universities and, as a consequence, the destruction of opportunities for vocational education and training provided by the colleges of advanced education, to the enormous detriment of many of Australia's young people.

We have a system which has not got the flexibility to provide additional places to Australian students above those funded by the Government. As a consequence, although there is a universal concession that there is in this country from the point of view of long term employment for our young people a need that they have skills of international standard, the Government deliberately, flouting the advice of its expert advisory body, the Industry Commission, has persisted with a system of regulation which denies to the universities the flexibility to provide places to Australian students in the way that they have to provide additional places to students from other countries.

We have a quite intolerable inequity; we have a quite intolerable rigidity; and we have the inevitable consequence of this kind of central planning, planning which has worked nowhere in the world—institutions which are unable to adjust to the demands made upon them and institutions which are unable to open their doors to many qualified Australian students. Again, this is a dramatic contrast to the coalition's policy, which will provide opportunities to the universities of this country to open the doors to these 50,000 Australian students and opportunities to those students to achieve tertiary places which are currently open only to students from other countries. It is with those arguments in our minds that we have moved this second reading amendment. I commend it to the House.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)—Is the amendment moved by the honourable member for Goldstein seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
