"whilst welcoming the provisions of the Bill which return the responsibility for the administration of the Coal Mining Industry Long Service Leave Fund to the coal industry, the House is of the opinion that the long service leave provisions should not be limited to those employees to whom an award, determination, order or agreement applies".

The second part of the package comprises the other three Bills: the Coal Industry Amendment Bill; the Coal Research Assistance Amendment Bill and the Coal Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill. The first of those, the Coal Industry Amendment Bill, relates to a refining of the powers and a reduction, in effect, of the powers of the Joint Coal Board, which is the board which exists under legislation between the Federal Parliament and the New South Wales Parliament. I serve notice that I will seek to move to that a second reading amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

PARA.TAB: (1)notes that this legislation is complementary to legislation of the New South Wales Parliament; and

(2)calls on the Federal Government to negotiate with the New South Wales Government with a view to abolishing the Joint Coal Board and transferring the occupational and health and other key components to industry managed bodies".

SPEECH.PARA: The second Bill, the Coal Research Assistance Amendment Bill, restructures the research arrangements and effectively privatises the research arrangements of the coal industry in a most satisfactory way. The final Bill, the Coal Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill, abolishes the coal export duty levy. Under the terms of the guillotine, I have to serve notice on the House that I would propose to move to the Coal Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

PARA.TAB: (1)notes that the Government has adopted in the Bill one of the seven key tax abolition planks of `Fightback'; and
(2)calls on the Government to implement the other six key tax abolition planks of `Fightback', among them being the abolition of payroll tax, sales tax and fuel excise tax".

SPEECH.PARA: So I have placed before the House the nature of the debate. I think it is a great pity that seven large pieces of legislation on the coal industry, arguably one of Australia's most important export industries in terms of revenue—at this time, the most important—have all now been lumped together and are to be pushed through the Parliament in the next one hour and fifty minutes through to 12.20 a.m. tomorrow. At the sad end of the autumn session, the twilight moments of the autumn session, in this mad rush to comply with Senate requirements, we have one of the major packages of legislation on the coal industry.

PARA.TAB: In respect of that aspect, the coalition is not opposed to the three Bills to which I am specifically referring. They constitute, in general terms, a correct step forward by the Government; in some parts, they constitute a stealing of coalition policy. But equally they represent the outcome of a number of deliberations over recent years. I commend many aspects of the legislation before the House.

Specifically on the Coal Industry Amendment Bill, we have this situation which, I must say, is curious in the extreme. The Australian Parliament has decided to link up with just one other State for the purposes of formulating the Joint Coal Board. This happened just after World War II at a time when there was a very small coal industry in other States and a slightly larger coal industry in New South Wales. Each year we have an annual report of the Joint Coal Board, which is made available to the Prime Minister of Australia and the Premier of New South Wales, when other States that have now developed major coal industries are not parties to, in a direct sense, the Joint Coal Board.

We have a completely separate Queensland Coal Board, which produces—it is a bit of a worry—an even larger and more glossy report than the Joint Coal Board. It is this free-standing State level board which carries out considerable work on research. It probably does not, on that score, replicate what happens with the Joint Coal Board, but equally it is, in a sense, a convoluted structure associated with one of Australia's most important exporting industries—an industry performing against considerable difficulty in a very competitive international trading place.

I put it to the House that at some stage the Government—if this Government does not, the next one will—must go back to negotiate with the New South Wales Parliament and the New South Wales Government. We accept that we do not have the right to take unilateral action. It would have to be something done in liaison. Those negotiations would be undertaken with a view to winding up the Joint Coal Board and restructuring its arrangements where best they might go, particularly the occupational health dimensions, which are extremely important and not to be underestimated. Yet if they are all that important, why is it that we have a Joint Coal Board operating only in respect of New South Wales and federally, and not, in a sense, picking up on the very large coal industry, open-cut and underground, in Queensland, Victoria, to a lesser extent South Australia at Leigh Creek, Western Australia and even dear old Tasmania, where there is a boutique coal industry, although Tasmanians probably would not care for my describing it in those terms?

I put it to the House that the time has come, in the middle of this recession that we did not have to have, to think long and hard about this industry structure. Whilst I know that some of the colleagues of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) and the Minister himself will jealously defend the fiefdom and the performance of the Joint Coal Board and say that this is another untouchable which has been there since 1946 and should be allowed to plough on into the future, I also accept that the Minister accepts the challenge that change is upon us in many policy areas. I would hope he would agree with the tenet that there is not an automatic blank cheque for joint organisational boards and quangos, that they are, from time to time, the subject of proper review to see whether their functions relate to the requirements of industry and government and the impact of change which has arisen since the last review.

It is in that context that I am certain there is a case now to completely restructure and revamp the Joint Coal Board. The industry is of that mind in general terms, although it is very careful how, when, where and how loudly it states that particular objective—and I understand the reasons for that. I do not want to dwell on this issue because of the time factor. I simply put before the House the forty-fourth annual report of the Joint Coal Board and the annual report of the Queensland Coal Board and say that there goes Australia again with non-meshing arrangements associated with such an important industry.

The second dimension I wish to put before the House relates to the export potential of the coal industry. Undeniably, Japan is an extremely important customer for Australian coal. Korean, Taiwanese, north-east Asian, European and other markets are opening up. In January I visited Korea and Japan. I looked at the coal market and at other energy aspects such as transport, primary industry export prospects and the political and economic circumstances of those two countries.

Interestingly, some factors are moving in favour of Australian agriculture and, to a lesser extent, Australian coal, although there are some fierce competitors on the horizon. Three factors are involved. These include, firstly, the fact that the environmental circumstances in South Korea and Japan are becoming more and more critical with regard to the quality of coal and the quality of food products being sent there; secondly, the greater urbanisation that is taking place means that a lot of agricultural land has been taken out of production and that gives us more chance to compete agriculturally; and, thirdly, there is a growing middle class in Korea and Japan with discretionary spending power which it is not ploughing into real estate because of certain structural aspects of those economies. A great deal is being spent by individual consumers on energy requirements and higher grade food, such as steak, noodles made from wheat and the like. Once again, Australia has a great potential for being the major exporter to north-east Asia both in terms of clean and fresh Australian agricultural products and our quality coal because we have, over the years, carved out a niche in that regard.

I remind the House that it was John McEwen, a former Leader of the National Party and then Minister for Trade who, in 1957, against the opposition of elements of the Labor Party and the RSL of the day—we must remember that it was only 12 years after World War II—forged a trade treaty between Australia and Japan which provided the basis for much of the Queensland economic growth that has occurred in the last two or three decades as well as a great deal of Australian economic growth, Japan being our major trading partner.

In terms of the prospects for coal exports, north-east Asia remains a major focus for the industry, as does Europe. I say further to the House that there is one thing that we have not yet heard from the Europeans, although we have heard some slight good news from them in the last week in respect of the common agricultural policy, the CAP. We have not heard too much from the Germans about their deep underground coal subsidy levels and alterations to that coal subsidy because the quantum of that subsidy is unbelievably high. I think it exceeds the actual cost of production of an average tonne of Australian coal. Germany will have to face the music on that before much longer. I raised that issue with Chancellor Kohl when I met him in May last year in Crete for the Battle of Crete reunion. I took the opportunity to pursue both the CAP and coal industry issues. Hopefully some progress will be made and Germany will make adjustments to its coal mining subsidy levels in the interests of the Uruguay Round of GATT trade negotiations and progressing the trading circumstances of the world.

The third dimension I wish to put before the Parliament concerns the importance of research. The changes that the Minister has brought forward under the Coal Research Assistance Amendment Bill represent a privatisation, an industry-controlled fund with certain requirements and obligations. The Bill puts in place safety nets. One of the good fortunes of the coal industry is that it has been a very progressive industry. It has not always got every decision right, especially with regard to transport infrastructure, but equally it has come a long way in the last four decades and all Australians have benefited from that coal industry research. The general reform and boost in productivity is detailed quite clearly in both reports to which I have referred, one of them being the report of the Joint Coal Board which shows that between 1984 and 1991 the annual output per employee increased from about 2,900 tonnes saleable to about 4,700 tonnes. We now have to match best world practice, not just comparable Australian practice. Hopefully, further research and a restructuring of the research effort will provide for that.

The Coal Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill removes the $50m-odd coal export duty, which is a direct tax on exports and is long overdue for removal. It caught a particular seam of coal, mainly in Queensland, between certain depths—so well it was targeted as a profit creaming-off tax. Item No. 7 of the Fightback package, a copy of which I just happen to have in my pocket, states very clearly:

SPEECH.PARA: Coal export duty abolished!
Eliminates $49 million tax on one of our major export industries.

We are delivering on that and have provided a funded basis for removing the coal export duty. I would like the Minister to nominate tonight where he will make up the $45m difference. It depends on how it is calculated for the particular year of production.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put it on Bankcard.

—Is it going to be put beyond the nation's Bankcard borrowing limit? Is a special area of taxation to be nominated, such as an increase in alcohol excise tax, a tobacco excise tax or a fuel excise tax? Minister Willis and Treasurer Dawkins today were dancing around on the very question of a tax increase in the next Budget. They have not categorically ruled out a tax increase. Is the Government just going to fudge the books and say, `This is on the never-never and we will provide the funding requirement for the abolition out of the enhanced increased economic growth.'?

PARA.TAB: It is true that the Government negotiated a package to provide certain additional effort from BHP, which it may have intended to undertake anyway, in relation to the coal industry. It is a very progressive company. I do not think it has to be dragooned into these matters. It is correct policy to abolish the coal export duty. It is in the Government's nature to do a deal and stitch it into a locked-in package of arrangements. We will abolish it. We also welcome the additional investment expenditure by BHP. But that does not answer the question of how exactly the Government intends to fund the additional $50m blow-out on a Budget deficit which has already gone from a prediction in Kerin's Budget last August of $4.6 billion to $6.8 billion and then to $9.3 billion last week.

It is not a lightly placed question injected into this debate to ask the Minister how this aspect is being funded in detailed terms. I look forward to the Minister's reply. I reaffirm that the Government has stolen one of the seven key planks embraced by Fightback to abolish sales tax, petroleum and fuel excise taxes, payroll tax, lump sum superannuation tax, the training guarantee levy and customs duty. Coal export duty was dealt with under item 7 of the Fightback package. The Government has stolen that plank. We will commend to the Government by way of a second reading amendment that it steal the other six and fund them in the process because all Australians will be the winners from such an approach. Export industries in particular will be the winners. The coal export duty was a direct tax on exports.

The Deputy Secretary to Senator Button's Department, Dr John Bell, has pointed out on a number of occasions that the average disadvantage rate created for all our exports as a consequence of the sales tax and related regimes was 5 per cent. That is not my figure; it comes from the Deputy Secretary to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. By abolishing all sales tax, bringing in a VAT and zero rating that VAT so far as coal industry and other exports are concerned, we will provide a framework for further export enhancement and stimulus to our key export industries.

I know the guillotine is being applied and that others want to speak on this important legislation, which will not be opposed by the Opposition. The coalition, as always, will be very responsible, particularly in relation to this huge decentralised export industry.

There are missing links in the industry. One of those is the Goonyella-Newlands railway link from Riverside North in the middle of Queensland. This did not come up for mention in the One Nation statement, but if it were put in place, it would give a three-way linkage to the Queensland coal industry's northern port of Abbot Point and provide some security, flexibility and enhanced exporting capacity. It is something less than 80 kilometres. There have been some studies looking into it, and currently studies are going on. I mention that to the House.

I also say to the House that our second reading amendments, to be moved by myself and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), will in fact pick up on these points. I understand I am duty bound to move the first of those amendments at this time. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"whilst welcoming the provisions of the Bill which return the responsibility for the administration of the Coal Mining Industry Long Service Leave Fund to the coal industry, the House is of the opinion that the long service leave provisions should not be limited to those employees to whom an award, determination order or agreement applies".
In the context of the guillotine, I have moved that amendment.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Dubois)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Coal Mining Industry (Long Service Leave Funding) Bill, the Coal Mining Industry (Long Service Leave) Payroll Levy Bill, the Coal Mining Industry (Long Service Leave) Payroll Levy Collection Bill, the States Grants (Coal Mining Industry Long Service Leave) Amendment Bill, the Coal Industry Amendment Bill, the Coal Research Assistance Amendment Bill and the Coal Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill, I wish to say that the contribution of the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) is partly thought through and well indicates the difficulty in talking about the coal industry.

PARA.TAB: The coal industry is not the coal industry; it is several different industries. Essentially it is an export industry divided between coking coal and steaming coal. That is then divided, in each of those categories, between open cut coal and underground coal. The domestic industry is split into coking coal and steaming coal, and again each of those categories is split into underground coal and open cut coal. Effectively we have 10 different industries. It is always generalised and talked about as though we are talking about one industry. Our great difficulty is that 70 per cent of our coal that is mined goes to export. We are a very high export proportion country and, as such, we are very vulnerable to changes in export prices.

As long as we have in this country a disorganised, fragmented selling basis, as we now have, and as long as our largest customer—who buys over 50 per cent of our coal—is buying on an organised, highly regimented buying basis, we will be exploited and we will never get the best value for this country. I do not care what is said on this side of the House or on the other side of the House, I have seen it for too many decades—we will be taken to the cleaners at one stage or another over and over again. One only has to go back to the statement, published in the Australian of 11 May, of Mr Bob Flew of BHP Australia Coal Ltd at the recent coal conference where he cautioned:

SPEECH.PARA: Local producers of thermal coal should be cautious and limit their investment in new projects in order to maintain profitability.
He went on:

To avoid a repeat of the mistakes of the 1980s, Australian producers or potential producers of thermal coal should adopt a cautious view of bullish world energy projections, and restrict investments to projects low on the production cost curve that will remain profitable through the extremes of normal economic cycles.

Be sure of this: there will be extremes and they come in cycle after cycle. I have seen them several times. The bullish talk that is about now about expanding coal production and opening up new mines is the classic ploy that has been used, essentially by Japan, to create a bullish market, to engender new production and then, when overproduction comes, to use that overproduction as a means of forcing down the price, leading to the closure of more Australian mines.

PARA.TAB: We want efficient, competitive production in this country, and we are well on the way to getting that. But we cannot get the best out of our vital natural resource of coal as long as we operate in a totally disorganised, fragmented selling manner where Australian producer competes against Australian producer to the benefit of external purchaser. I would have liked very much to have heard something from the Leader of the National Party about that. Many miners live in country electorates, but not one word was mentioned by the Leader of the National Party about the welfare of miners and their families. I think that says a lot.

Similarly, in respect of the Joint Coal Board, having had to deal with this industry over the years and having close family connections with the industry, I know that miners are Australians, I know the dangerous conditions under which they work, I know the agony they go through in times of tension and pressure like other Australian workers, but they are demeaned and categorised in a manner by those opposite that makes them think that they are some sort of alien beings. The Joint Coal Board, through all that process of tension within the industry, is the one organisation that has always been trusted by both sides of the industry.

Let me say that this package of Bills deals with change in the coal industry, and change has been an ongoing process in the coal industry since the first coal was gathered from the shores of Nobbys and exported to Bengal in 1801. I have reservations about some aspects of the legislation, particularly the gutting of the Joint Coal Board. However, since this resulted from an agreement between all the parties, only time will tell whether my fears are justified.

Miners in the Hunter have embraced workplace changes over recent years which have brought substantial increases in productivity. In 1990-91 the Hunter produced 69.27 million tonnes of coal, equivalent to 86 per cent of New South Wales coal production or 42 per cent of Australian production, mixed between domestic sales and export sales. In 1991 each miner in the Hunter produced an average of 5,014 tonnes of coal, compared with 3,750 tonnes of coal in 1986-87, an increase of 1,264 tonnes of coal per miner per year, or an increase of 34 per cent.

Yet, despite that productivity increase and ongoing improvements in the industry's production processes, miners are losing their jobs and losing their careers as mines continue to close in the northern district. Between 1986-87 and 1990-91, the number of coal employees in the Hunter was cut from 12,634 to 10,477, a reduction of 17 per cent or 2,157 jobs.

Mine closures can result from the working out of seams or expensive and insurmountable difficulties in the extraction of coal. That can be accepted. But in many cases managerial short-sightedness, managerial incompetence and, in some cases, just plain greed have resulted in premature mine closures and the squandering of millions of tonnes of valuable and non-renewable coal reserves. That irresponsible behaviour by coal proprietors, and the lack of a comprehensive energy or coal mining strategy at either State or Federal level, is allowing millions of tonnes of coal to be left in the ground to be wasted, to be squandered.

The continuing loss of jobs and the waste or sterilisation of an increasing quantity of our vital reserves are what have brought more than 100 miners from the Hunter to this Parliament today. Earlier this evening, along with my colleagues the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) and the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), I met with Mr Mick Watson, the President of the Northern District Branch of the United Mineworkers Federation of Australia. Earlier, miners from our region held a lamp vigil outside and above this place. They are here as part of their Survival '92 campaign, a non-industrial campaign aimed at securing the future of the coal industry in the Hunter region.

The Hunter has been hit hard by the short-sightedness, the `Rip it out and sell it to the first bidder, and to hell with the workers!' approach of mine management, which has led to the closure of still commercially viable mines, mines that still had a part to play in Australia's economic prosperity. Lemington Colliery is to close on 1 July. It has 2.4 million tonnes of coal reserves. Bloomfield Colliery is soon to close. It has 7.5 million tonnes of coal reserves. Lambton Colliery, in my own electorate, closed in December 1991. It had 5.5 million tonnes of coal reserves. All three mines have suffered or will suffer from sterilisation because there are no care or maintenance programs under way.

If a mine is shut completely it suffers from rock falls, water seepage and gas build-up. Thus that coal is lost and it is uneconomic to retrieve it. These three closures follow the closure of Burwood, John Darling, Stockton, Wallsend, Stockrington and Aberdare in recent years. More recently, in April, 27 miners were retrenched without warning from the Preston Colliery. The closures of Lemington and Bloomfield will add 250 miners to the retrenched list.

Many other underground mines have suffered heavily with retrenchments. In my own electorate there are seven underground mines, a number of which risk closure and loss of jobs due to the ruthless policy of privatisation from the Greiner Government of New South Wales and in one other case due, I think, to the working out of the seam.

In Gunnedah a critical situation has been reached where the mine may close if the State Government does not assist with more equitable rail freight charges. If it does not, there may not be funds available to pay out employees. This highlights the need to have an industry fund scheme to ensure that moneys are available to pay employees their proper entitlements in the event of mine closure.

In the Survival '92 campaign being mounted by the Miners Federation it is calling for the need for an effective government policy for the future management of our coal resources, thus ensuring a balance between underground and open cut extraction, together with a critical review of any application for new developments. That is good commonsense. I support it. It is in Australia's interests.

It expresses the need for a bipartisan overviewing body to ensure that coal price negotiations are conducted under guidelines framed to end results which are in the best interests of the industry as a whole. Again, that request points in my view to the immaturity and the incompetence of many of Australia's coal exporters.

It calls for an advance warning system whereby operations which have had foreseeable problems can be reviewed and solutions sought before the axe falls. Lastly, when all other alternatives to closure and retrenchment have been explored and failed, it calls for a significant government subsidy scheme for the retraining and relocation of displaced mineworkers. There is an element of assistance already available in that area. There are about 1,000 more jobs that could be lost in the Newcastle-Hunter region in the year ahead. If we take the multiplier effect of that at 3.5 : 1, we are looking at the loss of some 4,500 jobs in the Hunter. They are jobs that will disappear unless there is an improvement in conditions.

As I come to the conclusion of my remarks in this limited debate, I wish to quote from the editorial of the Newcastle Herald, which was the Newcastle Herald and Miners Advocate in earlier years. This journal is not known for radical viewpoints, particularly on issues such this. The editorial of 16 May 1992 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A wasteful loss of coal

There is something frighteningly cavalier about the way Hunter underground coal mines are being closed because they are not, for the moment, profitable. Coal companies and governments appear to have forgotten the lessons of mining history. That is a more charitable explanation than the alternative that they do not really care that valuable national resources could be made irrecoverable by their actions. . . Hundreds, and probably thousands, of millions of tonnes of coal have been effectively sterilised by wasteful mining practices in nearly two centuries of coal recovery in the Hunter. With the sophisticated mining techniques available today, there is little excuse for sterilising coal. That costs have exceeded prices for a year or two is certainly no excuse for such a wasteful action.

In the last part of the editorial it goes on to say that mine owners should not be forced to continue mining coal at a loss, but that, instead of closing mines and locking away coal reserves for good, they could adopt the sensible proposal of the United Mineworkers Federation to put mines on a care-and-maintenance basis. The editorial calls for a small industry levy, preferably administered by a restrengthened Joint Coal Board, that could pay for the scheme which, in the long term, should return much more than its cost. That is good sense, Mr Deputy Speaker. It needs to be addressed in the national interest.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I refer to the remarks of the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) in respect of the Joint Coal Board and occupational health and safety. If there is one industry in this country where employers cannot be trusted in respect of safe working practices, it is the mining industry. I ask members of this chamber to go down the mines from time to time and have a look for themselves at the working conditions. They should have a look at the structures; have a look at the roof works; have a look at the conditions under which men are clambering around and working. The Leader of the National Party is saying, `Leave it to the mine managers and the mining industry'. That is why we have a Joint Coal Board. I am strongly of the view that occupational health and safety practices should remain with the Joint Coal Board.

I think it is irresponsible, insulting and dangerous for the Leader of the National Party, who represents many miners in this country, to be suggesting that the mining industry has the sense of responsibility to look after occupational health and safety. There may be some exceptions, but I strongly oppose the view he is putting. I commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution will be very brief. I support the second reading amendment to the Coal Mining Industry (Long Service Leave Funding) Bill proposed by my colleague the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: "whilst welcoming the provisions of the Bill which return the responsibility for the administration of the Coal Mining Industry Long Service Leave Fund to the coal industry, the House is of the opinion that the long service leave provisions should not be limited to those employees to whom an award, determination order or agreement applies".

Our view is that this represents yet another limb of what amounts to de facto compulsory membership of unions in the industry. I know my friends opposite pretend it does not exist, but it does exist in large lumps right through Australian industry, and we have moved this second reading amendment in accordance with our longstanding opposition to that. As my colleague the Leader of the National Party has argued the case in relation to our general approach to this legislation, I simply wanted to make the point that the reason for proposing this second reading amendment is to emphasise yet again the total rejection of any kind of compulsory unionism by the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: The commercial building industry is an even better example than the coal industry of the undoubted malady of compulsory unionism in Australian society. The commercial building industry is absolutely notorious for the `no ticket, no start' rule. We would never have had the scandal of what has been unearthed and spelt out in such clarity by the Royal Commission of Mr Roger Gyles in Sydney today—we would never have had the collusion, the rorts, the rip-offs, the thuggery, the dishonesty, the cheating and all the other things that have gone on in the building industry in New South Wales and in Victoria—if we had not had the notorious `no ticket, no start' rule.

My friend the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), who is at the table, knows that. I know he does not like contractors. I can remember a notorious occasion when he turned down an invitation to a function because some man who led a contracting organisation in the United States had been invited to make an address. It was a function to celebrate the centenary of the commercial building industry in Melbourne, and he turned down the invitation because the organisers had the temerity to invite a man from the United States who had once led a contracting organisation. I think it was an American version of Troubleshooters. I know that my friend opposite does not like Troubleshooters.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not right.
—You do like Troubleshooters?
—I have had a number of dealings with them.
—I have dealt with a lot of people I do not like, too.
—Do not stretch the point.
—Why are you legislating against them?
—We are not.
—You are. You are legislating to destroy them in your contractors Bill.
—That is your version.
—That is true. The State secretary of Peter Cook's union said so.
—You are wrong.
—I am not wrong. Are you saying the State secretary of your union is wrong?
—I am talking about the amendment, too.
—I am talking about the State secretary of your union.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Dubois)—Order! The honourable member should not respond to interjections.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enjoy them, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am being provoked. You should protect me.
—I am trying to protect you.

—If you do not want me to respond to interjections at this hour of the night, Mr Deputy Speaker, you ought to protect me. I am intimidated occasionally by the honourable gentleman opposite. I will defer to your ruling. I simply want to make the point that anything that smacks of compulsory unionism is odious to the Opposition. It is odious if it is compulsory membership of the Law Society or the Australian Medical Association. In case the Minister in his reply says, `What are you going to do about membership of professional bodies?', let me say that I have dealt with that. I have already told the Law Society of New South Wales, of which I am a member, that the legislation we bring in after the next election to get rid of compulsory membership of trade unions will apply with equal force to compulsory membership of professional bodies.

PARA.TAB: I certainly will not be in the business of going around the country saying that it is wrong to force people to join unions but it is perfectly all right to force people, as a precondition to practising law or medicine in this country, to join a professional organisation. I think that is equally odious. Whilst I have no objection to parliament's giving disciplinary authority to those bodies, I have every objection to those bodies using that authority to force people to become members of those organisations as a precondition to practising.

I commend this amendment to the House. It is a reminder of our policy on compulsory unionism. To find a quintessential example of how compulsory unionism has destroyed an industry, one need look no further than the building industry in Sydney, the maladies and sins of which have been exposed all over the media of Australia in the last 24 hours. We certainly have not heard the last in this place of that exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —This nation must have a wide-ranging debate on the coal industry. I had hoped that we would have that debate tonight. However, these coalmining industry Bills are under guillotine and, tragically, I have no opportunity to address crucial issues such as changes to the Joint Coal Board and long service leave provisions.

PARA.TAB: I have no problem with the long service leave legislation—as a matter of fact, I applaud it—but I am spitting chips about the emasculation of the Joint Coal Board. The Board played a splendid role, and still has a vital role to play, in promoting a prosperous and profitable coal industry, and a safe coal industry. It angers me that this coalmining industry debate has not been given the same length of time as other debates on important industries such as wool and wheat. We need time for the Parliament to debate the type of nonsense spoken by the Opposition. I cannot understand why people would come out and castigate miners to the extent that they do.

We have the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) racing around the countryside talking about trains, but also, in lighter moments, serving out a decent swipe at the miners. What those opposite want to do is abolish completely the Joint Coal Board. What they want to do is wipe from the face of the earth the Coal Industry Tribunal. Furthermore, they want to abolish completely this Federal Government's right to veto coal export sales which are not in the national interest. Honestly, one could only form the conclusion that those opposite do not care a hoot about the miners. They do not care a hoot about the safety of miners, because, after all, miners are labourers, and labourers are an alien spirit in the minds of those opposite.

We know that the conservative colleagues of the Leader of the National Party protect their natural constituency—the top end of town. They will never give a sympathetic thought to the mining fraternity. Coal is a national industry and our nation's major export earner. But, as is so often the case, within an industry there is plenty of competition—competition from other coal-producing countries and regional competition from within.

I represent a New South Wales constituency in which coal is crucial to economic well-being, a constituency in which coal is crucial to employment. Coal has had its boom times and its bust times. It has had its roof falls, fires, dustings, gassings, explosions and deaths. Coal went through mechanisation, which cut a swathe through its work force. Coal towns stood poised to become ghost towns.

Some coal areas succumbed to trials, tribulations and tragedies. Coal in those areas lost its crown. But coal survived in the Hunter Valley of New South Wales and coal remains king in Cessnock, Maitland, Kurri Kurri, Singleton, Newcastle, Muswellbrook and many other Hunter cities and towns. In retaining its crown, the coal industry has given birth to the finest and friendliest body of men and women it would be possible to meet.

In speaking on these Bills I represent the interests of the coalminers in the Hunter Valley, and I do so with a great deal of pride. I mentioned earlier that there is plenty of competition with the Australian coal industry from other countries. I mention also that there is plenty of competition within Australia, coming from different coal producing regions. We are indeed one nation, and it is important that we think of ourselves as such and work together in the national interest. However, within every country there will be a degree of regional competition, which can be healthy in some instances. For instance, it was competition which caused the Hunter to develop and become the promoter and producer of the finest wine that this nation or any other nation can produce. However, regional competition will be healthy in the Australian coalmining industry only if each region is given the opportunity to operate on the level playing field and State and Federal governments strive to ensure that any reforms effected satisfy a number of criteria which create a fair and safe working environment for miners.

Coalmining presents a harsh and hazardous working environment, particularly in underground mines. Historically, that environment has been made even less attractive because of the difficult relationships between miners and management. Those relationships have improved dramatically in recent times, but miners have long memories and it is not surprising that they are fiercely protective of hard-won rights and benefits.

To return to the subject of regional competition in the coal industry, it is the time to say that the greatest threat to the New South Wales coal industry and the jobs within it is the Queensland coal industry. Bearing that in mind, it is not surprising that coalminers in the Hunter Valley did not clap their hands in glee when the Minister signed a memorandum of understanding with BHP-Utah Coal Ltd, effectively abolishing the coal export levy. The coal export duty was an inequitable and potentially distortional tax. Since 1984 only six open-cut mines operated by BHP-Utah have paid the export duty. Levied at $3.50 per tonne on exported coal, the tax raised about $48m per year. Because it had taxes of $48m per year waived, BHP-Utah gave in return. The company provided commitments to invest $248m over the next five years. That is a fair deal because, instead of paying the tax, the company will effect significant efficiency gains, improve regional employment opportunities and provide environmental benefits for Queensland.

That is the crux of the matter. I told 200 miners outside this House this evening, when they hooted and shouted about the deal we did for the abolition of the coal export duty which benefited Queensland, that only six mines in Australia were paying that duty, that they were all in Queensland and that that was not a fair crack of the whip. Maybe they understood that, but when we mention Queensland we must understand the psychology of the New South Wales miners, who correctly see the Queensland mining industry as the greatest threat to mining in New South Wales.

My Minister is certainly justified in seeing these arrangements as typifying the mutual gains that can be made when governments work closely with industry to remove sectoral impediments. However, as I have said, many miners in the Hunter and other coal areas of New South Wales believe that the deal arranged with BHP-Utah had a ripple effect which rocked and may well wreck the viability of underground mines in New South Wales.

It is significant, and probably a coincidence, that BHP-Utah, flush with funds due to the repeal of the coal export duty, led the field in the most recent contract settlement with Japanese buyers. BHP-Utah's capitulation and premature acceptance of the low coal prices offered placed an increased and dangerous pressure on New South Wales mines which were producing similar ranked coal.

A few underground mines in the Hunter have hit the wall, and there is a very real fear that other underground mines will be forced to make severe cutbacks in present employment levels. The long term future for the Hunter coal industry is most promising, with major developments planned in new mine areas. However, the new mine openings are some time away and the ranks of out-of-work miners could swell to intolerable levels in the short term.

Unemployment in the recession-hit Hunter Valley is above the national average, and massive job losses in the mining sector would have a catastrophic effect on the local communities. The economic rationalists have decimated the textile and clothing industry work force in the Hunter. We as a government must make certain that we prevent the coal mines in the Hunter and other areas of New South Wales going down the same path.

The executive members of the United Mineworkers Federation of Australia have displayed admirable restraint and exhibited a large degree of sound commonsense in embarking on a campaign to assist its cause. The northern miners are worried about their position, but they have not attempted to flex their industrial muscle. Survival '92 is a sensible but desperate cry for help—help to maintain our greatest export industry. Miners are quietly and rationally gathering community support for their position, through a public education campaign, to heighten awareness of the extent to which every community in the Hunter is dependent on coal incomes.

If we take away the jobs of the miners and the jobs of the men and women in industries related to mining, the Hunter Valley will become an economic wasteland. The mining unions are acting very responsibly in seeking to work in harmony with the Federal and State governments and the Coal Association to minimise the employment consequences of short term difficulties. I and my colleagues who represent coal mining areas in New South Wales will be calling on the Government to assist unemployed miners as jobs go.

It is imperative that this Government provide structural adjustment funds. Appropriate structural adjustment funds must be made available to cater for the needs of mining communities. Appropriate structural adjustment funds must be made available to ensure that irreplaceable general mining skills are not lost. The mining industry has been fortunate in having the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) and the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean) as successive Ministers for Primary Industries and Energy. Both Ministers have worked tirelessly to assist the mining industry. But the position remains that companies are closing marginal mines in the search for cheaper coal, thereby losing forever hundreds of millions of tonnes of coal remaining in those mines—coal which will never be recovered. The mines will never be reopened.

We must find solutions which will stabilise the coal industry and protect for future generations those valuable coal reserves which will otherwise be lost. This Parliament and this nation need the establishment of a review body, made up of representatives of government, owners and union representatives, to ensure that this country's coal resources are mined and managed responsibly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will confine myself to a few very brief remarks in the short time available to me now. I want to make those remarks in the context of being a representative of people involved in coalmining in the northern end of New South Wales, around Gunnedah. Interestingly enough, it is not generally acknowledged as a coal producing area; yet the proven reserves of high quality coal in the Gunnedah coal basin are in excess of 40 billion tonnes—more coal than exists in the Hunter Valley.

PARA.TAB: As one who represents the area from Muswellbrook north, I have something of an interest in this matter. I would like to highlight some of my concerns. A particular concern that I have relates to the mining of underground coal, and I will turn to that in a moment.

I refute any suggestion by the two speakers from the other side of the House who have spoken in this debate that we on this side are not concerned about the future of the coal industry. I regard the development of the Gunnedah coal basin, for example, as critical to future prosperity and the job opportunities for young people—often, tragically, young farmers who have no future on their own places. It is of vital importance to the local economy.

The trouble is, of course, that underground mining in particular faces some particularly difficult problems. To that end, outside the House today a group of people attempted to highlight some of the problems that they face. A recent editorial in the Namoi Valley Independent summed it up in these terms:

The mining industry is never stable. It is a turbulent industry, with high labour and recovery costs and variable returns. In the last decade, there have been only short periods when the industry has been in the black. The traditional underground mining methods have come under increasing pressure, because of the higher labour component, the complexities of extraction, the physical barriers, such as dykes and extrusions in the coal seams, and the variable quality. As pressure grows on returns to coal producers, underground mining becomes a less attractive option. The point has been reached where virtually every underground mine in Australia is struggling for survival and all the expansion is occurring in open cut mines.
That explains why close to $60 million has been spent at the Vickery open cut near Gunnedah . . . and why 27 miners were laid off at Preston underground mine last week.

The long-term danger, though, is that years, perhaps decades, down the track, the state's easily accessible coal will have been worked out. Perhaps, by then, alternative power sources will have been found—

SPEECH.PARA: certainly not under this Government, but they may be found—

and coal extraction, by any means, will no longer be needed. But what will happen if coal is still the main power and energy source? All the "easy" reserves will have been exhausted and mining companies will have to resort to underground extraction. By that time, however, the expertise and methodology in underground mining, built up over more than 100 years, will have disappeared.
The editorial goes on to say:
Governments have a poor track record in industry assistance. The coal mining industry could tear itself to shreds, unless a concerted effort is made to restore profitability.
I think we would all concur with that. The editorial continued:
As it was pointed out recently, it's no consolation to retrenched miners for Gunnedah to be known as the Coalfield of the Future. There is no future, unless the industry is able to survive.

Lest I be accused again by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) of being on another union bash—although he always seems to follow me in these debates, he preceded me today; and he always makes the point that I raise these issues—I will be very quick to point out that I frankly believe that many of the union representatives who have to deal with companies and workers in the Gunnedah area in respect of these issues have been extremely responsible. I commend them for it. In fact, I could go so far as to say that the companies that have had to deal with them would want that to be acknowledged and put on the record. I have met with some of those representatives. I will meet with them again both tomorrow and, when I have the opportunity, back in my home area.

PARA.TAB: I have to say that some of the confrontationist and misleading information dished up by some other more remote union representatives serves to do nothing other than keep alive the old hatreds and irrelevancies and, if you like, even the old nonsensical class distinctions based on some sort of belief that somehow we must fight and compete amongst ourselves rather than playing as a team and opposing other teams. Of course, in an export industry that means basically opposing those nations with which we compete for markets in places such as Japan.

I find referred to me, from a magazine entitled Common Cause, an article by the General Secretary—I do not see any point in naming him here—which causes me some distress. It is headed, `Keating and Hewson offer us a real and vital choice'. That, of course, is true: there is a real and vital choice. The General Secretary goes on to say that that has not been the case during most of the 1980s. He claims that the two parties have been very close to one another and that the differences have been hard to distinguish. However, he says that it is essential that we now understand clearly that there is a great difference and that we need to look at those issues.

That is fine as far as it goes. The problem is that he misrepresents the differences. He misrepresents our position and, I believe, very clearly fails to highlight the advantages that even the Government's own Treasury indicates will flow to the mining industry and, therefore, short circuits the debate. It is reminiscent of the lately departed Minister, Senator Richardson, who, in the town of Mudgee, recently incited a group of Labor people on a delegation not to worry about debating the issues of the Opposition's goods and services tax proposals rationally. He said, `Just use fear. That's all you've got to do; use fear'. Of course, misinformation is the main vehicle by which fear can be promoted. Unfortunately, this article falls into that category. For example, the General Secretary states:
Labor sees the need for continued workplace reform and increased productivity to be achieved through the involvement of employers, unions and Government.

SPEECH.PARA: That is fine as far as it goes, but it overlooks the fact that we have seen precious little progress. This is confirmed by the recent OECD report on Australia which commented that our transport, ports and Public Service are still only about 50 per cent as efficient as similar services in foreign competitor nations. Where is the reform? Where is the sense of urgency?

PARA.TAB: The article goes on to say that the Government also favours decentralisation and growth in regional areas. I can only say that here we have clear evidence, in terms of the problems that the coal industry is facing in rural Australia, of just the opposite happening—the dying of the bush; the death of rural Australia—under the policies being pursued by the current Government. He goes on to say that his union is opposed to privatisation. He says:

Labor under Keating is still committed to an ongoing program of privatisation that our union does not agree with. However, the Labor program still retains public ownership of some of our biggest enterprises, such as Telecom.
Hewson's Liberals want to privatise all Government businesses, including massively profitable assets like Telecom.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that the recent OECD report, to which I just referred, indicated that Telecom was perhaps the least efficient and cost-effective of nine similar carriers which were studied recently by the OECD. The General Secretary goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: The big difference for most people in the economic policies of both Labor and the Liberals is taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, that is technically correct as well. He says:

PARA.TAB: Labor is opposed to a Goods and Services Tax (GST). The Economic Statement provides for middle income personal tax cuts;

SPEECH.PARA: He conveniently forgets to say that there are no tax cuts mentioned for low income earners. He also conveniently forgets to point out that those tax cuts increasingly look to be very elusive indeed, given that they were to be funded by bracket creep which now will not flow because of the lower inflationary estimates. The growth projections of 4.75 per cent were optimistic by anybody's standards, but in terms of the increase in growth, which we are now supposed to see and which will help to pay for those tax cuts, those tax cuts obviously become highly illusory indeed.

PARA.TAB: The General Secretary goes on to say, `Labor would retain payroll tax, excise and sales taxes'—as though that is something to boast about. He then goes on to point out that the Opposition wants to introduce a 15 per cent goods and services tax. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: This would be a harsh blow against the majority of Australians, but particularly cruel to those on fixed incomes, especially pensioners and the unemployed.

What I find offensive about this is that if he were really interested in a fair dinkum debate he would acknowledge that they are to be fully compensated. Even if he wanted to argue the point about whether it was adequate compensation, he makes no mention of the 8 per cent increase scheduled for pensioners and returned veterans, and 6 per cent for other beneficiaries. He goes on to say:
To sweeten the pill, Hewson offers personal tax cuts and the abolition of payroll tax, excise and sales tax.

There is no analysis of the value of those either to his members or to their prospects of retaining their employment opportunities. I think that is unfair, to put it mildly, and irresponsible in terms of his responsibility to his members and their needs and the obligation that he should have to put the reality before them.

PARA.TAB: But he saves his most serious representations, perhaps predictably, for the area of industrial relations. Of course, his line here is to simply and rather glibly point out that we are going to do a big New Zealand job here. He goes on to drag out all the old furphies: for example, wages have been slashed in New Zealand by 25 per cent. A quick look at today's Australian will establish that in most of the enterprise agreements that have been entered into in New Zealand there have been modest pay increases, which really puts a lie to the furphies that are being put about New Zealand, just to mention one thing alone.

We could look then at the other issues he raises. He says there have been massive cutbacks in social welfare, health and public education and that unemployed people in New Zealand often have to wait up to six months for benefits. Like so much of the scare campaign being run by the labour movement in its various guises, that completely overlooks the fact that New Zealand's crippling international debt—far worse even than ours in relative terms—has been primarily responsible for that collapse. In fact, the reforms it has undertaken are now beginning to bear fruit. He ought to have pointed that out.

It is highly significant that last month for the first time since 1973 New Zealand recorded a trade surplus. That really ought to be engraved on the heart of every Australian, because we still face chronic difficulties with no real evidence of a turnaround in this very critical area of our economic performance. New Zealand is slowly beginning to turn the corner. It has been through enormous difficulties, but in a way in which we can only admire in many respects it has tackled some of the enormous difficulties that it has faced. Nobody pretends it has been easy. Much of it in New Zealand has had anything but to do with the question of industrial relations and tax reform. It has had to do with the fact that New Zealand was in a far worse financial mess than we were when we started. But it is turning things around. A fair assessment of what is happening in New Zealand should acknowledge that. I leave that subject there.

I repeat that many of the unions and the union representatives involved in the problems of the northern coalfields have been highly responsible. But I make the point that if people such as the individual responsible for this article really have the interests of their members at heart and not just their own positions they ought to be keen to establish two general points of integrity. The first is that they need to be more honest about the Opposition's policies and to fall into line, if you like, with the Prime Minister's promise before Christmas when he became Prime Minister that from now on we would be honest with the Australian people. The second thing is, again in the context of his concern to do something about extracting a better deal from the Government, that he really ought to be saying, `What are you going to do to match the undoubted assistance for the coal industry that is contained in the policies of Fightback?'.

Let us look very briefly at some of the facts. Treasury's estimates of the savings for the mining industry come to almost $700m, mainly as a result of the abolition of payroll tax, fuel excise and the wholesale sales tax. The northern coalfields in my electorate quite simply would benefit enormously from the abolition of the seven taxes we are talking about here. I actually believe in all honesty, in all integrity, that it would mean the difference between opening and closing for many of them. It is as simple as that—jobs or no jobs.

One simple example is that for one company which is forking out $7m per annum in wages at the moment payroll tax savings come to $500,000 per year. Add the fuel excise plus the payroll tax abolition savings for rail and for trucking transport and we have an enormous equation of assistance by virtue of cutting costs, as I said a moment ago, that I frankly believe will mean the difference between survival and death for many of these mines and the jobs that go with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not have much time because my colleagues were generous and did not bother sticking to the agreed timetable. There are few industries more important to Australia than the coal industry, especially in the area I represent—the Illawarra area. I do not agree with the amendments of the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) regarding the Joint Coal Board. I think there is a health and safety issue there and I do not want to see the safety issues going to the owners.

PARA.TAB: I agree, though, with what the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) said about negotiations. Too often the people who are selling Australian coal go to Japan and sit around in hotel rooms in Tokyo waiting for a telephone call while the Japanese, who deal in a unified manner, play one off against the other.

DEBATE.TITLE: COAL MINING INDUSTRY (LONG SERVICE LEAVE) PAYROLL LEVY BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to address very briefly the Opposition's earlier amendment in regard to the long service leave provisions. There are two fundamental flaws in that amendment. Firstly, it misunderstands what the legislation in fact says. When the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was in the House—he is not now—he made some pretty wild allegations to the effect that the Bills were designed to provide the basis for compulsory unionism in the coal industry vis-a-vis long service leave. I draw his attention and that of the Opposition to the fact that, whilst the second reading speech did refer to awards of the Commission, it went on to recognise that, where such payments are made arising out of an obligation under a recognised enterprise or workplace agreement, reimbursement may also be claimed.

PARA.TAB: Quite frankly, I do not understand the purpose of that amendment brought forward by the Opposition tonight, because it really says that `long service leave provisions should not be limited to those employees to whom an award, determination order or agreement applies'. What is an enterprise agreement if it is not an agreement? The assertion that is being made is that somehow we have inveigled into this legislation some surreptitious approach to compulsory unionism. I simply point out that any attempt to read the legislation itself will show that the definition of `relevant industrial agreement' is, `an award or determination made, order given or agreement approved by or registered with, an industrial authority . . . '. The definition of `industrial authority' on the previous page includes the New South Wales Industrial Commission, which recognises industrial agreements that do not have to involve the union. So, as I say, not only is it creating straw men but also it is deliberately misleading to assert, as the honourable member for Bennelong did in his contribution, that these Bills provide for compulsory unionism.

It is also important to note that this legislation does not create of itself an entitlement to long service leave. It merely provides a means of guaranteeing funding of existing entitlements in the black coal mining industry, whether they arise under awards, agreements, enterprise agreements, individual contracts or any combination of these that are capable of being addressed under the State as well as the Commonwealth jurisdiction.
I make the additional point that the proposed arrangements have been agreed to by representatives of the employees and the employers.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (COAL MINING INDUSTRY LONG SERVICE LEAVE) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try not to take too long, but I am advised that this statement needs to be read to the House in relation to the long service leave reform package.

PARA.TAB: Since the Bills, which give effect to the Government's proposals to reform the funding of long service leave in the black coalmining industry, were introduced, representations have been received from the New South Wales Coal Association and the Queensland Mining Council about the meaning of the words used in paragraph (b) of the definition of `eligible employee' in clause 4 of the Coal Mining Industry (Long Service Leave Funding) Bill 1992.

The paragraph is coextensive with five other paragraphs in clause 4, which together provide the basis for determining which employees in the black coalmining industry are to be covered by the national scheme for securing funding of long service leave entitlements in the industry. Here I note in passing that the legislation does not itself create an entitlement to long service leave. The legislation merely provides for the creation of the fund, upon which employees will be able, as the need arises, to obtain reimbursement for funds made to eligible employees in respect of long service leave entitlements.

Concern has been expressed that the absence of the words `in the black coalmining industry' from the definition of `eligible employee' in paragraph (b) may be construed as having the effect of widening the definition to include persons not presently covered under longstanding arrangements within the industry. This is not the intended effect of the legislation. The words already appearing in the paragraph in question, when read together with the objects of the Act which are set out in clause 3 of the legislation, limit the classes of worker who may be regarded as eligible employees for the purposes of the Act to persons employed in the black coalmining industry. The addition of the words `in the black coalmining industry' to paragraph (b) accordingly serves no useful purpose.

The Government wishes to make it clear that it is not its intention to extend the coverage of the scheme beyond persons who are currently regarded as being engaged in the black coalmining industry. What may be described as the boundaries of the black coalmining industry vary within and between States and are to a significant extent determined by custom and practice reflecting a range of considerations.

The Bill, accordingly, provides for a means including or excluding limited numbers of workers from the scheme but not from entitlements to long service leave by regulation, as is provided under paragraphs (d) and (f) of clause 4. The Government will, reflecting the provisions of the legislation and the cooperative nature of the scheme, consult with representatives of all interests likely to be affected by the making of such legislation. This will allow the industry some flexibility in regulating its affairs, while safeguards to protect the interests of any individuals who may be affected are retained and regulations that are made in respect of the coverage of the scheme will of course be disallowable.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we are a little ahead of time, I will delay the House for a couple of minutes to finish the point that I was going to make before. The first point that I was going to make, which is related to the Coal Research Assistance Amendment Bill, is that I believe very strongly that we must have a national coal strategy in Australia. We have sterilised far too much of the coal in Australia. Underground pits in my area that have been left have now flooded. So much of Australia's coal has been sterilised.

PARA.TAB: I was going to agree with much of what the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) said until the last part of his speech. I agreed with him when he said that we do not know what the energy future holds for us. At some time we may need that coal, and some of the very best coal in Australia today is sterilised. We will never be able to recover that coal. That is a great pity. I have always argued that we should have not only a national energy policy in Australia, but also a national coal plan. We should know exactly where we are going with coal, what coal we have and what the long term future is.

I note that the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) talked about a railway line in Queensland. He knows this area. It was a criminal act that the Maldon-Dumbarton railway line in New South Wales was stopped. We are talking about export of coal. We have the coal loader at Port Kembla. We have that line half finished. A lot of the most difficult part is finished. If the New South Wales Government will not fund the line, I appeal to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), who is at the table, and the Federal Government to—

TALK.START.PARA: —One Nation.

—I was bitterly disappointed that it was not included in that document, and I have conveyed that to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I believe that we have to finish that line, which is a coal export line. It would stop those coal trains coming from the western fields, trundling through the Sydney suburban network and trundling down the south coast line, which is ready to fall down at any time. One would get all those coal lines off the Sydney suburban network and put them on the Maldon-Dombarton line and it would be a great boost to Australia's coal export trade. I urge that much more serious consideration be given to that.

PARA.TAB: It is a great tragedy that we have lost half the work force in the coal industry in the Illawarra area. But I am one who believes that coal has a great future. We must not go gung ho at it. As the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) has said, the Japanese have shown in the past that they talk up a production level. We overproduce and then they use that against us. I appeal to the Minister, as I have appealed to every Minister in his portfolio, not to listen to the bureaucrats on the National Coal Authority; they will shaft it. They have shafted it with every Minister. It is the only way that we can really get the correct price for coal and can negotiate. The Japanese understand negotiating from a united body. They do it to our negotiators there.

I ask the Minister to look very carefully at our having a national coal authority that can act in the selling of our coal, especially to the Japanese, and get the very best deal for Australia. I thank the House for letting me finish my few comments on this vital industry to Australia—the coal industry.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the amendment to the Coal Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill. I will not take too long in the House, but, given that the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) asked the question about coal export duty, I want to put a couple of things on the record.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, the Government did not adopt the coalition's statement in relation to the abolition of the coal export duty from Fightback. The negotiations with BHP-Utah commenced well in advance of Fightback being produced and correspondence that I have made public attests to that fact.

Secondly, the approach to us in relation to this tax makes a fundamental difference between what we say and deliver versus what the coalition promises. It should not be forgotten—and it has not been forgotten by the industry—that the promise the Opposition has in Fightback was also a promise it gave during the 1975 election which it did not deliver on in 1977 and, in fact, some time in the late 1970s, the Opposition increased the coal export duty.

The Opposition's credentials are not that good and that is understood by the industry. On the other hand, the Government said to the industry that it recognised the inefficiency, but wanted to address that impediment in the context of getting significant national interest benefits. The national interest was a $250m package commitment of investment in exchange for the forgoing of revenue of $47m, roughly some $120m in the form of new investment in mining and the remainder, some $66m, in research and development, which is of benefit to more than just the Queensland coal industry, because it comes back to the importance of research and development. I believe there is a strong future for the coal industry, particularly if it develops the clean coal technologies, strategically links with the user end of the industry and builds on our strength as clean, low sulphur, low ash producers of coal.

The third aspect of the agreement that we were able to reach with BHP-Utah was in relation to rehabilitation. In many senses, it is the ecologically sustainable development process in practice. One need look no further than the statement made by Bob Flew from BHP-Utah when he said in relation to those commitments, `But for our preparedness to abolish and enter into agreement to abolish the coal export duties, those investments would not have been made'.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
