TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, upon notice, on 24 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: Will the Office of the Status of Women (OSW) launch a housework sharing campaign in April 1992; if so, (a) what are the aims and objectives of the campaign, (b) who initiated the campaign, (c) does the OSW fall within the Prime Minister's area of portfolio responsibility, (d) did the Prime Minister approve the campaign, (e) what sum will be spent on the campaign, (f) over what period will the sum be spent and (g) how will the sum be spent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: No. The honourable member may however be referring to the educational materials produced for the Working Families: Sharing the Load Program, which I launched on 9 April in Sydney. These materials provided to the honourable member were produced by the Office of the Status of Women, under ILO Convention No 156 on Workers with Family Responsibilities, and are complementary to the workplace initiatives being undertaken by the Work and Family Unit in the Department of Industrial Relations.

(a) One of the major aims of the ILO 156 Convention on Workers with Family Responsibilities is to promote community awareness and attitudinal change which will minimise the pressures faced by workers with family responsibilities. Much of the implementation of the Convention is being co-ordinated through the Department of Industrial Relations' Work and Family Unit. Legislative and workplace reform will need to be complemented by new patterns of organisation and sharing by individual family members.

The Office of the Status of Women has received funding to conduct a community education program over three years to specifically address the issue of women's double load of paid and unpaid work. International and Australian research demonstrates that although women are moving into the workforce in increasing numbers, they are continuing to carry the vast majority of domestic responsibilities as well. This burden is not only affecting women's capacity to take full advantage of equal employment opportunities, but it is also taking its toll on health, relationships and on family life.

Materials developed by OSW have been welcomed by a wide range of community and government bodies as there is a dearth of educational resources addressing work/family issues. Marriage Guidance Australia, an organisation at the front line of relationship counselling, and similar groups around the country have received the materials with enthusiasm, expressing relief that this enormously common problem of balancing work and family is finally being recognised and addressed.

Double load has been identified as a concern around the world. In 1991, Mr. Francis Blanchard, Special Advisor to the Secretary General of the OECD and former Director General of the International Labour Organisation, chaired a high-level group of experts which reported on directions to encourage structural change to improve the status of women, which included finding a better balance of work and family responsibilities.

The educational materials produced by OSW carry the endorsement of the 1994 UN International Year of the Family as they are consistent with its aims to foster equality between women and men within families and bring about a fuller sharing of domestic responsibilities and employment opportunities.

(b) In March 1990 the former Prime Minister announced that the Government would ratify ILO Convention No 156 and fund a community education program in OSW to assist in implementing the Convention. The Government also established the Work and Family Unit in the Department of Industrial Relations, with responsibility for the development of an implementation strategy for the Convention across Commonwealth policies and programs. OSW's Working Families Program is one element in this strategy.

Requests for the materials have come in from a wide cross section of the community including universities and schools, libraries, government offices, health centres, private companies and the media, local and overseas. The materials developed for the Program here received public support from a range of people volunteering as role models for the Program. These included media personalities Geraldine Doogue and George Negus, Jennifer Rowe from the Australian Women's Weekly, AFL footballer Simon Madden, Don Edgar from the Australian Institute of Family Studies and Michael Bittman from the University of New South Wales.
(c) Yes. OSW falls within the portfolio responsibility of the Prime Minister and also myself in my capacity as the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women.
(d) See (b) above. I repeat that the Government is fully committed to implementing ILO 156.
(e) and (f)
The funding provided to OSW for the Working Families: Sharing the Load education program is $415 000 over the three year period 1990-93.

(g) The funds are being spent on staffing (1.5 staff), research, consultation, strategic planning and the production and distribution of educational materials which are available to relevant agencies and individuals who request them. Approximately 1700 educators from academic, health, community and workplace areas and individuals have already requested the materials. The major program components which have been completed are:

the production of Michael Bittman's 1991 analysis of the Australian Bureau of Statistics 1987 Pilot Time Use Survey, Juggling Time—How Australian Families Use Time, and a booklet, Selected Findings from Juggling Time and the collected papers of the National Women's Consultative Council Conference on ILO 156, Sharing the Load. The materials continue to attract a positive response from the media and the community.
the development of an Issues Kit with accompanying speakers notes, media notes and a poster frieze, outlining the issues relevant to work and family and double load.
the production of a catalyst Video and facilitators booklet, to stimulate discussion on the issues concerning workers with family responsibilities.
Further components of the educational program currently being developed are:
a Family Information Project being undertaken by Graeme Russell of Macquarie University to produce educational curriculum materials and take-home resource materials for families; and
State and Territory initiatives to introduce and explain the Working Families: Sharing the Load educational materials to parent educators and others who have requested the resources.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 24 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the complete range of documents which require the signature of a witness.
(2) In which circumstances is it necessary for a third party to certify or attest to the character or status of another party by way of signature.

(3) Which professions or qualifications are recognised as entitling a person to (a) sign as a witness in each case referred to in part (1) or (b) certify or attest to another person's character or status in each case referred to in part (2).
(4) In each case, why are the professions or qualifications referred to in part (3) deemed to be recognised.

(5) Is (a) a professionally trained engineer, (b) a person who is a Fellow of the Institution of Engineers and a Fellow of the Australian Computer Society or (c) a professionally trained research scientist recognised to perform the functions referred to in part (3); if not, in each case, why not.

(6) What (a) conditions need to be met or (b) processes need to be undertaken to gain accreditation for professionally trained engineers and scientists to perform the functions referred to in part (3).
(7) Will he initiate measures to gain that accreditation; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question asked by the honourable member is extraordinarily wide. It extends to the requirements imposed by Federal, State and Territory law and for both public and private purposes. I do not propose to authorise the use of extensive resources in my Department to answer this question. However, I answer the honourable member's questions in relation to the following:

PARA.TAB: (1) Statutory declarations and affidavits are the principal documents that require signature by a witness. Statutory Declarations are made for the purposes of Commonwealth or Territory law under the provisions of the Statutory Declarations Act 1959. Affidavits are made under the provisions of rules of court.

Affidavits require that the deponent swear to the truth of the facts stated in the affidavit by swearing on oath or affirming in the presence of a witness. After witnessing the deponent's signature at the bottom of every page of the affidavit, the witness then also signs the document. Affidavits are used in court proceedings. For purposes other than court proceedings, a statutory declaration is sufficient.

A statutory declaration is a written statement of fact declared to be true in the presence of a person authorised to be a witness. When making a declaration, the declarant is not required to take an oath. After declaring that the contents of the declaration are true, the declarant then signs the statement in the presence of a person authorised to take the declaration. The witness then also signs the declaration. It should be noted that at no time does the witness attest to the truthfulness or accuracy of the contents of the document, or to the declarant's identity.
Under the Corporations Law and the Corporations Regulations the following documents, if lodged under that legislation, also require the signature of a witness:
(i) Subscribers to a memorandum of a company must each sign the memorandum in the presence of at least one witness (not being another subscriber): paragraph 117(3)(b);

(ii) An application for incorporation of a company must be signed by each subscriber to the memorandum (in the case of proprietary companies), or at least one subscriber (in other cases), in the presence of at least one witness (not being another subscriber): subsection 118(4);
(iii) A company's articles of association are to be signed by each subscriber to the memorandum in the presence of at least one witness (not being another subscriber): paragraph 125(4)(c); and

(iv) The proxy of a person entitled to attend and vote at a meeting of creditors in a winding up, who is blind or incapable of writing, must not be accepted unless the instrument is read to him or her by a witness to his or her signature or mark (not being the person nominated as proxy) who completes the certificate of witness set out in Form 532: regulation 5.6.29(3).
(2) None of the documents mentioned in (1) require a third party to certify or attest to the character or status of another party.
(3) (a) Affidavits for use in federal proceedings may be sworn:

PARA.TAB: The witnesses of documents made under the Corporations Law and the Corporations Regulations need not have any qualifications.
(4) In relation to affidavits I am unable to state the considerations that the judges of federal courts have taken into account in determining who may witness an affidavit.

In relation to Statutory Declarations, the Statutory Declarations Act was amended in 1991, by removing the provisions for the appointment of Commissioners for Declarations and providing that statutory declarations could be witnessed by any of a class of persons referred to in regulations. Regulations have been made. The classes of persons referred to in those regulations were, essentially, those who could previously witness a statutory declaration and, in addition, the classes of person that had previously been authorised to witness an application for an Australian passport, and professions, such as the nursing profession, who could be expected to meet a need for witnesses in the community.

Provisions of the Corporations Law also require the preparation of statutory declarations and affidavits. However, with one exception, the requirements for the witnessing of those documents are the general requirements set out in the Commonwealth Statutory Declarations Act and relevant State Acts and Court Rules, and are not peculiar to the Corporations Law. That exception is the provision in Regulation 5.6.57 of the Corporations Regulations that a liquidator in a winding up by the court may administer an affirmation or oath, or take an affidavit, for the purposes of the liquidator's duties in relation to admitting a debt or claim.

(5) Prior to the amendment, Commissioners for Declarations were appointed from limited groups of persons—Commonwealth public servants and officers of ACT financial institutions. To be appointed, members of these groups were required to demonstrate a need to witness declarations in the course of their employment. No such need has previously been identified in the case of the professional groups referred to in the honourable member's question.
(6) I am unaware of any process of accreditation for persons to witness affidavits or statutory declarations.

(7) I will give consideration to the making of regulations to expand the list of persons who may witness a statutory declaration, and will consider whether professional engineers and research scientists should be included in that list at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 25 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: 1. Did the Commonwealth Criminal Law Review Committee recommend in its final report in December 1991 that legislation be enacted on the lines of the United Kingdom Genocide Act 1989 to implement fully Australia's obligations under the 1948 Genocide Convention.
2. Has the Government considered enacting the necessary provisions of the Convention.
3. Did Part II of the Human Rights Bill 1973 contain clauses to give effect to the rights recognised in the 1966 Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
4. Has the Government considered adopting legislative measures to give effect to the rights recognised in the Covenant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: 1. Yes. I mention that the Genocide Convention came into force for Australia in 1951. While the Gibbs Committee found that existing Australian law provides adequate penalties for most of the acts described in the Convention as genocide, some of these acts are not offences under Australian law.
2. Consideration is being given to the enactment of appropriate legislation.
3. Yes.
4. This Government is fully committed to complying with Australia's obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights

ANSWER.PARA: (`the ICCPR'). There is no obligation under the ICCPR to implement it by introducing specific legislation. There now exists a wide range of measures, including Federal, State and Territory legislation, which give protection to the rights recognised under the Covenant.

PARA.TAB: This Government and previous Governments have enacted a range of legislation specifically designed to protect human rights. This legislation includes the following:

ANSWER.PARA: the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986

PARA.TAB: The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 came into effect on 10 December 1986. The ICCPR is one of five international instruments attached as Schedules to the Act. The Commission is empowered to promote human rights as defined in the Covenant as well as to administer the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, to settle complaints and to undertake research and education activities. (These Acts, while enacted in furtherance of the specific UN conventions on race and sex discrimination, also give partial effect to Australia's obligations under Article 2 of the ICCPR to eliminate all forms of discrimination based on status.)

In addition to the passage of the Sex Discrimination Act, in 1988 the Parliament passed the Privacy Act which commenced on 1 January 1989. The Preamble to that Act refers to the ICCPR and to Australia's undertaking under the Covenant "to give effect to the right of persons not to be subjected to arbitrary or unlawful interference with their privacy, family, home or correspondence" (Article 17).
The Government is also considering enactment of legislation on discrimination on the basis of disability.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 25 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did he receive evidence from the Western Australian Forest Alliance in December 1991 of alleged breaches of environmental conditions on the woodchip export licence granted to the WA Chip and Pulp Company Pty Ltd; if so, (a) what were the alleged breaches, (b) what was his response to the Western Australian Forest Alliance and (c) what action (i) has he taken to investigate the allegations and (ii) will he take if there have been breaches.
(2) Has the export licence been renewed; if so, (a) on what date and (b) for what period.
(3) Will he present a copy of the export licence to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I have received from the Western Australian Forest Alliance unsubstantiated allegations that the WA Chip and Pulp Company breached some of the conditions of its export licence in 1991.

(a) The Western Australian Forest Alliance alleged that, when planning and conducting logging operations on Crown land in Western Australia, the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management (CALM) has failed to comply with the conditions of the Western Australian Minister for the Environment's 1988 approval of the woodchip export operations of the WA Chip and Pulp Company. The Western Australian Forest Alliance alleged that, by purchasing pulpwood from CALM, the company is in breach of its export licence which requires the company to comply with the WA Minister for the Environment's approval.

The Western Australian Forest Alliance also alleged that a delegation by the Western Australian Minister for the Environment to the Commissioner for Soil Conservation of the Minister's power to authorise the WA Chip and Pulp Company to use pulpwood from certain private property operations is illegal. The Alliance alleges that any logging operations authorised on private property by the Commissioner or Deputy Commissioner for Soil Conservation are therefore illegal, and that the purchase of pulpwood resulting from these operations is therefore also illegal.
(b) I have sought comments from the Western Australian Minister for the Environment on the allegations and I have advised the Alliance of this action.
(c) (i) I have sought comments from the State Minister for the Environment.
(ii) I will not be making any decision on further action until I have considered the State Minister's comments.
(2) Yes. The licence was renewed on 19 December 1991 for the period from 1 January 1992 to 31 December 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 25 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has he received a copy of the Victorian Government response dated June 1991 to the report of the inquiry by the Victorian Parliamentary Social Development Committee into vehicle occupant protection.
(2) Has he received submissions from the Victorian Minister for Transport concerning recommendations in the report.
(3) Has he referred the submissions referred to in part (2) to the Australian Transport Advisory Council; if so, when.
(4) Has he specified a date by which the Council is required to report on the matters referred to it; if so, what date; if not, will he ask the Council to report in 1992.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, I have received a copy of the Victorian Government response dated June 1991 to the report of the inquiry by the Victorian Parliamentary Social Development Committee into vehicle occupant protection.
(2) Yes, I have received submissions from the Victorian Minister for Transport concerning recommendations in the report.

(3) The issue of passenger car occupant protection, including the recommendations of the Social Development Committee report, was considered by the Australian Transport Advisory Council in 1990. As a result, a high level committee was formed to examine the matter.
(4) The Federal Government has been active in the area of occupant protection.

Under the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989, the Commonwealth has legislative responsibility for determining vehicle safety standards which are declared as national standards. The Act is administered by the Federal Office of Road Safety.
The Australian motorist already enjoys the benefit of vehicle safety standards which are amongst the most stringent in the world.

Our rules are largely harmonised with international standards, and Australia has led the world in a number of safety areas such as seat belts and safety requirements for Forward Control Passenger Vehicles.
The Federal Government has taken the initiative of allocating significant additional funds for research into passenger car occupant protection.

A major study was commissioned in 1989 by the Federal Office of Road Safety to examine how vehicles are performing in real life crashes with a view to identifying areas for improvement. This report recommends the examination of a number of measures to improve occupant protection.
Following on from this work, the Federal Government has embarked on a $1 million standards development program incorporating the following main elements:

ANSWER.PARA: Crash testing of seven Australian produced vehicles to provide baseline data
Autoliv in Germany, a world leader in seat belt and airbag technology, to analyse the data to develop and provide enhanced safety systems to be used for further tests
Three further crash tests on Australian cars fitted with these enhanced safety systems
A study of the cost effectiveness and feasibility of safety options
A study of consumer willingness to pay for safety measures
Laboratory tests on a range of new technologies to be undertaken for the Federal Office of Road Safety by the NSW Roads and Traffic Authority
Research into crash data on side and offset crashes, spinal injuries and injuries to rear seat passengers.

PARA.TAB: The aim of the Federal Office of Road Safety research program is to identify the causes of injuries to vehicle occupants and to help develop a cost effective strategy to reduce these injuries.
This program of research and analysis will determine the effectiveness, feasibility, cost, and industry implications of options to improve occupant protection.

The high level committee mentioned in part (3) involving the States, Territories, motoring associations and representatives of the motor vehicle industry has overseen the various parts of this research.

The Federal Government will be looking for practical, cost effective and achievable outcomes so at the end of the day, the Australian travelling public will have affordable vehicles which provide a high level of occupant protection at the forefront of international standards.
This research is well advanced and results are expected by the middle of 1992 together with recommendations for consideration by Government.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Armed Forces: Death Penalty in World War II

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 30 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did courts martial impose death sentences on members of the Australian armed forces during World War II; if so, for what crimes were the sentences imposed.
(2) Were any of the sentences referred to in part (1) carried out; if so, in each case, (a) when, (b) where and (c) how.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes; for murder.

During World War II, section 98 of the Defence Act 1903 provided that no member of the Defence Force was to be sentenced to death by any court-martial except for mutiny, desertion to the enemy, traitorously delivering up to the enemy any garrison, fortress, post, guard, or ship, vessel, or boat, or aircraft, or traitorous correspondence with the enemy, and that no sentence of death passed by any court martial was to be carried into effect until confirmed by the Governor-General.
Inquiries have revealed no case in which a member of the Australian armed forces was sentenced to death by a court martial for any of the abovementioned offences.

However, in April 1942, two members of the Royal Australian Navy were sentenced to death by a court martial, having been convicted of the murder of another sailor. This was possible because, during World War II, all members of the RAN were unconditionally transferred to the Royal Navy, so that the Naval Discipline Act 1866 applied to them. That Act provided that every person guilty of murder shall suffer death.

After the trial, an application was made to the High Court of Australia for an order preventing the death penalty being carried out. The High Court held that the transfer of the sailors to the Royal Navy had the effect that the Naval Discipline Act 1866 applied to them without modification, so that section 98 of the Defence Act 1903 did not apply, and that the sentence of death was lawful. See The King v Bevan; Ex parte Elias and Gordon (66 CLR 452).

(2) No. The Royal prerogative of mercy was exercised and the sentence was not carried out. The two sailors eventually served 8 years in prison. For information, it is advised that the two convicted sailors were sentenced 'to be hanged by the neck until they be dead on board such one of His Majesty's Australian Ships and at such time as the Board of Administration for the Naval Forces shall direct.'

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Fraser Island and Great Sandy Region

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 31 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the attributes of the town of Rainbow Beach, Qld, which led to its inclusion in the area of Fraser Island and the Great Sandy Region nominated for World Heritage listing.
(2) Did the Widgee Shire Council and the Rainbow Beach Chamber of Commerce submit that Rainbow Beach should be excluded from the nominated area; if so, has she considered their submission.
(3) What restrictions will be placed on the future growth of Rainbow Beach if it is accorded World Heritage listing.
(4) Is exclusion of Rainbow Beach from the Fraser Island and Great Sandy Region nomination for World Heritage listing being considered.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Rainbow Beach is part of the Fraser Island—Cooloola sand mass. The natural values of that sand mass have been nominated against all four natural criteria of the World Heritage Committee Operational Guidelines as follows:
(i) be outstanding examples representing the major stages of the earth's evolutionary history; or
(ii) be outstanding examples representing significant ongoing geological processes, biological evolution and man's interaction with his natural environment; or
(iii) contain superlative natural phenomena, formations or features; or

(iv) contain the most important and significant natural habitats where threatened species of animals or plants of outstanding universal value, from the point of view of science or conservation, still survive.

(2) I have no record of receiving submissions from the Widgee Shire Council or the Rainbow Beach Chamber of Commerce. I understand that both made submissions to the Commission of Inquiry into the Conservation, Management and Use of Fraser Island and the Great Sandy Region which was established by the Queensland Government. I am advised those submissions would have been considered by the Commission of Inquiry and therefore by the Queensland Government before that Government decided to support the World Heritage nomination.

(3) Restrictions would be imposed only on activities which are incompatible with the universal natural values for which the area was nominated to the World Heritage List. State and local laws continue to apply.

(4) The Fraser Island and Great Sandy Region nomination is presently being assessed by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN). Variations to the boundaries of a nominated area are not unusual in the assessment process. I would consider any advice on variations to the boundary that might be made by the IUCN or World Heritage Bureau during the assessment process. Any decision to vary the nominated boundary would have to be taken on the basis of World Heritage values.

(c) There are no departmental activities inconsistent with the pursuit of Government policies of maximising employment growth.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 28 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: Following the Prime Minister's pledge at the start of the One Nation strategy to fight the battle against unemployment and for economic recovery with all the energy he can muster, is Commonwealth Funds Management Limited giving pre-eminence to the goal of growth of employment in Australia in its corporate planning and policy development; if so, (a) how is pre-eminence being given, (b) in what ways is the goal being implemented and (c) are there any organisational activities which are inconsistent with maximising employment growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Commonwealth Funds Management Limited (CFM) does not continue to have the trustee role that its predecessor the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust had in managing the moneys in the Superannuation Fund established under the Superannuation Act 1976.

CFM operates as a general funds manager and invests according to directions given to it by its various clients. Therefore it has only a limited role in deciding whether to invest in ways which promote employment growth or otherwise.

The trustee role formerly held by the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust has been transferred to the Commonwealth Superannuation Boards of Trustees Nos 1 and 2. The Boards have overall responsibility for the management and investment of the moneys in the superannuation funds for the 1990 Public Sector Superannuation Scheme and the 1976 Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme respectively. The day to day investment activities are carried out by CFM in accordance with the directions of the Boards.

The Boards have a statutory obligation to act in the best interests of the members of the schemes. The Trustees have adopted an investment strategy which has the primary objective of maximising the expected rates of return over the long term while investing prudently. The Boards' investment strategy concentrates on the growth and protection of members' funds rather than directing funds to areas where employment growth is maximised. Indeed, if a strategy to maximise employment were adopted at the expense of members' returns, this would not be consistent with Boards' trustee role.

While it would have been open to the Government to provide more specific investment guidelines in the Boards' charters, this would have been inconsistent with its broader superannuation policy which places the responsibility for managing and investing superannuation funds with boards of trustees comprising equal numbers of member and employer nominees.

Nevertheless the Boards' powers cover the full spectrum of investment activities. Consequently, the Boards are active in all the mainstream investment sectors. A significant amount of the Boards' investments through CFM support Australian companies, which has the effect of providing capital to them, thereby indirectly assisting employment. Also other investments by CFM involve direct participation in the development and refurbishment of commercial projects and the provision of infrastructure for business, notably in the rural and tourism industries.

CFM numbers among its clients other boards of trustees for military and Government Business Enterprise schemes. The investments on behalf of CFM's other clients would also operate to assist employment in the manner described above.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet: Employment Goals

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 29 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: Following your pledge at the start of the One Nation strategy to fight the battle against unemployment and for economic recovery with all the energy you can muster, is your Department giving pre-eminence to the goal of growth of employment in Australia in its corporate planning and policy development; if so, (a) how is pre-eminence being given, (b) in what ways is the goal being implemented and (c) are there any departmental activities which are inconsistent with maximising employment growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) and (b) The Department's primary corporate goal is "to advise and inform on those matters requiring the Prime Minister's attention as the Head of Government and the Chairperson of Cabinet." Promoting economic recovery and employment growth has been a high priority for the Government during the year, and the Department has provided extensive support for the preparation of two Prime Ministerial economic statements, including fiscal and other initiatives to accelerate and sustain economic recovery and foster the creation of new jobs. These statements were prompted by the recognition that economic recovery was not occurring as quickly as expected when the 1991-92 Budget was introduced.
(c) There are no departmental activities inconsistent with the pursuit of Government policies of maximising employment growth.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Convention on the Rights of the Child

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing

QUESTION.PARA: the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 29 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: Will the Minister bring up-to-date the information in the answer to question No. 522 (Hansard, 11 March 1991, page 1738) concerning the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: I refer the honourable member to the answer to question No. 1323 (Hansard, 30 March 1992, page 1434) which provided the information requested. Since that list was compiled Tunisia (30 January 1992), Lesotho (10 March 1992) and the Central African Republic (23 April 1992) have ratified the Convention and Lithuania (31 January 1992) and Latvia (14 April 1992) have acceded to the Convention.
